content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								“Two possibilities exist: Either we are alone in the Universe or we are not. Both are equally terrifying.”―Arthur C. Clarke


The Solus Project 
A Screenshot of The Solus Project
By: SABINA




The Solus Project is among the most engrossing games I've played. The creators have clearly put a lot of time and thought into creating this world and its story. While still in Early Access, it is important to note that the current content and gameplay is complete and polished. Regular updates add more content and areas to explore. And exploration is where this game shines. Stranded on an alien planet, with an unstable, volatile weather system, you must survive to make contact with a humanity that has lost it's home and desperately needs a new one. As you search the open-world for parts to build a communications tower and survival goods, as well as try to survive the richly atmospheric weather, you begin to reveal a deep story behind the planet's inhabitants. The mounting level of intrigue, even horror at times, is expertly written and delivered. Anyone at all interested in aliens/ancient aliens lore will be immediately swept into the story and begin to formulate theories of their own.  “The land through which we have gone, in spying it out, is a land that devours its inhabitants; and all the people whom we saw in it are men of great size. There also we saw the Nephilim, the sons of Anak; and we became like grasshoppers in our own sight, and so we were in their sight." -Numbers 13:32-33


The Solus Project 
A Screenshot of The Solus Project
By: SABINA




The story seems to hint at ideas most popularly written by the likes of Zechariah Sitchin and Erich von Däniken, concerning such things as Nibiru (the theoretical tenth planet in a much wider elipse of the sun), Sumerian myths concerning the Annunaki, and the much interpreted biblical passages concerning the Nephilim, more widely written about in the apocryphal Books of Enoch. "The Nephilim were on the earth in those days, and also afterward, when the sons of God (bene Elohim) came in to the daughters of men, and they bore children to them."  Genesis 6:4


The Solus Project 
A Screenshot of The Solus Project
By: SABINA




At its heart, The Solus Project is an exploration game. The game world is beautifully rendered with UE4 and highly optimized for any machine. While it is tagged as a survival game, it doesn't have some of the common elements of EA open-world survival games such as crafting menus and base-building. This absence does not detract from immersion in any way. The story touches on themes that no other game has ever touched, remarkably so, because it is a rich treasure trove of fascination, mystery and intrigue, and yes, as Arthur C. Clarke so famously said; absolute terror.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												Excellent game, one of my new favorites for exploration/puzzles in first person. The storyline moves really well, the graphics and textures are on point. The first ten minutes can be a little daunting as you understand how to combine items and how the game's flow is going to be but after that it carries onward. If you aren't interested in storylines you might not find this as good just from a puzzle perspective. There's no combat at any point, either. It plays a little like Amnesia but somehow feels like Portal 2 in terms of the atmosphere. I haven't found nearly all the locations and "secrets" that are in the game yet, as I was driven to complete it and understand the full story. The story itself is something unique and interesting, not much can be said about it without giving too much away though. The controls all made sense and managing health/thirst/hunger/sleep seems daunting at first but is manageable once you realize where the game is going to put resources for you. The only bug I encountered was with the inventory. Sometimes the inventory would disappear when you move your mouse and you'd have to do this multiple times before you could actually switch items. You can use the keyboard to do this too, but in some situations time was of the essence. The only negative part of the game is the male protagonist's voice acting. It's just terrible all-around. The quality of the voice isn't the issue as much as his acting, which is disjointed and awkward sounding. The character speaks probably less than ten times throughout the game, giving short audio diaries to send home that you listen to, but each time given the circumstances he's in at the moment his attitude and demeanor is entirely inappropriate which draws from the immersion of the game. I'd say his acting is on par with a high school theater student. Even without a change to the script, replacing his lines with a more capable voice actor would carry the game a lot further in the long run. I'm not sure how the female voice is, but I will try that option for my next playthrough.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												Review is based on the non VR version of the game.I am fascinated by the end of the world topic / exploring a distant alien planet and this kind of ScFi adventure games as such. This game delivers it all in very good quality! I’ve been following its development since 2013 and now I have seen the end!The main objective is to reestablish the radio transmission / call out for help. But this isn’t as easy as it seems at first glance. You have to survive the extreme climate (tornadoes, storms, meteors, etc.) and the deadly/dark secrets buried beneath the surface of this hostile planet. This journey can be done with a female or male character. The world (vast!) setup: 5 islands, 10 levels, 60 locations, 118 secrets and 513 documents to discover, if desired.  So make sure that you complete all your objectives, to avoid additional backtracking. Gameplay: First person, main focus is clearly exploration, but with survival elements. (Look for shelter, food, water, etc.) Difficulty multiplayer 0-100% available, select between easy and hardcore mode. (…never seen this before in any game) The following character parameters can be influenced by “artifacts”: Health and Inventory limit, Movement & Resistances: Hypothermia, Heat stroke, Starvation, Dehydration and Falling. “Easy to go crafting; combine 2-3 items”. You can save your progress almost always, when you're sleeping.Graphics (Unreal Engine): Amazing day and night cycles. The very decent graphics, with great attention to detail, reflected in diversified level design fills the planet and its hazards with life. There are a lot of settings to adjust the details of graphics quality. (Presets, VSync, Field of view, etc.)  Sound: Realistic, well done quality of waves, thunderstorms, the howling of the wind, etc. There are very atmospheric, selectively placed elements of music.  Score:  The story and dense atmosphere kept me hooked from the very beginning till the bitter end…! Clear recommendation! 9/10

content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												Have a Vive and want a full game experience? Pick this up. Bought it for Vive and were frustrated by the controls? Update it and load it again - it's like a brand new game.FIrst for the people who tried it and walked away because of the "In Prgoress" controls. The 1.02 patch released today adds the ability to point a controller in the direction you want to go while free-looking. You can D-pad move or teleport, your choice, on the fly. And most importantly, the game interface now supports the Vive controllers. This was HUGE for me. No more clicking through your inventory one at a time. No more guessing which item will come up. No more crafting nightmares. No more trying to remember which button does what, because it's all look at the screen and direct select what you want. On top of that, your PDA is now functional by pressing the buttons with the other controller for the objective screen, sleep, status, and even zoom. This pretty much addresses every problem I had with gameplay, that turned exploration into a chore as I fumbled for light or tried to refill my canteen or get some shuteye. Instead of rushing through the game to finish, I now want to explore every nook and cranny and with this new control scheme I plan to do just that. So - if you bought SP for your Vive but quit because it made you want to stomp your controllers, update it, fire it up and give it another go. It's totally worth it (especially since you already bought it, right?)If you don't have it yet, the new VR additions make it a must buy VR experience. There aren't any other real adventure/exploration games out there yet. Bear in mind this isn't a shooter but more of a dungeon crawl. It's closer to Tomb Raider than Mass Effect. There's no combat, only traps and enemies to avoid, and an environment that's trying to kill you. But it's a way cool environment, with islands and caves to explore, ancient catacombs, some really interesting plants and animals and an interesting mystery that almost works until the end. But Solus Project put me on an alien planet. I can't think of higher praise for a VR title. I believed I was on another world with its own weather, climate, tides, etc. I wanted to explore, and by the end of the game as I started firguring out where things were and how things worked, my little base camp on top of a cliff started feeling like home.  Even with all of the issues I had with the ocontrols prior to this current version, I had to keep going. Just when I was getting tired of the beach, I found the caves. I got tired of seeing the caves, here come some ruins... And after the ruins? The game kept throwing new things at me right about the time I started thinking "is this all there is to this game?" Right now, I don't think there's another game that can touch it for absoulte immersion. As for the gameplay itself, like I said, think Tomb Raider over Mass Effect. The story moves along like a lot of other standard adventures with written and audio logs. What interaction you have with plot elements are all scripted but flow well. There's a survival element which is fun at first but can become a drag, though the longer you explore the stronger you can get and the less you have to do it (plus now you won't have to fight the lack of an inventory screen - made surivival a HUGE hassle.) There is also a minor horror element to it, more psychological than anything and there are some hugely effective moments as you start to think "Did I just see that" which later turn into "Oh♥♥♥♥♥♥I AM seeing this and it's kinda freaking me out..." There are one or two jump scares as well, which if you're not careful will make you jump through a virtual door and run into your physical wall. This too, is high praise for a video game but no joke, I heard a noise behind me,  turned and saw something nasty charging me and tried to leap out of the way on reflex and smacked right into the wall in the real world. Again, high praise for making me forget I was in my living room.The game still has some flaws... IMO the story doesn't have a solid ending, it's possible to abuse room scale to get through locked doors, and there still aren't loading screens in VR which mean you see your VR lobby in between levels. Also, if you're not into exploration, this isn't the game for you because that's the hart of this game: wanting to see what's around the next corner. Solus Project delivers that in spades, and with this latest Vive patch it's finally a top tier VR experience.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
												5/5 Stars, absolutely would recommend!This is a VR review of the game.Are there flaws with the VR? Yes. Could it have been done better? Yes. That said, this is still the single best experience so far for the HTC Vive I've played, approximately 40 or so games/experiences (Haven't played starseed yet).The Cons:-Movement can be worked on a bit as it's all over the place regarding which implementation your using. This could arguably be a good thing as well, as you have the opportunity for both normal locomotion and teleporting.-Inventory system is extremely weak and a bit frustrating clicking through until you get to the item you want.-You need a beefy PC. I'm running a 8 core extreme i7 and a 980ti and still had to turn down the settings. The resolution scale should be at 150% no matter what or its blurry but the game still looks fantastic. Disable AA as its making the experience worse.-VR controls not intuitive. If I have a torch, I should be able to light a candle by bringing the flame close. Little things like this break immersion but again this wasn't built ground up for VR.Now for the Pros:-Stunning atmosphere. The game feels amazing and I quickly forget where I actually am. The music, the scenery, the sound effects all work seamlessly to create an amazing experience.-Tension. The game is not a horror game, at least not up to where I am, but it has an amazing tension that is building as I play. No jump scares, but definitely a healthy presence of danger and threat. This is amplified by VR and is quite frankly amazing.-Mystery. This game does a brilliant job at showing you there's something going on but not telling you outright. Its a great balance between trying to find clues while exploring as you progress through the game. Many secrets to be found.-One of the biggest and most important pros are that the Devs are vocal in the community. They're on reddit taking feedback and using it to fix many of the issues we're seeing. The most recent update fixed many of these issues immediately.-Content. As far as the content goes, I would say that this game as 2-3 times as much content as the next highest game on the vive(excluding simulators). This is the first real roomscale game that you can take time to enjoy as you're playing through it and exploring. As great as vanishing realms is, this game has much more meat than just 2 hours!All in all, the pros vastly outweigh the cons and this is a game any vive owner should have. It's truly a shame that the work in progress feature they added (VR) caused it to have so many negative reviews when it clearly says its not ready and in an alpha state. Please note that while the VR is not finished and not perfect, this game MORE than deserves your time and money. If this were any other Vive game, the price should be over 100$ based on the content equivalent of similar Vive games, at 20$ this is an absolute STEAL.Please support the developers and write them a good review as this game is exceptional and the few people who cant read that VR is a work in progress, should not tarnish its reputation.5/5 Stars, absolutely would recommend!

content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												Holy sh** this game is captivating. All the negative reviews are from VR kids who don't like the VR implementation. If you don't care about VR, then there is no reason not to buy this. Absolutely worth the full $20.It's a survival game, but there are more things to be mindful of than in most survival games. Ways you can fail to survive include:--Starvation--Dehydration--Hypothermia--Overheating--Exhaustion (lack of sleep)--Physical damage to body (falling, etc)The game makes all of these even more challening by putting you on a planet with volatile temperature and weather conditions. One minute the temperature is below freezing so you have to huddle in a cave throwing sticks on a fire while waiting for the cold front to pass, then the next minute it's blistering hot so that you have to run from shade to shade to keep your body temp from rising too high. And of course you have to stay on top of food and water.Unlike other survival games, there is no farming---only gathering. And there is technically no storage, although you can still hoarde piles of things because the game will remember where you dropped them.Also unlike other survival games, there is a narrative and an overarching goal to this game. It's not just a game of seeing how long you can survive---you're also trying to scavenge materials from crash sites to build a satellite uplink. There are also huge caves and dungeons to explore (be sure to bring food, water, and light!)---not to mention loads of secret items as exploration rewards.If you like survival gameplay but also like exploring and having a definite end goal, then this game is worth every cent.I emphasize again that this review pertains to the regular, non-VR experience.*edit*Updating this review because it's also worth noting the following:--This is first and foremost an adventure/exploration game, but there are some survival elements as described above. HOWEVER. The game lets you tweak the survival settings to make them more intense or, if you prefer, make them completely negligible so you can focus on just the exploration (which is also fantastic!). So FYI if you like exploring but dislike survival.--By default the game uses the metric system. But if you were born in stubborn America, like me, then the game options can be tweaked to use Fahrenheit / ounces / miles / etc.--By default the protagonist is male, but you can switch to a female voice in options (mostly just your typical grunts and groans, but the protagonist DOES talk occasionally, so take your preference).*/edit*7) A classic, essential, and/or must-buy game that is worth full price.6) A good game that is worth the full price.5) A pretty good game worth checking out--especially if discounted.4) A fairly good game, but I'd recommend buying it discounted.3) Not great, but a few redeeming qualities. Only buy if heavily discounted.2) Only worth checking out if you are dangerously curious.1) Avoid at all costs.

content:
Posted: March 24
The Solus Project - detailed reviewThe Solus Project is an adventure-type game, in which we have to survive on a human-unfriendly planet, where meteor rains and deadly tornadoes are common aspects of living. Our task is to communicate with the mother-ship, however the communication system is broken. As we try to fix it, it turns out that we aren't the first human-like creatures to live on that planet.Gameplay conceptThe game puts emphasis on storytelling and atmosphere. As developers mentioned, the game also consists of exploration and survival, but don't take these as major elements. Survival itself isn't demanding and player is guided where to go in order to continue. Unless we want to explore deeper, optional areas - to find out every secret hidden in the game - we won't have any problems.ProsMusicBeautiful, ambient music composed by Jonas Kjellberg accompanies us through the entire journey. It changes depending on where we are, what we are doing and whether we are in danger or not. I have to admit that without so magnificent music this game would be much worse experience.Graphics & visual performanceCongratulations to developers! Smoothly rendered and good quality graphics are hard to achieve, but here it couldn't have been done better. I haven't experienced any lag issues so far and had all the chunks loaded before entering a certain location - perfect!StoryRich in secrets, complex environment pays off for rather linear story with no side-quests. There are plenty of references to famous alien-like movies, books, etc., but I won't mention them here (find them!). Story idea itself is quite genuine and well told. It also does contain some horror-like elements, which, together with magnificent music mentioned above, creep you out very well. Great!ConsPoor fauna/floraWhile locations like alien structures or caves are really detailed and diverse, flora and fauna could be much more improved. It simply lacks variety, even for the planet with surface created of rocks. Why not add bird-like creatures, if we already can hear them in the game, some fish living in the ocean or stone-like plants chilling at the beach - huge field to fill the game with details, yet not used for anything.SurvivalUnlimited torch fire. Unlimited water source in every cave. Unlimited food and water every checkpoint. Multiple full food/water recovery snacks found everywhere. Plenty of rockets filled with resources dropping from mother-ship. Come on guys, how is it survival? Even while exploring some deeper areas never was I even close to dying from thirst or hunger. And that's almost the harderst difficulty level. In addtion, nearly all puzzles could be solved in seconds and multiple traps found both in caves and alien buildings definitely couldn't be described as "deadly”. I actually used the fire ones to warm myself in cold areas. Smart, isn't it?OverallTo conclude, The Solus project is a beautiful, astonishing game. Its main strengths are story and atmosphere, yet it lacks diversity in planet nature and survival aspects. Strongly recommended for every adventure seeking person! Score: 8/10

								Day 1 - Landed roughly on uninhabited planet. Totally intentional. Toilet is gone.Day 2 - Found nice cave. It's cold as f$%&. Super mega storm with weird sounds and a large tentacle outside. Millions invested in me and I forgot that fire doesn't like water... Shouldn't have left the cave. I will just return to it. Day 6 - Another freak giant storm with a giant tentacle. Aliens? Nah... totally uninhabited planet.Day 7 - I forgot to sleep, my computer says I'm wet, sleepy and tired. I ran out of meat to eat. I need to pee.Day 8 - I am starting a diet on local plants and drinking water from the walls.Day 9 - Maybe I should look for help. I need to go Number 1 and Number 2 but I'm not some savage. I need a toilet.Day 10 - PLANET IS NOT UNINHABITED, REPEAT, PLANET IS NOT UNINHABITED!!! I will NEVER leave this cave!Day 11 - I left the cave. Need to find a toilet.Day 12 - Found another cave, had some ancient alien artifacts of unknown purpose. Totally stole them.Day 13 - I entered another cave and there's some weird stuff inside.Day 14 - I'm never leaving this cave. Not because I like it, but because I don't know what to do and got lost.Day 15 - Solved some puzzles, I'm out of the cave. Day 16 - FREAKING TENTACLE STORMS!Day 17 - Building tower to call home. Lol... I'm like a reversed ET... damn... no I AM the ET... I gotta stop eating these fungi from the floor. Day 18 - Still need to go to the toilet.Day 19 - Found yet another cave. Man, this one looks promising!Day 20 - ALIENS!!!!Day 21 - Some screen popped up saying I need to wait for part two! Damn it... Now I am NOT leaving this cave at all...Buy this game, support the team, it's worth it. So much potential. Plus, it looks awesome.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												You wake up to a foreign sky. The moment you step out you are greeted by a meteor rain or a closing tornado. You turn around and you see an ominous planet just over the horizon. Welcome to Gliese, the mysterious planet on which the Solus Project takes place.The game is described as an advanced environmental survival-exploration game with very mild horror elements. And it's just that. You walk/run around looking for clues to what happened to the other ships from the expedition trying to survive as the planet isn't very friendly – the weather changes from heat to chill, heavy rains, meteor showers, tornadoes may occur instantly and you better run for cover. There are a lot of documents, diaries, photos scattered around and by reading them the player starts learning about the Solus Project and what caused it.At its core the game is a walking simulator, there are very few hostile creatures and your main concern should be looking for food and water and surviving the climate changes, you have no firearms just a teleporting device. And here is where the main problem lies IMO. Most of the time you have to babysit the survivor. Especially annoying is that he gets tired and needs to sleep every 10-15min even after sleeping for 8hrs on a mattress and a pillow. You start exploring an area, tornado/meteors/heavy rains interrupt your exploration, you have to look for cover and wait for the weather to stabilize. Finally you go exploring again and just after a few steps you hear “Operator tired, sleep advised”. You can choose to ignore it but the suit AI won't stop repeating it every 60sec. Or “Operator wet and cold, temperature dropping”. OMG, is the “operator” a trained interstellar explorer or just a boyscout-wanna-be? Aside from that, The Solus Project is a nice exploration game. It has good graphics, interesting story, no bugs or any other setbacks. If you are into stories, exploration, loneliness – this game is for you.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												The Solus Project is too simplistic to be a survival game, too easy to be an old-school adventure game, and too linear and dull to be an exploration game. Survival elements in the game are so dumbed down, they're pointless. Your character doesn't starve or dehydrate as quickly as actual survival games and you have easy access to unlimited food and water at frequent resting spots throughout the game, and other food/water items are easy enough to find anyways. Crafting is extremely limited, with too few items and combinations. Surviving the planet's climate extremes is marginally better, but you spend the majority of the game underground in low temperatures, and you get access to a heating ball fairly early on that renders most of the surviving parts irrelevant. The game's attempt at 'puzzles' is laughably poor. They are either (1) find key to stick in lock/device, (2) put rocks on pressure plates to open door, (3) step on/operate mechanism to select clearly-marked symbol, and if we're being really generous, (4) press button to open door. None of these would ever count as real puzzles in any other game, but this is the best The Solus Project can do. Clearly, this was meant to be the spiritual successor to developer's previous game The Ball only because it involves giant metal spheres as plot devices. And finally, the exploration is limited. You start on a very small island with terrain that, while not completely impassable, locks you into only a handful of paths, most of which just lead you to the single cave/ladder entrance to the island's underground. From there it's a single underground path to travel through, hitting the occasional large space that, again, has a single entrance and single exit, any number of the previously-mentioned non-puzzles, and then you hit the loading screen that takes you to the next island, where you do it all over again. In theory, you can try and wander everywhere to find the secrets the game keeps count of. You could just pull out the teleporter and squeeze yourself into every nook and cranny, or start jumping around the rocks to get places, but what's the point? The secrets you find are items that boost your survival stats, but the survival gameplay as described earlier is completely pointless. And it's not like the setting and story are interesting enough to explore, either. You're basically just walking through the same-old tunnels to find just different varieties of underground temples with different collections of skeletons inside. You figure there would be an interesting story to them, but The Solus Project also falls apart here. The game's only way of communicating is to make you read exposition from these giant stone tablets that your tricorder-like Wilson device translates for you. It's clunky and uninteresting, and you quickly get bored of stopping to read everything. Overall, The Solus Project is a terrible game. If you want a survival game, go buy a real survival game. If you want an adventure game, get one with actual puzzles. If you want something with an interesting world to explore, there are a ton of other options that aren't even open-world. Whatever it is you want, The Solus Project isn't it. Save your money and your time.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
												This game was suggested for me by my Steam Queue, and by the trailer alone I knew this was my kind of game. Gladly I wasn’t wrong. I am a big sucker for Sci-fi stories, and very recently I have been finding out I’m a fan of survival games. This game is a delightful mix of both elements.I have to mention that the Story part is stronger than the survival one, but just one bit. This, however was no problem for me, since I enjoy a good story. And this game kept me on the edge of my seat while I was figuring out what happened in the planet I crashed into.Talking about the planet, the atmosphere of the game is amazing, climate is always changing and even when most of this changes are dangerous for you, are still a sight to behold. This is one of the things this game doesn’t lack, great visuals enhanced even more by a great use of soundtrack and sfx’s.Now, there is a horror-survival side of this game, however I wouldn’t call it much “horror” as it is creepy, which at least in my opinion, it’s 10 times better. Because the times you can get scared in this game does not rely on cheap jump-scares. But in its ability to keep you “uncomfortable” in an environment that you are not familiar with, and why would you? It is an alien planet after all! This element of the game intensifies as you get deeper into the dark caves and unveil secrets which I won’t spoil any further!--There is however, an issue that it’s worth mention for AMD Fx users such as me. Apparently there is a “hiccup” with this processor and the audio used for this engine (Unreal 4) which causes the game to freeze at some points when the game is loading. Which is obviously a minor inconvenience. That being said, I can testify the devs have been working hard to find out the source of this problem and facilitated a patch for us AMD fx users, which can easily be found in the discussion forums.-- Anyway, even with all that, I still recommend this game because you can tell how much work was put into it. One of my best gaming experiences in the latest years.And an even stronger recommendation if you are Sci-fi fan like me.Pros:- Engaging story- Great use of visuals, sound and music- Lots of secrets to discover- Big areas to wander around and exploreCons:- Audio glitches (for AMD Fx)- Survival can get a little too easy some of the times (For hardcore survival players)

Posted: March 23, 2016
 You're Earth's single hope! If the Solus Project would be like any other project you do for a class, then this would easily get an A+.Side Note | Important for some  The lack of registered hours on this game is because I had no choice but to play it offline. Lore  Humanity no longer has a home. Earth has been destroyed, and all that remains of it is on a nomadic fleet of ships searching for a place to rebuild their civilization. In The Solus Project, you take on the role of a surveying team charting an Earthlike planet that may just prove suitable for humanity’s resettlement. Disaster strikes suddenly and you find yourself marooned on the surface of Gliese. Armed with only the most basic knowledge of the dangers the planet holds, you must set out to solve the mystery of the destruction of your ship, and contact your fleet for rescue.You were sent to save the mankind.Who will save  you  now?GameplaySolus Project is a single player, first person survival game. Solus Project takes place in an alien alike prehistoric, colourful sci-fi setting. As stated about the sci-fi setting and all, The Solus Project could easily be mistaken for another sci-fi themed survival game. As soon as you start, you're greeted by your PDA which gives you basic information to get you going in the unknown, as well as some tips about survival.It might have the same mechanics as all survival games such as finding food and water, be careful with your character's temperature and get enough sleep. One of the differences here, and quite a big one, is the need to create buildings. The shelter itself is not permanent. You're a nomad. Why? Because the objective of this game, is to explore, explore and explore! But not generated lands! It's one, big planet full of rich alien foliage, mountains of impressive sizes giving quite a challenge for the player to reach their top. Upon doing so, the view is fantastic especially with the weather the developers have implemented that gives the game even more charm, I simply love the meteor showers with an undescribable feeling. Though the player must be careful as the temperature as well changes and gives more discomfort, giving more difficulty.The lack of mini-map gives as well an interesting feeling, since like in the old days, you're let with the single option, that one option being to draw your own maps with the explored areas.For the achievers, there is a multitude of secrets and hidden areas ready to be plundered, with quite a reward. More lore. Yet.. it's pretty short without exploring and fiddling around with every bit, you can complete it fast, in an hour or so. Don't fret! Part two is here so the hours have been extended. Have fun exploring, for the mankind! Graphics As stated above, the whole relief of this planet is not only the reward itself for exploring, but something mandatory as soon as you're in-game. It's quite stunning to see such a beautiful unknown, which makes you want more and more. The Unreal Engine 4 really pays off on this one, especially maxed all out, to let your eyes feast on every little detail. The color palette used for this game surprises me as well, a mix of orange and gray, with lots of blue, metal there and there which are the ambient's mains and it's delicious. Those are the mains, while the secondaries are the ones used for the foliage, items and so on. OST & SFX This game’s sound design is just superb. The soundtrack is incredibly atmospheric and memorable. The sound effects are incredibly satisfying. The music just adds so much energy and life to the world, as any good soundtrack should. It’s a great listen to while exploring caves and strange structures. Such a great one that I just stared at the scenery and let the time flow with the tune playing. Should you buy it? Overall, Solus Project is out of this world(pun intended)! In my honest opinion, it is a nice experience and take on the survival genre, which is focused more on exploration. If you'd like to experience something new with the same mechanisms, this is your cup of tea, worth the whole sip. Full price recommended.If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group:  Original Curator Group

content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
Product received for free
See written review below or watch it here: 


YouTube™ Video: The Solus Project - Quick Game Review 

			Views: 1,072		

			The Solus Project is a first person sci-fi survival exploration adventure, developed by Teotl Studios, that’s a spiritual successor to The Ball. The game is available on both PC and for VR.		

TL;DR: SKIP TO CONCLUSION! THIS IS A MIXED REVIEW!The Solus Project is a first person sci-fi survival exploration adventure, that’s a spiritual successor to The Ball. Now that the Earth has been destroyed, you are sent to an unexplored planet to investigate the surface, and see if it’s fit for humans. You are the last member of your crew, and the last hope for humanity’s survival. You must find a way to repair the communication tower and report back to what's left of humanity.Pros:intriguing story that gets even more interesting as you continue to explore the planet, and learn the truth (and even though there isn't any replay value as far as the main story goes, there are so many secrets to discover for those who love exploring)excellent graphics; everything from the planet’s surface and caves to the sky, storms, stars and nearby planets look absolutely fantasticthe voice acting is done very well, and it helps to convey the importance of the mission at handthe music, sound effects, and ambience work extremely well to create an atmospheric environmentvery immersive world throughout (I was sometimes be so focused in what's ahead, that I would walk into traps, and scare myself)exploration is satisfying - there are tons of secrets to find, and every one of them rewards you with a small permanent stat or resistance buff - it’s also nice that the game tells you how many secrets are left in an area when you’re about to leave itthere’s a lot of lore to be discovered as well, and those who learn more will have a better understanding of the story, and likely get the most enjoyment out of itthe survival aspects are manageable for the most part, and you are able to find enough food and water without much trouble; maintaining your body temperature to avoid hypothermia and heat stroke was a bit more challenging, and it often gives you a sense of urgency while exploring, but doesn't usually feel overwhelmingthe teleport movement, and room-scaling is implemented well for the HTC ViveCons:when it was dark, being in extremely hot and cold areas was annoying at times because the hot and cold orbs don't give off much light, and you'll have to change between items to see where you're going (you can hotkey some of the items you use regularly, but the heat orb is not one of them - some of the items with hotkeys available feel unnecessary, and I would have rather had the option of which items to assign keys to)inventory management gets tedious since space is fairly limited, and it’s not always clear what items you should keep (it might have been less annoying if you could keep walking while accessing the inventory)some people will be too sensitive to motion sickness to really enjoy the VR experience because there are many times where the camera shakes from earthquake or meteors (I used PC instead)I encountered an issue that caused me to be unable to finish the game* without completely starting over (partially my fault, but the game should have stopped me - a completely separate auto save point right before you pass the point of no return would have saved me)*I ran into an issue where I unknowingly skipped getting an orb that makes you cold, and continued playing the game not realizing. I then got into the final chapters of the game, and hit the point of no return. I was warned to be prepared, so I was stocked up on food and water, and figured I was good to go. However, I did not have this one specific item that keeps you from dying to heat stroke in intense heat; this item seemed to be required to finish the chapter, and I have no idea why the game allowed me to skip getting it in the first place. I admit that I am partially at fault for not having fully explored. After hitting this point of no return, I couldn’t find any way to go back, and I couldn’t finish the game without restarting completely.Conclusion:I played The Solus Project for 11 hours, but over an hour and a half of that was me being stuck trying to get through a part that was actually impossible for me. I was close to the end, and I never intended to go back and try to find more secrets, so despite my issue with not being able to finish the last part of the game, I still really enjoyed the game overall. I’m just glad that I was able to watch the ending, otherwise I would have been really mad. I'm sure there aren't many people who have come across a problem like this, but I still hope they fix this issue though, so that this can’t happen to others. It’s still a really good survival exploration game, with a lot of secrets to uncover, and I enjoyed playing almost all of it.If you like my reviews, please feel free to join my Steam group, and follow my curations here.You can also view this review on my website here.[www.azralynn.com]

Posted: June 17, 2016
Product received for free
TLDR at the bottom - The Solus Project is an adventure exploration game that borrows some aspects from survival games. That said, while it is not by any means a survival game like the ones that’ve flooded Steam over the past few years, I think this is one of the few that delivers a true survival experience, even if it lacks in many aspects.Earth is doomed, and in an effort to save Humankind, the UN creates the Solus Project, a series of ships destined to search for a habitable planet for the top tier scientists to colonize. You are sent to Gliese, one of the most promissing planets, before the rest of the fleet in order to scout the surface and determine if it can sustain life. Unfortunately, after years of space travel you crash land upon arrival and soon find yourself stranded, all by yourself and in a constant fight for survival in an unknown and alien world. Welcome to the Solus Project.Right from the start the game introduces you to the light survival elements that it has, which consist mostly on barebones crafting and collecting items. You’ll have to keep an eye on your PDA for your calories and thirst meter as well as body temperature, wind velocity, condensation, ambient temperature, health and sleep deprivation meter. In order to keep these things in check, which for the most part of the game is an easy task, you have to eat, drink, sleep, avoid getting too cold or too hot in order to avoid hypothermia and heat strokes, which is most efficiently done by seeking shelter and sleeping there for a while. However, these are not your only threats, there are multiple natural phenomena that will come at random times and can kill you in an instant. These are particularly pretty well done and the first time I saw them I was blow away by the scale of these events. Despite the fact that this is at its core a very linear exploration based adventure game, there is plenty of optional and side stuff to do. Most of the narrative and background story is actually delivered via texts that you find and read through your PDA, but there is the ocasional voice dialogue where you record a message or you catch a glimpse of a transmission from the fleet that is out there waiting for you to report. For me these were some of the best parts, initially you can see that the operator that is transmiting is worried about you, but by the time you’re in the later stages of the game you can feel the terror in her voice, the idea that the Humanity could potentially become extinct if you don’t make it, you are the last hope of Humankind.This is what sells this game for me, being trapped in a beautiful alien and unknown world, struggling to survive, trying to keep on searching for a way out, witnessing marvels of nature of enormous magnitude, while very slowly starting to unravel some pretty grim and dark secrets beneath the planet surface. While the visuals do a pretty decent job, the sound design is way much better in fully immersing you into this world and the sountrack is pretty good as well. Some areas have this very dark and spooky atmosphere and there were a lot of times I was very tense on my chair, looking for small signs of light in the middle of dark caves.Final verdictDo I think that this is a perfect game? Absolutely not! But I strongly believe that this is a must play for anyone who likes dark and tense adventure games with an emphasis on exploration, or games with a great atmosphere filled with mystery, intrigue and a whole lot of sci-fi and doomsday scenarios. That said, I was kind of sad about how the game ended, it felt very anticlimatic, and explaining how and why that was would be spoiling you what was to me the joy of playing this wonderful little gem.Also, I mentioned that most of the background story and lore is delivered via texts that you find, this is entirely optional and I’m pretty sure I didn’t find a lot of them. Could I go back and explore everything in order to unlock every possible piece of text and secret? Absolutely, but I think in doing so it would ruin my experience, I rather leave things as they are, a result of a one time experience that I will always remember and I hope that so will you.This review is part of the Steamified Community Review program. For giveaways and similar reviews please visit http://www.steamified.com/

content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
												This is a really impressive story game that presents you elements of survival, exploration and treasure-hunting.I really liked it, especially buying it at half price, I thought it was excellent value for money - at the sale price only. My reason for this is because it is a one-play linear game. As soon as I had completed it, my enjoyment there ended. Reading the text within the game, (the notes left by people there, or signs carved into walls etc), played a part in my enjoyment-for-money, so I recommend reading what you can, but it is not essential. I even made my own alphabet and was able to decypher the alien language, it really is accurate! (I even found a translation mistake on one of the slabs of text, but I was able to translate what it said myself, so that was rather fun in itself lol!)Even though the fun is over now for me, I will say that the game most likely requires a re-play because there are some very well-hidden secrets to be found! I would replay it for the completion factor I think.These secret treasures combine to 'upgrade' your survivability stats and are banked as soon as you obtain them. I would only replay the game to find all secrets for the completion factor, not for the upgrades, since I enjoyed the difficulty and challenge of the survival element. Oh and if you are a hard-case, you can make it hard, so don't worry about collecting the secret treasures.It pays to keep paying attention to your vital stats, featured on your hand-held device. You need to do whatever you need to to survive and that involves preventing numerous ways that you can die from happening. So make sure you box - clever. With this in mind, I will give you some helpful advice about what you are likely to encounter in the game;1) At the start of each area/level, you will encounter small 'worship shrines', 6 ft high pointed stones, standing in the ground (that are actually spelled 'woship' lol, but hey never mind). What these are telling you is how many artifacts, secret treasures, are to be found in that area/level, which is neat because that will be useful for the second play-through.2) Secondly, you will come across 'Cargo Manifest' crates, that list certain items of use, but the cargo box appears to be empty. What are they? Well, these are telling you what special items are to be found in that given area/level - much like the shrines that tell you about the hidden artifacts! (I had to google to find this out, since I found it confusing and didn't get it). This did not ruin the game, since I enjoy having to find things out for myself and not have my game played for me or my hand held. However, it may as well be given as advice to save time for those who just want to get on with the game.As you adventure along in this Alien world you come across different items that you can decide for yourself if you want them or not and yes.. there is no 'right or wrong'. You only need food, water and sleep to survive, so your inventory is yours for the making. I liked that.However, I'm not sure why some objects were there in the game, what role they actually played because for me, I didn't find much use for them. Nevertheless, this did not spoil the game at all for me, I enjoyed unravelling the mystery cave by cave, engraving by engraving and with every turning of a key, which unlocked more of the game as I played.I do recommend this game, as long as you don't mind not having any guns. Still.. you can always make a Hammer..

												In the end I am satisfied to have played it through but am also glad it is now over.  Not sure how to define but it took actual effort to keep playing. Walking puzzle game with survival elements.  Navigate a guided path to piece together a story while collecting an array of fantastic tools.  Some of it is spooky.  Violent themes.Mostly twisting subterrainian exploration dependant on maintaining light sources and navigation without a gamemap but with navigation beacons.  Must also manage food and water supplies but there is a lot of it around so mostly just remember to pick it up when you see it then eat/drink if you get hungry/thirsty.  And there's avoiding the cold with fires and such.  And sleeping periodically in places where it's not cold.  You'll figure it out after it kills you a few times.

												The Solus Project is a game that is not perfect, but works well with what it is. Focused on basic survival around drinking water, managing heat/cold, and fighting hunger wrapped up in a linear narrative, this game is focused on a combination of seeking secrets while managing one's own failing condition. The game's narrative itself is the focus of the game, don't expect crafting to hold your interest. It's pretty basic at best and mostly used to limit your access to certain items. There's a reason why a lot of fear in the game comes from losing your torch. Though I'll say that it will be nothing compared to that one small section. I will say the ending is kind of weak, felt kind of like they weren't sure how to advance the story more. Otherwise, enjoyed almost every moment of this game.

Early Access Review
								Verdict: A Galactic success story.Before I describe to you, as to why the Solus Project is a phenomenal game, I must admit that I was at first dubious as to how immersive the gameplay would feel and how much replayibility it would have. Having played for almost 3 hours, I realise my concerns were unfounded and here is why:SimulationYou start the game marooned on an alien world but it has traces that an Egyptian type civilisation once inhabited this world. Hieroglyphics depicting gods being praised by their worshippers adorn the walls of the the subterranean underworld. Water drips down the stalagmites, its drops signifying health reguvenation is close at hand. Alien plant species strike from the shadows, breaking your visor and splattering it with blood. You will need a medkit or sleep to heal your wounds from this beautiful yet deadly ecosystem.VisualsThe game is near photorealistic in its depiction of life on this hostile planet. The sea glistens and undulates to the rhythem of the tide, a day and night cycle creates unimanginably gorgeous panoramic scenes, cave interiors beckon to be explored with their incredible colour palettes and glistening stones. Asteroid strikes light up the sky with trails of fire and smoke, striking nearby scarring the landscape with their tremendous force. Of all the games in my librabry, this is by far the most visually stunning game I own (80+ games with a GTX 980)Some screenshots:


The Solus Project 
A Screenshot of The Solus Project
By: echo1







The Solus Project 
A Screenshot of The Solus Project
By: echo1







The Solus Project 
A Screenshot of The Solus Project
By: echo1




AdventureWhilst this is no sandbox, the parametres to explore are wide and there is a deep sense of accomplishment when you discover a humanoid clutching a sword which can be used for a multitude of purposes. Kindling can be lit to ensure you keep warm after suffering from hypothermia, or shade can be used to reduce the impact of heat stroke. An advanced monitoring device held in your characters left hand indicates all your vital signs and even reminds you that you need to sleep!PerformanceThis game does not perform like an EA game. There is no stuttering, no erratic fps drops, no sudden crash. It runs silky smooth even during natural events such as  earthquakes, tornadoes etc. On my GTX 980 laptop I'm getting 50fps at 3k resolution.ValueFor just under £10 this game is an absolute steal! The production values are extremely high for such a modestly priced game. Bear in mind, during EA content is being released episodically until May (the release date).ConclusionIf you love the following themes buy this game: Atmospheric, survival, Simulation, Aliens, Galactic, Crafting, Exploration, Beautiful and ClassicEdit: Just completed the first part in 3.5 hours. It would have taken me 5-6 hours had I explored more rather than stick to the objective. Great value for money!

Product received for free
												The best experience I have had in VR so far, this game has taken me to places no other VR game has so far. Some may find it slow but I enjoy that in a single player game. It's mainly about survival and gives you missions to complete to help you survive. There are little bits of story all around you to discover and if you take your time it builds up a great back story.This game has sold me completely on VR and what In depth games can be when some longer and more story driven games are released for VR. Some of the stunning VR moments for me have been.Watching meteorites crash all around me Shining a light into the water and seeing depth to it like never beforeExploring deep within caves and looking up to see the the high cavern ceilings with my torch light flickering of itGoing under the ocean and feeling like I'm under the ocean.Watching the massive moons move across the sky.Standing in a torrential down pour and almost feeling it hitting me.I know pretty mundane stuff but it all adds up to making the game more realistic than anything else I have played up to now. Just the fact that when I'm playing I really feel like I'm on a distant planet.Anyway if you have VR and enjoy story driven survival games on distant planets then def give this a go. Also if you have a large fan make sure you have it going on you when you're playing as it really adds to the immersion.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
Good Exploration Game with a StoryThe Solus Project is a good exploration game with a touch of survival threaded together by an interesting story. I played entirely in 2D (no VR) and it never felt like a tech demo. I played almost a full 40 hours before reaching the end. I could have gone longer if I explored more, but I felt like it was a good time to end.Do's and Don'tsDo expect to deal with varying degrees of threatening environmentsDon't expect any combat; you can't even swat a flyDo expect to search for food and water and safe places to sleepDon't expect a lot of crafting; the recipes are mostly just combining two itemsDo play with the game audio on. The audio is cool and audio cues are extremely helpful.Things that could be ImprovedYou can only hold one thing at a time which is annoying when you need one item for your environment (e.g. a light or temperature control item) and another to do an action Some of the areas with extremely high and extremely low temperatures are more of a pain than a survival mechanic. Towards the end, even with the best possible items, there were times I had to drop a bunch of items to create a "temperature offset zone" just so I could bring my body temperate up/down.You can only hold items in your right hand. Generally this doesn't matter, but when going for high precision shots with the Teleporter, you can get "locked out" of a shot that would be possible with your left hand.To get the max distance on the Teleporter, you have to jump. Since you can only hold the Teleporter and nothing else, this just delays how long it takes to get a good shot. Plus, it just feels stupid.Sprinting is interrupted by jumping or short steps down. So long as you hold down the sprint button, you should be sprinting regardless of your other actions or terrain.There's a bit too much crouching required. It's painfully slow and despite the reality that dank caves would require a lot of crouching, it just slows down the exploration.The stuttering of walking up stairs is far slower than walking up the railing beside it. I understand that's more realistic, but I shouldn't hate stairs and constantly seek out a railing to move around the game world.There were very few glitches and they were minor or brief. A short period of no rain sounds while standing in rain or a little terrain flicker in a corner. It's a solid game that has a lot to offer, especially for the price. I think it's worth full price, but if you find it on sale, it's a must buy.

Posted: June 10, 2016
												I love this game on the Vive. It's probably my favourite experience on the device so far, after having bought about 50 games. And that from a game with VR support added after the game was mostly done. That of course has its limitations. The inventory is cumbersome (but l understand the devs are working on it), and the controls aren't always logical. You have to push a button to interact with things (that is probably hard to fix as the game is designed around a controller). But you can use your hands independently, light your way with the torch etc. and move about freely. The default locomotion will be tough for some, but with a little tinkering you can adjust the walk speed, and even make the in game clock slower so you have more time to explore the incredible looking locations.  You even get a teleportation gun you can use for moving around if your VR legs isn't good (I haven't used it much though as I find the default locomotion very nice, but I've had some time to train my VR legs). It can be quite scary in VR, with an eary atmosphere, and I have more than once had chills go down my spine.And the story so far is really good, keeps me pushing on. This game is fantastic! The VR implementation is an example for other devs to follow, and its improving with every update. Thank you devs for giving me this amazing experience in VR!

												This is a VR Review.I bought this game due to it's roomscale VR and motion control support, and long gameplay time.This game has a lot to it, however, I didn't realize this was a survival horror game. Or at least from how far I am in it, I think it is. I believe this is supposed to be a survival game, but even the smallest creatures in VR as so surprisingly scary. Everything in it is so scary because it's VR.The controls for roomscale are still being hashed out, but in general they aren't bad. I'd say I have more of an advantage compared to those in seated experiences due to the teleportation mechanic. However, this is not a reason to stray away from this game.If you're considering buying this game for VR, I'd say this is a full game, which is something not seen often for the early stages of VR. I recommend this game for that reason. The controls being a work in progress show that they wanted this in players hands as soon as possible.I don't think I'll find the courage to finish this game. However, I do applaud the content and presentation.

content:
Posted: March 28
												As a sci-fi adventure it's pretty good, if you like to put down your blaster and do a spot of exploring and follow the slightly predictable story.  Great enviromentl effects, looks nice, plays decent, and certainly worth the entry price, though if your the trigger happy need action all the time player, this game is not for you, but if you have a good sense of imagination and are happy to open yourself up to story and atmosphere above pew pew, you'll enjoy it.But try in in VR and holy f*%k, it is staggering, it literally dumps you on this alien world and the feeling of presence is amazing.  Your brain reacts to this in a totally different way than playing on a monitor, it ceases to be a game and becomes an experience, a personal adventure and the first game to illicit genuine feelings of fear and dread about my own survival, it's a remarkable acheivement for an Indie developer, it feels like a AAA title, yes it still has a few bugs, and needs a fair bit of polish and optimising, but please, continue to push the VR support devs, you are SO close to making this a poster game for VR's future.  If you have a VR headset, stop reading this and go buy it, it's un-missable, if you don't have a VR headset, this game is absolutly worth getting one for, it's nice wthout it, but I can't express the effect VR has on this game over playing on a monitor, it's a genuine taste of the future.  Support this developer in either case, for the little cash they are charging, from a VR point of view, this game is definate value for money if you like creepy, isolated, using your brain for once, trapped on an alien world that wouldn't look out of place on "Star Trek" but at the same time, giving you a sort of stranded colonist in an "Alien Covenant" creepy what the hell happened on this planet sort of way chills, you'll lap up this experience.Not for those with a short attention span / don't like puzzling out things, or need to be blasting aliens to be happy.For those who enjoy mystery games, can inject a little of their own imagination by thinking what they would do in this situation (especially in VR), recommended.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												Review written as of 11/2-16.Played the "normal", non-VR version of the game. It took me 13h to finish.I will divide the review into multiple sections, I had to rewrite everything because I hit the review character limit before. The lists below are just points worth noting in my eyes and they describe both good and the bad parts of the game.Let's start.The Solus Project follows a space ship colony sent by humanity after destruction on Earth in hopes of finding a new home planet for our species. After reaching the probable new home the colony ship gets shot down from the surface of the planet and you crash land on it. After getting into grips with your situation you discover ancient buildings and architecture while trying to establish contact with the remainder of humanity who are still waiting for the update from the mission. However, things are not as simple as they seem and soon you learn of the past interactions between other species who have previously visited and inhabited this planet, for better or the worse.Uncovering all of the truth is not easy, you will be put through many tests with cult and religious like background, all mixed together with an unsettling and often sad atmosphere surrounding it.- Graphics -Looks good from afar, worse up close due to lower res textures.No AA options but you can super sample (Resolution scale option is available if you wish).Says you can edit advanced graphical options in .cfg files instead of having them in the menu itself.Good art direction, makes it a coherent whole.Decent looking effects, they are quite varied (weather etc).Weather is not global, it's localized around the player (hide under a roof and rain disappears from the whole world).Has baffling performance issues in certain areas, runs super smooth otherwise. - Sound -Very atmospheric, good quality.Own footstep sounds can be misleading, has weird coordination issues (at least in my case).Spot on ambient, music and effect sounds.Good voice acting, nothing bad or outstanding, it's all around solid and nice to listen to.Can specify between male or female character sounds and dialogue voice. - Gameplay -Heavy on story telling and atmosphere, explores the ancient aliens and exploration themes.No weapons, running from the dangers in required in order to beat the game.No map, you can leave beacons behind to mark important places.The planet itself is your enemy, you need to protect yourself from the elements.First person exploration with optional survival elements.Features a somewhat realistically driven weather system, caves flood with water depending on the sea level due to the moon phase etc..Includes a lot of easy puzzles of basically every kind like environmental ones, basic logic ones and so on.Badly designed interaction and inventory systems. Wastes your time, fit for consoles but not for a PC keyboard and mouse usage. Interactions have a pointless timer on them (think No Man's Sky inventory where you have to hold a button to do anything minor) and it carries over to your teleportation device. - Level Design -5 different islands, all interconnected together with a complex cavern system.Islands and caverns are all behind loading screens, it's not one world in that sense.Gorgeous buildings, architecture and story telling by the environment.The sense of scale is astounding when it comes to buildings and locationsThere is a lot of variety between different areas and they are easily identifiable (except the caverns especially if you are out of light sources :3)Has a megaton of secrets and hidden areas everywhere. I've stumbled upon secrets inside of secrets... it's craaaazy. Overall if you are into exploration games that are linear with good and engaging story I would recommend this game. To make things even more interesting try out the predecessor to this game, it's called “The Ball”.Once you have played “The Ball” some of the things will make more sense and/or be more interesting in “The Solus Project”.Good job devs, hope I can see some DLC/sequel(s) in the future with improved mechanics.Recommended!

number of helpful: 20 of 25 people (80%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
												Non-VR reviewThe Solus Project is one of those indie creations to get excited about. It’s a very good game, but is it a perfect game? Of course not! It’s got a few weird things going on: a couple graphical issues and seemingly endless references to other intellectual properties (borrows much from TV show Lost in particular). Readers, I know what you’re thinking: So what, another indie studio created another indie game blah blah blah why should I care? Readers, I already told you the answer to that: it’s a very good game! Weren’t you listening!? Think: a crispy Lost pie crust with the disappointing conclusion trimmed off (Season 6, I’m looking at you) and fill that with Interstellar custard cream, but now scrape the oily Matt Damon meringue off the top and then sprinkle with a couple teaspoons of crushed Ancient Aliens. Ahhhh, pure heaven I tell ya!Okay, so there’s no black hole or time travel in TSP, but it captures that “Interstellar” vibe nonetheless. More than once, I found myself overlooking an alien tropical beach paradise at the precipice of a craggy drop off and wanting pump both fists into the air and yell, “I’M THE MATTHEW MCCONAU♥♥♥♥ OF THE WORLD!!!” I didn’t though. My wife isn’t into videogames. Such spontaneous outbursts would be frowned upon and followed up by punishment nagging to do irrelevant tasks. Yeah, fetching that glass of water for you and then that bowl of kale chips for you and then turning off that hallway light so you could watch Gilmore Girls without the glare sure showed me for enjoying something without you. Lesson learned.Ahem, moving on readers, this is simulated walking at its finest. That statement is coming from me: a gamer who loathes Dear Esther et al. I feel like TSP goes the extra mile to stand apart in its genre, so much so that “Exploration Simulator” would be a more accurate description of TSP’s gameplay.Exploration of the unknown carries the risk of fatal failure. If history is a guide, then it has shown us that the cost of expeditions to parts unknown is paid not only in coin, but often in blood as well. Elon Musk knows this when he asks “are you prepared to die” on a journey to Mars? In a game that tries to put explorers on Gliese-6143-C, a fictional planet orbiting another star, you can bank on people dying in it. Spoiler alert: they do!Exploration of the treacherous unknown is all well and good. Eventually though, the unknown becomes the known, the traps and pitfalls mapped and accounted for, yada yada yada fartnoise. That’s a problem when the main hook is exploring; before long, the soul-sucking boredom of the type found in standard walking simulators can seep in. Worry not readers, for the agile TSP parries the creeping tectonic blow of boredom with a quick megathrust of excellent pacing. You are encouraged onward via objectives at a rate slow enough to let you take in the sights of the superbly crafted islands and caves, while fast enough to keep the flow moving forward. If you linger, it’s at your choosing and likely because you are trying to find the secret areas, you elite completionist, you.In that sense, despite the open world that allows backtracking and travel between areas at will, TSP is a linear game with a defined beginning, middle and end. This structure keeps things fresh hour after hour, much like those packets of silica beads found in packaged products (you know, the ones that say “DO NOT EAT”? I really should start listening to those warnings). However, I did experience some game fatigue, but that was after 35 friggin’ hours in a 16 hour game, so yeah my fault mostly. Fortunately, getting back into the plot progression quickly reengaged my interest.The plot is solid in TSP. It is a chunky mishmash of other sources but it injects originality into the mix. In the 22nd century, a rogue star has destroyed Earth and torn asunder most of the solar system; a cataclysm that has stranded the survivors with dwindling supplies on ark ships near Pluto. Before they can burn fuel reserves needed to leave the shattered remnants of the Sol System behind, they must desperately await the “all clear to colonize” signal from any of the scout vessels sent to promising exoplanets. Wow, that’s just the backstory.I’m on a scout ship lightyears away, which suddenly turns into a roman space candle while entering orbit around an exoplanet. All of my crewmates appear to die in the explosion. That’s okay though, I could use a little alone time after spending 8 years pent up with them inside that relativistic sardine can. So there I am, crash landed and alone, and loving it!All kidding aside, the atmosphere from then on is tragically hopeful as I realize I can still succeed in my scout mission if I collect enough scrapped spaceship parts to build a transmitter. I cling to that shard of positive thinking, which the plotline sinisterly whittles away at as if it were carving a marshmallow roasting stick. I soon felt that at some point I would be plunged into the fire. The survival of mankind hinged on my ability to overcome creeping hopelessness. This is a story that I thoroughly enjoyed, and I found the emotionally charged conclusion to it very satisfying.This is a story supported by strong visual and audio production. The graphics are excellent, with a couple of issues. There is a weird distortion effect sometimes seen on the edges of objects that are framed in the near background by water. Also, on my midrange system with the settings on Ultra, 1080p ran at 60fps+ but dropped inexplicably every couple of hours to 40ish until I entered a loading screen or restarted the game. Not a game breaker for me; it simply meant that I had to play a small percentage of the game below the ideal framerate. Besides, the audio steals the show here, readers.The sounds of Gliese-6143-C pull you into the fantasy. From the thematic background music to the immersive ambience, you can hear the love that Teotl put into this important aspect to gaming that is too often overlooked by other dev teams. My biggest complaint here is the voice acting. If your preferred language is English DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME AS THE MALE CHARACTER! The guy who voiced the male derped hard and cannot sell the story. Luckily, the woman who voiced the female protagonist did an incredible job capturing the emotion behind the script. I smiled her smiles, shivered her shivers, and cried her tears (they were crocodile tears, no wetness; manhood=restored). Play with the female voice enabled or don’t play it at all. Yeah it’s that important to the journey through TSP.To aid that journey, you scavenge supplies from ship wreckage and derelict alien settlements and craft various inventory and quest items. Scavenging is crucial, but this game mechanic is well implemented and avoids the tedious resource grind found in other open world survival games. For example, you don’t need to stock up excessively on food; you could live almost entirely off of the infinite alien food and water stations found around the levels. The devs took the infinite supplies idea a little too far, though. Alien technology explains infinite food stations, but the oily bark torches you craft that never burn out was a weird design decision. After you craft the first torch, there’s no need to make another one. Small gripe I know.That’s how well TSP is made; I’m nitpicking to find things I didn’t like. More nitpicking: the exploitable loophole where you can put a burning torch in the inventory “backpack” and submerge yourself in water, then get out and pull the still burning torch out of the backpack… then use it to help dry yourself off. Come on Teotl, that’s dumb. The torch system should be reworked for more realism. Again, nitpicking.TSP is a well-crafted adventure. A must play for sci-fi fans.TL;DR this game is a steal at $20. I got it for 10 and I’ve been indicted for internet piracy.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
												HTC Vive VR Review A menu that wouldn't let me select anything at first (needed to alt tab on my PC), an hour of  figuring out the controls, settings and movements, clunky Vive controls ...None of these things detracted from this being my favourite VR experience yet!This game works best once you've got used to artifical locomotion (I used to get really really sick, now not at all). It has a teleport system in it, but it's not quite as smooth as the Lab, and I personally find teleport breaks the immersion.Last night, I crash landed on an alien planet, where there was lushous grass and rock pillars and I was really there, warming my frozen hands on the engine of my broken rocket, watching shooting stars fly past the moons in the sky. Searching around for food, I sat down to eat, and watched as light slowly creeped into the alien world as a new day broke. I survived my first day!This all felt very very real.This is clearly a beta VR experience, but the world fits VR so well that it's clunkiness can almost be ignored. How this is so far down the VR recommend list is a mystery to me... But I can advise anyone wanting to play this to go and try some demos with artifical motion first, and see if you can get used to it. Took me at least a few weeks, maybe even a month. If you can though, it is well worth it for this experience alone! Worth the full price I paid for the game. Would pay €40 no probs for a game like this if the VR was just a little bit better implemented.EDIT: completed.Don't want to change my review as too many people have already read and liked it. Just a quick edit... 16 hours to complete, wow what an experience! The ending was pretty bad, expecially in VR, but the journey there was amazing! Such an adventure, and was exactly what I dreamed of playing in VR when I was a teenager. Give it a go!

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												Back in the 1990's and early 2000's I was lucky enough to call the folks at Cyan (who made MYST and Riven) people I had met and discussed their games with directly, including sitting with Tim Larkin in his studio while he shared with me some of his techniques for making the music to URU. I wrote a 5 page review of MYST III:Exile that was published during E3 in that year with the help of Presto Studios (man, that was a long time ago, I'm an older gamer), so I love adventure games. I love FPS games too, don't get me wrong, but adventure games are really hard to do correctly. That is why, when one comes along that does it right, it can become far more engaging than even the best FPS for me. Solus is one of those games. Solus has an extremely engaging and simple inventory system that work to help both solve puzzles and keep you alive. The survivalist aspect of Solus is so well implemented, that simply trying to gauge the weather and atmospheric conditions consumed a full three days of my time at one point (which was entirely my choice since I figured it was probably important to understand if the weather was going to be my friend or not). There's more, of course, to Solus that simply that, but the point is that there are a lot of layers to Solus that reveal themselves only if you really push yourself. And if you get killed, you have only yourself to blame.The game has really good velocity, and never stagnates into a hunt-and-click. In fact, that somewhat annoying aspect of adventure games is completely missing in this game, much to my delight. Solus is really beautiful. OK, the skyscapes are in fact stunning. Watching the celestial mechanics can be entrancing in this game. I really feel like I'm on another world here. I almost want to go buy a VR headset just to see what that must be like. I'm sure it's really amazing. The rock textures and plant textures could be better, and the water effects also seem a bit thin even when all my settings pegged at ultra. But the balance they have struck between beauty and performance is so well acheived that this really is just a nit that I mention because I'm sure someone will pick it. :) The Solus Project implements survivalist adventure gaming in the most engaging and immersive way imaginable, with a storyline that I like because it's not overly complicated, is plausible, and it ends in a way that to me seemed very likely given what we are learning about the universe around us today. The game runs completely bug free for me, but I understanding the first release was not really that stable. I haven't experienced any problems at all. I love this game.

Posted: July 26, 2016
												I did not finish the game, yet. But I am on my way to do so. I am not a VR user, and my opinion is for non-VR potential purchaser.If you read this, you probably wonder if you should buy this game. TLDR : exploration + immersion + background story + PvE + next-gen graphics + very few bugs = this gamePros:If you like survival-oriented game, with some puzzles but mostly exploration, fantastic landscapes mounted by orbiting planets in the sky, powerful meteorologic events and being the last hope of humanity... You will dig into this game.If you want a 'pew pew' game with moar guns and ghillie suit... Forget it :D You are in the wrong place.This game is a combination of Myst + Alien Story + last-gen graphics + No bugs so far... It's an adventure you want to know, an adventure you want to live.Cons:Initially the games asks you to make a decision (what outfit you get) but this is the only decision you will ever make (or maybe not, but +50% done and this was the only one...).It has no RPG feature at all. No skill tree, no experience... Only secrets (stats booster) you find by exploring. I was hoping for more choices ala 'make a decision on what happened and live with it' but it never happened again. The fact there is no RPG element is not a downside, but letting you think there might be is a little bit when you look backward (or you just forget it and move towards that light source). In the end the path you take is the path everyone takes. I think once the game is finished you might not want to replay it. This is not FTL.Conclusion: 200% worth the price. My hat for the devs. Such a small dev team, but such a competent dev team. 6 of them can do what a team of 30 can never achieve. Good work!
