content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												A VIVE USER PERSPECTIVE – A VR EXPERIENCE LIKE NO OTHERThe Solus Project is a prime example of what implementing VR to an existing, originally non-VR game can accomplish. The result is a supremely immersive, story-driven, athmospheric, and gorgeously beautiful exploration and survival sci-fi adventure, on a vast, mysterious alien planet. The game exemplarily captures the feeling and pace of arriving to and exploring a great unknown.I think VR (Vive room-scale) really makes the game. A couple of weeks back, before VR support, I watched a bit of a playthrough video on YouTube, and thought the game looked slow and boring. But once I heard the developers were adding Vive support, I had to try it, and haven't looked back since. I must say the Vive room-scale implementation really makes the game for me. It truly places you in the middle of a mysterious planet, exploring around, experiencing the story that is really well and immersively paced. It's quite amazing; a testament to what VR can do to a game, and surely a benchmark for the future. For me, what initially looked like a boring survival game on a 2D monitor is now an amazingly immersive sci-fi adventure that I would wholeheartedly recommend to anyone who has the Vive and the least bit of interest in a good story. With The Solus Project, you'll get to experience one like never before.To add, the developers are still making adjustments and fixing bugs, making their VR support even better with future updates. Frankly, with the current price of 18,99€, getting this game should be a no-brainer, especially for a Vive owner. A++(This review was based on version 1.01, using the walk control scheme while playing standing up in a room-scale setup.)

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								First things, first, The Solus Project isn't just another survival game, its much more than that, its done what many other current FPS survival games haven't, had a narrative. You'll notice straight away that there is an intriguing storyline, which I won't go into much during this review due to spoilers (which ill try my best not to have), it's a game best played before watching any "Lets Plays" or any other gameplay spoiling videos. You should probably be avoiding this review, but here we are. I'll put the review into individual sections covering the games mechanics, due to the Early access nature and the already large amount of content already in the game, this review will be regularly updated as i explore the current features and any i have come across.The game features a robust weather system, with tides changes and water levels rising/lowering, snow falls and rainstorm occur which affects the temperature of the character, requiring you to find shelter and/or a source of heat.StoryI refuse to go into much detail for now (for your enjoyment) but will update in the future.GraphicsUtilizing the latest Unreal Engine 4 the game really benefits from having advanced graphics, I find I get a steady FPS on all setting at their highest, You can tweak additional settings in the configs files but i have'nt delved into them just yet (will update when i try them out).Textures are high quality, lighting effects and the general details in the levels are fantastic, spider webs hanging in caverns, colored lightingfrom crystals (some form of torches). I didn't like the fire effect on the default torch and you can't see the protagonists hands when holding most items but it is early access. SoundThe atmosphere in the environments really benefit from the high quality sound effects, from eerie sounds in caverns to the flames from a damaged ship engine.I was genuinely freaked out when I was exploring a dark cave and I could hear these strange noises echoing from deep within. Voice acting isn't fantastic butits pretty good, atleast to me.GeneralOverall I'm currently enjoying The Solus Project and its a huge step forward for the company since Unmechanical and a gigantic leap since "The Ball",I enjoyed The Ball but it hasn't aged well. The player can explore a ton of islands and solve puzzles. It's like Tomb Raider but an FPS on an alien planetin the future...with aliens..., Well it has Tombs in it. The tombs/caverns are extremely creepy as mentioned a few times during this review. I haven't come across any creatures yet (if any exist). I wouldn't recommend this to people that want a Call Of Duty shoot em up or want to murder everything that moves. I really like the variety in difficulty, from hardcore survival to an Easy mode for those of use that enjoy the game for story and exploration rather than the realistic survival aspect of hardcore mode. I've barely dented the surface of this great game and will update this review regularly as I play through more content and the game gets nearer to release. The developer is often updating and releasing new updates, Episode 2 was just released with tons of new content.Summary+ Fantastic Graphics+ Unique Environments+ Story+ Difficulty Settings+ Open Environments+ High quality sound+ Atmosphere+ Will Support VR + Eye tracking+ Frequently updated+ Weather EffectsNeutral+/- No character customization (doesn't necessarily need it)+/- Can't see players hands (personal preference, could be down to supporting VR mode)Negative- Inventory management could be better9/10

content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												One of those gems of a game that for some reason isn't adequately advertised. I have been playing it only a couple of hours and I am completely wrapped up in it. If you like, mystery, science fiction, semi survival mechanics and great story telling then Solus is for you. I cannot recommend it highly enough. For the price, you can't beat it. You will get more enjoyment out of the game than you paid for it. Its one of those games.I don't review games very often, even the great ones like Witcher 3 and Fallout 4,etc., haven't gotten written praise from me; so for me do one for Solus, tells you I consider it a rare, rare game indeed. End of my original review.My original review stands for the game up until the ending. Now that the game is complete; and I have finished all levels; I wish to add this note about the end: If they were setting up a continuation of the story with a sequel or just another spiritual successor to the game, then I have no problems with the ending. However, if there is no further games planned for this game, than I have to say the ending was for me a total let down. Furthermore, if I had run across any indication that the ending played out the way it did I probably would not have purchased the game. I have not purchased other games because the ending of those games was not to my personal liking. Video games on the whole are not art forms. Some video games aspire to be an art form while other are done so well they deserve a higher quaility of appreciation. This games has elements of that higher quality of appreciation. But that ending,  is not a moral of the story kind of ending. It is an ending that should be examined closer because the aliens are committing serious genocide and no matter how long its takes the aliens will get their comeuppance. The company may not wish to go that route. Fine. However, the game let me down with that cliche ending that there is evil in the universe and the like it or not everyone survives. Meh.

Early Access Review
								Really enjoying it! I made it to the end (where you get a notice for the next part not released yet), really loving the environment, sounds and music. I've had more first time "woah!" moments that I can recall, haven't had this much new/original/unique stuff like this in a long time. 								The Solus Project is an exploration game (walking simulator) with great atmosphere and some survival elements. It's not an open world game with resources and crafting, the levels are linear and there is plenty of alien guacamole and water in the tombs, so you won't have to worry much about survival (except for when random tornado/meteor shower catches you on planet surface).But if you like story driven exploration games with mysteries, this one is the best looking atmospheric sci-fi "the interstellar like" experience you can get for 4 euros xD

Posted: March 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								I want to stress this is not a bad game from what I played, just not for me. I read review after review and thought this game looked great. I love survival games and I love science fiction. The problem for me was the lack of information about the fact the game is very much a mystery/puzzle solving game. I spent the first 15 minutes outside checking stuff out, and "surviving". Then after you go into the second cave it becomes a whole new game. I spent the rest of my time walking around inside a dark cave. Tunnel after tunnel after tunnel. Pointless door after pointless door to open. Water everywhere, food too, temp in  caves are great too and no weather. Survival went out the window for cave diving and linear "exploration"/puzzle solving. The caves I saw were hardly interesting either. Same thing everywhere I went. I decided I would rather get my money back and wait for the game to be finished and on sale. Maybe you love caves and puzzles... I do not though.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												The Solus Project is a hybrid adventure/survival game, successfully melding environmental exploration with managing the hazards an alien world. What begins as a fairly straightforward "crashed on an alien planet, time to survive and find out what happened" quickly evolves into a larger mystery uncovered through environmental storytelling and glyphs left around the environment.The game does a wonderfully job of making you feel like you're exploring an alien world; one that's familliar yet not quite right. The general atmosphere of the game is fairly benign, save for a stretch of time in the middle of the game where it shifts into more of a thriller/horror setting. It wasn't something I was expecting, which made it all the more unsettling (which I believe was the intended reaction).Puzzle solving is fairly intuitive and melds well with the exploration focus.  The survival elements never became overbearing. The storytelling was delivered well and I enjoyed piecing things together and constructing a fuller understanding of what happened to my ship and what exactly has happened on the world you're stranded on. The ending stumbles a little bit, of which your understanding of it will likely depend on how many pieces of lore you've uncovered and how well you've stitched it together in your head. I could see the ending making little to no sense for people who just main-line it straight through; finding ways to make some of the more important historical information central to the main progression would have smoothed over this issue.The game looks gorgeous with numerous times where I just stopped to take in the scenery. Unreal Engine 4 runs great and I experienced no crashes or bugs. I did not play in VR.All in all, The Solus Project is a great little game that will take you around 10-15 hours to beat and offers an interesting story, unique and compelling world, and plenty of pretties to make your eyeballs happy. Recommended.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								Solus, where to start. The direction of the game is a unique one. You are one of the last humans alive in the universe. You crash land on an alien beach (ARK) and have to use basic crafting supplies to survive (ARK). As you progress alien sounds and relics empower and guide your path to find a benevolent intelligence at work. The strengths of this game include a bizarre alien weather system, which makes survival interesting and unpredictable. One minute you're burning hot, the next you're freezing. You can retreat to various safe areas, which typically coincide with save points, but you will encounter a dark presence, which leaves you few options for a safe retreat. As survival games go, this one has puzzles that remind me strongly of any of the recent Metroid games. (I say recent, I think back to Gamecube and Nintendo 64) The puzzles require intelligence and planning. You will eventually have more locks than keys. Choose wisely! (spoiler)The textures (graphics) leave a little to be desired, but as you go you get swept up in the big picture. There are very few glitches (if any, I have encountered none) and many hours to be derived between searching for secrets, dodging the weather, hunting for aliens, and finding interesting new things to craft. This game gets 5/5 from me. Definitely recommended.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								As survival adventures go, this game has got it...Solus Latin for alone... yes there is only you left, all your crew mates are dead, Earth has been destroyed and it took you 10 years to get here.. What can go wrong....Well about everything in fact, as the planet is basically out to get you- and it will if you are not careful.Ways to die thus far:Die to starvation- yepDIe to hypothermia- oh yeaDie to drowning yesDie to MASSIVE hurricane- WTF is... ARGHHDie to meteor shower- oh look shineh,., OMFG- RUUUNN!Die to Lightning storm, while pretending to be Thor.. yes.. yes i did this..Die to falling off a cliff, into acid and off various other ledges.. yes- YOLO!Die to the "smoke beasty".. ohh whassat?.. ARRGHHH it does what- OMFG...Die to explosive gas.. that you set off with your fire touch.. yes.. grrDie to various "biohazards".. yes.. there are severalDie due to lack of sleep- yesDie due to tiredness- not sleep(you may not be able to rest- see weather)Die because you were sleeping and something happened, and it woke you up... you are unable to sleep because of the elements...rain, firestorm, Hurricane to name a few...So yes, there a MANY ways to die..I have managed a few of the list...The climate of the planet is amazing, from baking hot sun to ice storms(with cool nasty lightning) hurricanes, driving rain, howling winds and clear skys all within a few hours of each other- its harsh out there, so when it changes(and it will) SEEK COVER QUICKLY!I literally died 2 mins into my 1st game when a hurricane landed on me.. oh whats is that noise... oh it looks like- OH MY %^^&&&%&%$&&£ ^"^$£^^$^£$^£... you died-  Restart game.The game is still in early access, but it looks stunning, even at 3440x1440. I have not found any major bugs, only 1 and that was due to my own stupidity by jumping into a tight space and being unable to escape.. i did this a few time to test it..I am at the end of act/ phase 3 and i am eagerly awaiting the ice caved(of death)...Saving the game can be harsh- literally if you are caught out in the open and it turns nasty(see above) as you can not save unless at a sleep point(usually a safe place) or a save point. Other than that, and you will have to keep an eye on the elements when out walking, climbing and swimming... Eyes on the skies people!If you like wandering about(there is a LOT of this) hunting for items, secrets(found a few of them) as well as key components for crafting stuff, and other "keys" to open doors / solve puzzles this will be right up your street.I took a punt on it, and .. i`ve become pretty well hooked! I have had a great time playing and dying to this game, as survival games are not really my thing, but this game is great fun,and makes you think as you get very little instructions on what to do and where to find stuff... So what are you waiting for- get it while it is cheap

Posted: October 28, 2016
												I am really sad to give this game a thumbs down, I had very high hopes for it because I found the idea of a non-violent planet exploring game where you fight the elements interesting, unfortunatly, it's not that fun. Not a whole lot is happening, you do a lot of walking to find stuff and combine stuff, and that's about it, that's the gameplay. You gotta keep dry, warm, drink, eat and sleep, that's great, but apart from that, you just walk, find things and combine them. This is the problem with a no-combat game, you have to substitute the combat with something else or you end up standing next to a campfire doing nothing and waiting to get dry.Tl;dr: It's boring. Yes, I knew from the start that it's 'one of those games' but I don't like it. I find it neither challenging, nor engaging.Also, I got stuck in a dark cave that I didn't know had water in it, I lost my torch and couldn't teleport out, which was very annoying. This pretty much rekt my playthrough and I had to decide then and there if I want to continue or else I couldn't get a refund if I started all over again. I decided no.

												Not many people mention it but this is partly a horror game. However it doesn't make you leave your chair it sucks you in. The story is quite rich. You don't get cut scenes that explain the story, you figure out the story by interacting which I quite enjoyed (oh and you need to make sure there is nothing behind you while you're reading the walls and such). You spend a lot of time in the caves that connect every islands, it scares you bad enough that you want to see the sunlight, but when you do get back to surface you realize that nature hates you and you're better off in the caves. Overall this is a pretty good game with some very minor flaws, which I think are unimportant. Definitely worth every coin spent on it.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												I've been enjoying this game since launch. Initially there were a lot of issues around controlling the game in VR and it was not in a state I would recommend. After several updates the game has been cleaned up a lot and controlling the game in VR is now a lot better. On the Vive it still plays like gamepad controls have been mapped to the motion controllers with the controllers acting more as a cursor, and you still have to press buttons to have held objects interact with anything, rather than using physical interactions. But overall it is still a good experience and mostly intuitive. The game is a single player campaign in an open world, with a set of linear objectives. There is a mystery to unearth on this alien world, and all the while you need to survive. The world itself is believable and well designed, and both artistically and technically gorgeous. The meat of the gameplay is in exploration of its world and occasional puzzles, which usually revolve around using an item you found on something. The game is heavily reminiscent of adventure games such as Riven or The Dig, in its world, atmosphere and game mechanics. There are also survival elements such as having to deal with hunger, thirst, hypo/hyperthermia and sleep, but these didn't really add much to the gameplay. There is a slider to tune them down to a minimum if you find them too difficult or annoying. I have not yet finished the campaign and am about six hours in. I'll update this once I'm finished but for now I feel I can already recommend the game, particularly for VR users looking for a campaign with a good amount of content for the price. Right now, particularly for the Vive there is a lack of long form content and this certainly fulfills that role nicely. When you also look at the game's price this is probably the best game from a content point of view - you can easily pay double what the developer is asking for other VR games that will end up with half the playtime.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
Product received for free
An Exploration Adventure Survival Game


YouTube™ Video: The Solus Project || Exploration Adventure Survival Game || Part 1 

			Views: 588		

			#thesolusproject http://store.steampowered.com/app/313630 Add me on Steam: http://steamcommunity.com/id/desolater_iv/ + One of the best most immersive exploration games I have ever played....		

+ One of the best most immersive exploration games I have ever played.... The game keeps pushing you forward with so much mystery you can't help but think "what comes next?!" At times I felt like stopping, and then a new area would open up or some event would take place that would force me to continue onward. + The amount of content in this game is unbelievable. You will think you are getting close to the end but it just keeps going. You will likely spend over 8-10hours+ to get to the end.+ The planet you explore is HUGE with a variety of very atmospheric environments with a metric ton of space to explore. Many miles of islands, caves, and tombs to wonder through. You truly do feel like you are on an alien planet.+ The story is pretty epic, especially if you manage to get through the entire game. In the most basic terms, you crash land on a alien planet, and must find if it's hospitable enough for humans to live on after Earth is destroyed. What you find....is pretty alarming.+ Graphically speaking the game looks gorgeous. I was playing at max settings at 1440p, and loved every minute of it. + The survival elements are "light" meaning that you won't be wasting too much time going out finding food or water. The game typically provides a lot of water / food sources. (TIP: DO NOT LOSE YOUR TORCH)+ So many alternate paths, and places to discover. It almost felt like there wasn't anywhere you could not reach, and there is useful items, artifacts, and lore hidden everywhere!- Some of the puzzles can be a bit overly challenging which can be a bit irrating. At some point through the game I was just like "Ughhhh I have to find more keys?! Just let me continue through the game!" - The game doesn't provide you with a good sense of direction or purpose. You will feel lost, confused, and alone throughout most of the game. I was constantly thinking "what am i doing? where am I going? What am I supposed to be doing? Am I even going the right way" as the rabbit hole kept going deeper and deeper and deeper.This game is better than most AAA games, you won't be disappointed, and has earned a spot in my favorites

content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
The Solus Project - What A Great Experience!You find yourself in orbit of a newly discovered planet in an attempt to rescue humanity from extinction back home on Earth. Suddenly your mothership is engaged by an unknown entity, forcing your immidiate emergency descent to the surface of Gliese-6143-C. Things are not what they seem at first. Your are confronted with servere weather conditions, harsh climate and only a few basic things to help you survive. Sleep, hunger, thirst, temperature and body wetness play a fundamental role in the game and it is up to you to learn how these parameters are affected. No one is holding your hand here. Throughout the game you come across texts and inscriptions. Sometimes segments of text refer to ancient history known to humans on Earth today. Is there perhaps a connection between our civilization and that of Gliese-6143-C? In other places you might come across inscriptions seemingly belonging to a complete different entity. Who were these former planetary settlers?The Solus Project (TSP) has a consistent storyline but also a lot of variation as you encounter different environments from blazing cold to heat only comparable with that of Hell itself. As you will learn there are clever ways to comply with these extreme conditions during the game. As a sci-fi fan myself I really appreciate the way the devs have used their ingenuity throughout TSP. You will almost surely become immersed right from the beginning!TSP offers some great environments! I have been perplexed several times during the game by the size and scale of things. Some of the buildings you encounter are asbolutely megalithic! Huge structures with many secrets and hidden bonuses giving you advantages in movement-speed, falling-damage and lots more! You also come across massive cave systems (which can be somewhat difficult to navigate in for the first-time player, hint: beacon) with countless secrets, adding yet another dimension to the game's survival aspect.TSP clearly targets the curious and explorative gamer-segment and there are a couple of pretty neat puzzles aswell. The game can get pretty eerie at times but it's not actual horror. I have gotten some pretty good scares in the game where things looked to be something they were not! A place where TSP falls short though, is in the conclusion of the game. I was left with more questions than before I started the game, and there doesn't really seem to be a final wrap-up. The mission objective of TSP is to ensure the survival of mankind, but this issue is quickly dealt with by introducing the discovery of another habitable planet found through the Aliens' starmap. There are many hours of gameplay in TSP and if you love sci-fi it's packed with that!OVERALL RATING: 8.5/10

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												This review is strictly for the vr version of the game.  The quick review is this: It’s the best experience I have had to date with my vive and I highly recommend it. Now for a little more detail.  I was skeptical of this game since it is a port from a standard pc game.  I’ve read that porting a game is a recipe for disaster for vr.  The port does come with some down sides.  Since the game wasn’t made with motion controllers in mind, most of the interactions are point and click.  For example: you have a can that you want to open up and eat the food inside.  With the motion controllers and playing other vive games you may get the idea that you can set the can down, pull a pipe out, and swing for the fences with your controller to have the pipe smash open the can.  This is not the case.  You simply drop the can on the ground, pull the pipe out, point the cursor at the can and pull the trigger “simulating opening the can”.  The other negative in its current state is the inventory system.  Right now you have to cycle through everything which is a bit cumbersome.  The devs are working on an update to this issue and supposedly will have it out in the next couple days, so this will more than likely be even more of a non-issue than it currently is. Now on to the positives of the pc game port.  This is an actual, fully-realized game.  This isn’t a cool concept. Its not a wild 10 minute tech demo that has you salivating for more. My previous favorite experience was the gallery.  The gallery is $30 and lasts about 3 hours.  It’s a wonderful experience and great use of vr, but its over before you really get into it.  The Solus Project does not have this problem.  I am currently 5 hours into the game and have only scratched the surface of this world that you get to explore.  The devs say that you can beat it in roughly 17 hours, but can take up to 50 if you explore all the areas.  I long game like this is what the vive needs. There is depth to this game that you simply won’t find on any of the current made for vr games on steam.   Now let me take a moment to break down a couple aspects of the game. Controls: There are several different options you can do to move around the planet.  The standard teleport option which most games use is also available for The Solus Project.  For those that can handle it, you can also use one of the track pads to move around.  In the options I have set the walking speed to 30% and love the experience that it provides so much more than teleporting everywhere.  It’s a nice slow pace that will probably take me ages to complete the game, but its at a pace that I feel like I’m actually walking through the caves.  Overall the control options are good enough to allow you to play the way its most comfortable for you.  I also need to mention that the motion controls are definitely utilized in the game.  I mentioned above that the interactions are mostly point and click.  While this is true, the motion controls still work great.  When holding up the torch, you can move it around to change the angle of the light hitting off the cavern walls, point the flashlight where you want, etc.  the controls are 1:1 in terms of movement, just don’t expect to swing a sword around and have it physically hit something. Graphics: Holy crap is this game gorgeous.  Again, this is what sets this game apart from most games out for the vive.  These devs have taken a lot of time to make the caves look as organic and natural as possible.  The Unreal engine really shines in this game.  The feeling of being in a large alien cave chamber is indescribable.  The pacing of the game also lends to the visuals constantly changing.  By the time I was getting used to the cave scenery, the cave would end and you would be thrust into a gorgeous outdoor scene with alien beaches, rock formations, meteor showers, crazy storms.  It really pulls you into the game and gives you the feeling that you are on this alien world. Audio: The audio is perfect.  The general creepy ambiance they have created with the sound is superb.  I  hate horror games and jump scares. This is definitely not one of those games.  However walking around in a cave is inherently creepy.  Add in that this is a cave on an alien planet and the creepy factor goes up a couple notches.  There have not been any jump scares or anything scary that I have experienced in the game.  The creepiness and general foreboding as to what is behind the next turn is greatly enhanced by the audio.  I’m pretty sure it has spatial audio in the game.  There have been several times where I know I’ve heard something behind me.  Being able to pinpoint sound locations also adds to the overall atmosphere that they have created in the game. Gameplay: This game so far is more of a walking-simulator where you are the lead in a mystery story that is unraveling before your very eyes.  You aren’t going to feel like a badass like when you play holopoint or SPT. If you are in to movies like interstellar, or books like The Martian, you will absolutely love this experience.  I have been awestruck by the beauty of this game, and I have had to tell myself that I’m really just in my basement and nothing is going to hurt me if I keep moving forward.  The puzzle’s have been non-existant to really easy so far, but I’ve only just begun. Overall, this is the exact type of experience I was dreaming of when I first learned that VR was becoming a reality.  This game gives you the ability to travel the cosmos and explore an alien planet while you try to survive and figure out what’s going on with the planet.  Not too bad for only $20!  I can’t recommend this game enough! Go buy it now before the devs realize that this is at least a $50 experience. You won’t regret it.

Posted: February 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								The Solus Project is a diamond in the rough of survival games. While most will bore me with the repetetive gameplay, "The Solus Project" has kept me interested by keeping the survival elements as a side feature and focusing more on the exploration and story. And man is the story interesting. I haven't even gotten that far in, but I'm intrigued. Why did my ship get shot down? Who built all this stuff? Will I ever be found? These are all question I want answered. Mostly though, my very very recent experience with a weather anomaly is amazing. I woke up to a tornado spiraling out of control, I walked out of my house (cave) and was in awe of the tornado, it got closer to me, I ran into a wall trying to escape and then took shelter in my tiny cave, the music is amazing, the voice acting could use some work though.EDIT: As I progress through the story I can't help but be even more intrigued. There was a civilization here. The best part was finding The eggs and skeletons, and learning about the Sky gods. The graphic are great, the gameplay is amazing. This game is probably one of my top 5 favourite games.

The PDA and inventory could use some work but I find it not enough to get in the way of the experience. The navigation functions like that of The Lab allowing both walking around and teleporting.Aside from that I am finding the game to be a fun experience. I love exploring the alien world and caves. Crafting is fun as well. I am eager to venture deeper and discover the secrets of this world.If you have a Vive, I'd highly recommend it even if support is in beta at the moment.

content:
Posted: January 18
												Spoiler Free Review: The Solus Project was an unexpected surprise.  I did not play it via VR, but still thought it was an enjoyable game.  You play as a stranged astronaut on a deserted world.  Loads of exploration and reading ensue.  Even without the VR, I thought the graphics were good, and the controls smooth.Note that this isn't an action game, more of a novella.  A sci-fi story which requires exploration and to get the most out of it, reading.  The aliens in the story are quite interesting, but you have to read and search and explore pretty much everywhere to get the most out of it.  I understand if that is not the type of game everyone enjoys.  Honestly, you rarely have an enemy or see any living thing besides yourself until well into the game. Replayability:  No multiplayer or DLC available for this game.  One play through is enough, although if you're like me you'll be going back to try and get all of the achievements.  Some of which are very hard, such as finding all of the secrets. Rating: 7 out of 10. Recommended. Playing on i7-6700, 16Gb Ram, GTX1070

content:
Posted: April 3
												Highly recommended for explorers and completionists. This game is hours and hours of exploring, walking around vast cave and tunnel networks, temples, and deserted-ish islands. If you just want to wander 'over this way' and see what's there, you're going to probably enjoy this game. There are secrets to be found, journals and labels to read, inventory to keep track of ... all the while keeping yourself healthy (warm, fed, rested).It's not 100% free-roam, happy-go-lucky: there are a few antogonists you'll have to learn to avoid or run from. The first few times I encountered these things, I was swearing and messing my drawers, as the makers of this fantastic game outdid themselves with the music score. Dread and anxiety, heh ... why not just say FEAR, crept up on me as the music & sounds got closer. It's not horror genre, however. There are no jump-scares or zombies out to dine on your flesh. After a few run-ins with the 'things', you'll learn how to properly deal with them, and (hopefully as I did) marvel at their presence.There are puzzles, jumping puzzles. Nothing hard and annoying, especially since one of your tools allows you to go pretty much ANYWHERE you want to. The game is LONG, and replayable. I found less than half of the secrets, and look forward in a few years time to hitting it up again with someone's video/guide/map to aid me in finding every nook & cranny.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												This is the most awful thing i have experienced in the vive. The controls are far too numerous, the movement is sickening, the objects are hideous. I couldn't carry on playing it. In summary there is a lot of stuff that should be disabled when playing in VR mode as it's just bad for the experience. Controls: The button that does one thing on one hand, does something completey different on the other. What's pick up on one hand is teleport on the other, whats menu on one hand is crouch on the other. For VR this is very difficult to get your head around. The two track buttons have 8 functions! Movement: there is teleport which is ok.. there is button that glides you foward, and forward is not determined by which way you are facing but by the game somehow. so if you turn to your left and push the "glide forward" button you start shifting sideways! Turn all the way around and it's now a "glide backwards" button. This gliding is pretty sickening even when looking in the direction that you are facing. Crouch has no movement or animation, you just teleport to about shin height, which is far too low for a crouch anyway. Scale: in one hand appears your vive controller at normal size, in the other is a MASSIVE tricorder type thing. Easily 5 times the size of the vive controller in the other hand. To make this worse you can't read anything on it without moving it closer to your face making it take up half of your entire field of view. Scale wise it's like carrying around a briefcase sized tablet in one hand.In short things like crouch need to be removed when playing in the vive, as players will just crouch. Also unbind things like rotate left/right and glide forwards (unless it can go the direction the player is facing). I understand these controlls are trying to be appropriate to people with the Rift, where they might not be able to crouch or turn and are just head tracking, but why then bind these controlls to the Vive controller?? If you own a vive PLEASE do not put people into this game as it will taint their opinion of VR forever.

number of helpful: 12 of 17 people (71%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
From the creators of "The Ball" comes a far more confident and genuinely interesting offering, serving up a slice of survival adventure that for once, doesn't require you to harvest a ton of wood.The Ball was a really good game, don't get me wrong, but it was at it's core, about "The Ball", and as such effectively was centered around a singular note, navigating and solving puzzles with the titular ball. It was an excellent exercise in good puzzle gameplay, with a smattering of platforming and a side dish of adventure story nonsense if you did a bit of skimming into it, but it was a first try for the studio, so really it was mostly for them to get their eye in and to make sure they weren't doing anything mechanically wrong. In that sense, "The Ball" was a roaring success."The Solus Project", that's a far different proposition, this is a game that actually goes several steps further, creating a real story around your actions, a limited survival system that whilst not lethally challenging in "normal" difficulty (in hardcore however, you'd best believe it can punish you fast) does serve as a constant reminder to keep fed, watered and rested, and a zelda-like crafting and inventory system that gradually expands your reach and your ability to explore an alien island that you've just crashlanded into, nose first.A very beautiful, desolate land, it's like Sweden, but an unearthly SwedenAnd oh what an island it is, it's genuinely beautiful at ultra settings, whilst managing to remain fairly decent looking even if you tamp down on the pretty, whilst there's very little to actively contend with in the sense of wildlife and movable nastiness, there's a fallen civilisation that's left behind a lot of high tech nastiness, and a lot of that can, and will kill you if you're not paying attention. You learn pretty fast to keep an eye on the floors, ceilings and immediate surroundings if you're indoors, and your atmospheric readings if you're outdoors, as the outdoor temp can swing wildly between "So cold it freezes your genitalia off" to "So hot not even ice cream will help", this doesn't count the weather cycles, which seem to take their cues from America circa 2016, complete with tornadoes, blizzards, torrential rain, heatwaves, and that's all in twenty four hours.Your primary mission is to re-establish contact with Solus command, and effectively to warn them that the planet has a giant energy cannon that is being operated by the remaining natives that can and will blow anything out of orbit (as seen in the intro), so it's likely a really, really bad idea to come knocking at this planet unless they fancy a dose of highly concentrated plasma being slung at the colony ship (almost certainly a bad plan).Over the course of the game you'll get a bunch of downrange transmissions sent to your dinky little PDA from Solus command who are getting progressively more panicky at the state of the Solus probe teams, it seems most of them have not ended up in places that would qualify as "safe", but more than that would be deemed spoilery, so I'll keep that bit quiet.Unfortunately, whilst you might be "A" martian, you're no Matt DamonThe game leaves you alone to deal with the hazards posed by Gisele, the planet you are stranded on for the bulk of it, and essentially puts you in the shoes of "The Martian" but instead of trying to survive, you're trying to explore and figure out just what in the name of dieties is going on with the planet, you'll be spelunking through caves, picking through the remnants of a previous civilisation, and dealing with some genuinely creepy stuff as you work your way into the bowels of the planet. As you progress you'll gain an inventory of useful items for helping you deal with the various environmental hazards, starting with simple tools and working up to the really helpful stuff like hammers, teleporters and ropes to pick your way through.Some areas are very much "linear", you'll go through them and unlikely revisit them unless you're going secret hunting, others are much more exploratory, since you'll have to scour them for the parts of the comms tower, but in either case, you'll be roaming Gisele back and forth for a significant sum of time, probably 12-16 hours for the average player. If, like me you got this during the sale, this is a fantastic buy and well worth the money.  At full whack, potentially a tricker choice to make depending on your love for exploration games, if you -really- like them, then it's a safe recommendation, if not, you may want to wait for the sale to hit.Final ThoughtsThe Solus Project marks a coming to form from the creators of "The Ball", it's a much more confident and complete game, and it definitely marks their graduation from promising developers to fully fledged and talented rising stars. If the Solus Project is indicative of what we can expect of their things to come, they've a genuinely bright future among the distant echoes of space.Verdict : Recommended, if you like survival exploration games, upgrade to highly recommended.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
												The Solus Project:~~~~~~~~~~~~~~  After the earth has been destroyed, the faith of mankind is now relying on a small fleet of colony ships near Pluto! Your job is to scout planets to determine if one of them is suitable for human habitation. Well, as you approach one of them, your ship is hit by something coming from below and you just manage to reach the escape pod in time. As you fall rather quickly towards it, you keep wondering what you are going to find out upon impact!The Solus Project is a First Person/Survival/Exploring game with absolutely stunning visuals. At the start of the game, you will see a couple of splendid introduction videos from the destruction of earth to your crash landing. Then, you will step onto this glorious scenery of the planet Gliese-6143-C.All is beautiful but you really have nothing on you and your first task is to scavenge for useful items around the crash site. The first one you find is a survival device; a PDA which will tell you when to eat, drink, sleep, the outside temperature, can decrypt alien writing and other useful options.  You will be lead to specific destinations and will be shown where you can find food, water and how to craft items too. The game atmosphere is just brilliant - either you are on the surface of the planet or deep in the caves. The weather element is well done, too. You might experience a meteor shower, lighting and other extreme weather on the planet surface. Try to gather food (cans of food or plants) before entering the cavern just to be on the safe side. Oh, and be careful not to get wet too often especially in a cold environment like caverns. This is a great recipe for hypothermia!   The game does have a puzzle element to it, but to be honest they are not very difficult (as far as I have progressed) but make sure to read all the notes as well as the Alien symbols which can provide you with great intel; your PDA is very handy for that.You will only be able to store up to 12 items in your inventory at the Start of the game, which is a bit of a bugger. I like to gather as many items as I can and you never know when you might need them.Graphically this game is stunning. Mouse and keyboard for the controls and great sound effects all round. Also, you can set whatever level you want to play, from easy to hard.  Positives:~~~~~~~~ -	Stunning Graphics-	Good story-line-	Great weather effects-	Very good atmosphere-	Achievement & trading cardsNegatives:~~~~~~~~  -	Inventory could hold a larger number of itemsThe Solus Project is a very good First Person exploration game with a good story and splendid visuals! It is time for you to land on the planet Gliese! You won’t regret it!9/10Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!EPIC “THE CPT FROGGY” REVIEWS UP NOW ON ZEEPOND, THE HOME OF THE ALMIGHTY FROG![www.zeepond.com]FOLLOW THE CPT FROGGY CURATOR PAGE HERE

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												Solus project is a story-focused exploration game with survival elements. The story of this game is mostly told through environmental storytelling: reading plaques scatterd through the environment, observing said environment, listening to the protagonist recording his diary and some communication from the rest of the humanity's fleet. This game is quite good at storytelling, much better than I would have expected from this studio, given The Ball's... questionable storyline, both in terms of delivery and writing. This one's story is not only fantastically voice-acted (albiet there is VERY little dialogue), the environments are also excellently crafted and paced to preserve the sense of mystery, without creating confusion. Game's world is scattered though several open levels, which you progress between in a linear fashion (though you can always go back to explore and scavenge a previous level). Levels are rather open at the start and they get more linear toward the end. I don't know why it was made this way, it doesn't detract anything from the experience, but it doesn't add anything either. And sometimes I did miss a little storyline-free exploration towards the end of the game. Closer to the end you start to get a lot of information very rapidly, making a little more open and safe to explore levels would have helped some people process that info, IMO. Throughout the game, as you explore you are required to manage a basic set of survival stats. That is probably the most frustrating thing in the game, and for the most part it serves no purpose other than to restrict you from exploring at your own pace. Thankfully the survival elements are rather simplistic and not the focus (and by setting difficulty to easy you can pretty much just ignore them), because if they weren't I would definitely have hated this game. As it stands, they simply get in the way, but not too much. What I will say is that there is a stat which DOES contribute to gameplay: temperature. Manging temperature in this game is closely tied to gameplay, and unlike other survival stats, it actually contributes a lot to the atmosphere in some places. Reminds me of Cryostasis: Sleep of Reason (maker's breath, that was a good game), except here you also need make sure you don't overheat, just as much as freeze.This game does let you save your progress at any time by sleeping (assuming you sleep in a safe place), which is very important as it is incredibly unfair, when it comes to killing you. Most of the dangers in this game come from hazards, and there is one in particular - some sort of alien drone, that they don't actually reveal the details about, which kills you instantly when it touches you. That drone has fixed paths it partols, but instead of going back and forth like you'd expect, it spawns at the start of the path after finishing the route. When you don't know where that start is, it can and it WILL spawn right on you, killing you instantly. That would be incredibly infuriating if you could only save at save shrines. As it stands it's just a mild annoyance. The game also likes to obsure some traps in shadows, and there's a hazard which instantly kills you when you walk into with a torch lit (this is not mentioned ever before). Furthermore the game can spawn climate anomalies, which you have to hide from in caves, however especially towards the end of the game, the caves are really not that common, so if you encounter such an anomaly and you don't find any shelter in the next 30 seconds (which depends largely on luck), you are also dead.One of the greatest things about this game is it's sound design. Fantastic ambiance, with well-placed and fitting music and great sound processing, combined with my Corsair Void Wireless create an amazing atmosphere at any point in the game. Eerie in caves and dark chasms, calming outside during the quite mornings, exciting during a cataclysm of some kind or when you are exploring large alient structures.Contrary to the sound, the graphics is not that great. Poor texture quality is quite common, despite running on highest settings, and my 2560x1080 monitor really highlights lack of polygons on many models. Lighting is not better than Skyrim with mods and in general this game looks like something from 2011, and no a 2016 game running on UE4. I did work with Unreal Engine 4 a while ago and I know what it can do without too much effort from the art team. I guess it simply wasn't the focus. What I will say is that weather effects do look amazing, even if the tornados for example always repeat the same animation, which is not exactly accurate (but then again this is an oceanic planet with a desert climate, so clearly realism is not what they were going for).Lastly I would like to express my disappointment at the game's ending. It is, frankly,♥♥♥♥♥♥ Absolute trash. After such an awesome game to get such a rushed, vaigue, anticlimatic and dumb ending is much worse than getting it at the end of a trash game. I don't know if they ran out of money, or if they are sequel-baiting, but that ending provided no explanation, no closure, and no answers whatsoever. Moreover, after the game spent so much effort building up the importance of your task, making the player invest in that importance (even the death screen constantly tells you about it), it is extremely disheartening to just see such abrupt and inconclusive finalie to your mission.The ending is, by far, the worst part of the game. So much so that I probably would have been better off if I just left the game at that point, where I finish the communications tower. It was even worse because I didn't expect it to be so bad. I honestly thought there's going to be some extra levels on the alien mothership, teased in the distance for the last 3 levels. Never could I have though that such a good game can just end like that.I still recommend it, because no matter how bad the ending is, the rest of the game is excellent. And all you horror devs: THIS is how you make horror. This game is not even a horror by nature, but it's scary sections are more eerie than 20 Amnesia's combined. Because instead of putting stupidly exaggerated ugly monsters and jump-scares, it manages to create an atmosphere that tickles your nerves even when you KNOW there's no danger. That is friggin impressive. So yeah: play it. And I hope by expecting a disappointing ending, you'll be less disappointed than I was, when it ended so abruptly.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												Thoroughly been enjoying this on the Rift. About time I can find a good rift experience... and for the current $12 it is definitely worth it. The "normal" mode is a bit too easy, as there are way more survival resources than required, all over the place, but I'm probably going to be too lazy on trying anything harder at this point.I can understand why others say it is repetitive, as it is in many ways. But I love the open world. It's a lot larger than I ever expected. I'm the kind of guy that likes to find everything (Zelda syndrome), so I'm starting to get bored looking for any secrets, and 95% of the time the secrets are worthless. Permanent buffs are pretty much always only 1%. Woopy.  At this point (8 hours in), I think I'm just gonna try to do general explorations of areas and forget about trying to find secrets. The way I have been playing is definitely burning me out.My biggest problem with the game is that I WANT to explore all the environments, but sometimes I don't know that the way I am heading is to the "next area", and then it takes forever to go back. I just accidentally skipped like 4 areas and got to the third island, and I barely even touched the second island. I hate missing content and the game doesn't make it clear what is the next way to go, so I feel I am missing a lot going the "right" way first.

												An incredibly immersive sci-fi exploration and survival adventure. A journey across and through an alien planet builds and grows as you try to find a way to save your mission from disaster. It has survival aspects as you battle the elements of a hostile planet, making sure you don't freeze to death, and lots of exploration with plenty of secrets to find and a world lore that expands as you make your way across the planet. content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								The Solus Project forces my hand into giving a positive review for three simple reasons:1) Developer communication. Having had fairly important issues initially running this game in virtual reality (Oculus DK2) I had to resort to the community hub for some help, which finally ame in the form of an update from the developers. Not only were my issues resolved, but options were added to resolve issues others were having, and in the end we even got options that are a welcome extra. Devs that communicate so openly and then deliver on the discussion need to be recognized.2) Amazing performance. While the game is in "late early access", the VR portion of it is far less complete, but what makes it easy to handle - not being the case with most VR games - is the butter-smooth performance. When I'm not using any recording software I've seen the game stick at 75fps without even touching any of the stock settings. This will lgo a long way in making your playthrough smoother.3) Well polished. This part applies less to VR and more to the game overall... for what is being delivered, the game is almost there. They seem to have their mechanics about 95% the way, and at this point most of what's not here yet is actual content. The game has gotten my attention enough to select it for a let's play video series.Here's the DailyMotion 2D-only version of my first impressions video:http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x3uzrpz_oculus-rift-dk2-the-solus-project_tech

content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
												For starters, I haven't had the chance to try this game on VR, so my review is with non-VR play in mind.I really enjoyed this game, through-and-through. First of all, the art of the planetscape, with all its unique flora especially, was spectacular. While at first I doubted that the survival and story elements would cooperate, I was quickly surprised by how well they worked together to form and immersive experience. The game is really engaging; I really felt like it was me stranded on this strange planet, seeing so many strange things, trying to understand what was going on. There wasn't a dull moment in this game, from start to finish, but it didn't feel stressful either, like some survival games. All in all, a great experience that I intend to play again. Would also love to try this game out on VR - after playing it normally I think it would significantly enhance an experience I already really enjoyed. Really the only thing I can think of about this game that bothered me was that your PDA is called "Wilson" but has a female voice. That's literally the only thing that bothered me. Everything else leads me to recommend this game :)

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												The Solus Project is a nice survival game with a taste of adventure and exploring. Yet there's room for improvements. Let's have a look!The mankind has lost their most important thing, the Earth. The only hope is The Solus Project, a space ship colony with the hope to find another planet to live in. You and your crew were sent to Gliese-6143-C, a harsh and barren planet, covered by a vast ocean. As soon as you've hit the planet's orbit, you were hit a strange projectile, causing fatal damage und thus the crash course into Gliese. You've survived the crash, wondering if the crew is okay. Once you stand on the assumed safe ground, it's just You, Gliese, and a Nokia like device that helps you in the entire adventure...The adventure I'm talking about puts you in many tests. Finding food, solving puzzles, uncovering the stories Gliese helds in it and most important, to not die. Optional, you can look for collectibles that can improve your gear and thus your surviving capabilities.Gameplay wise it's well made, although I couldn't really friend with the object interaction system. There are soo many areas to deal with, 5 islands connected with a cave system. Whereever you go, you won't loose the impression that there's a secret somewhere. When it comes to graphics and sounds, it's also impressive that leads you to a nice atmosphere. Well, not everywhere. I got massive FPS drops in certain areas while it's pretty smooth otherwise. When it rains and you run into a cave, the rain disappears. The graphics options have plenty of settings, and says you can edit the .cfg file for more. I know that from older games but for today I'd expect a GUI for every setting. Other than that I loved the exotic art and style of Gliese. Also worth mentioning is the very well made voice acting and soundtrack.With hard difficulty and a slight effort for secrets, it took me 18h to finish the game. It lasted pretty long I must say. In the other hand I was a bit glad that it's over. The story end is not I was hoping for and it left me with many open questions. But that's a good sign for a sequel and I hope it'll happen so.Altogether The Solus Project is a pretty good experience for the price and it deserves my recommendation.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												What a impressive game even without the use of VR.I'll start with the Gameplay:There are thrist and starvation mechanics and you need to sleep, but in my playthrough i never got any problem with finding food or water, because there are many savepoints with unlimited supply. Savings works either with sleeping or by using a savepoint. You also have to keep yourself in the right temperature, because some areas are hot as hell and others very cold. There is also a basic crafting system to craft torches or put some items together. You also have a very useful (and needed) teleportation device, that's needed in some areas to progress furter.Environment:The areas are small isles, connected with tunnels. There are many secret caves and in a small cave you could find a button that opens a gate at the other side of the area. The isles are barren with only some grass and trees, no animals or signs of life. The weather is dangerous if you are outside, got no cave to find shelter and a anomaly is coming over.Story:Wont say much to the story, but it took me 9 hours with finding a few secrets. If you really want to find them all then you will have more time. I liked the story and there are many survivor pages and stones with writings on it to find.Horror:They put a decent horror in the game. Its not that obvious like in other games (walk downstairs and ooooh wow a horror moment.....). There is the overall darkness and some pretty creepy things. You have the torch (emits heat), some useless glowsticks, a flashlight that needs solar energy, a red crystal (emits a small portion of heat and less light), a white crystal( emits a small portion of cold and less light) and you can make "orbs" out of the crystals at some rare occations to let the emit a lot of heat/cold.I will definitly come back if i get a VR somedays and i know that i will♥♥♥♥♥♥myself twice at moments where i got scared without.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												It all starts off so promising.  I like the visuals and the moons effecting the tides was an intersting mechanic that could have been put to good use, but it quickly degenerates into, running down  a boring cave corridor to get a  key and run all the way back to open a door.... rinse repeat. Over and over again.  Like empty Skyrim caves.  No challenge even on the hardest difficulty. No puzzles worth the name puzzle.The infinate oil torches are just a god mode cheat. . The cold no longer is a problem, and you get the infinate oil torches at the start of level one!  I advise anyone starting the game to limit them selves to one oil torch. Carrying three makes the cold mechanic irrelevant. If this game had some alien animals that were attracted to heat and you had to throw your torch as a decoy that would help imensely. But there are no animals to attack or chase you. Just a couple of rare creatures that you can easily evade with out even trying.I get why games want to avoid first person shooting things all the time, but in this case it was just boring.The Long Dark found a perfect balance of conflict between the player and the wildlife. It isn't a shoot everything on sight game but you do still have to be afriad of wolves and bears. The the Long dark I would fight them off with a torch most of the time and rarely shoot with my precious bullets only to eat the animal and use it's skin,  In The Solus project you just begin to realize that there will be nothing  intersting arround the next corner or over the next hill... Just more keys and locks. Nothing will really challenge you or threaton you. I must admit I havn't finished it yet. I got to the Giant windmill and was finally staved to death by the mindless tedium of it all.I wonder about these non violent games being part of Political Correctness... Was this game made by people who don't like violence in video games? I'm left wondering if the devs are Vegans and disaprove of people killing anything even if only to eat it and survive in a video game.Such a shame the visuals and setting are intreging but i'm still searching for the gameplay > maybe it is on the next island level...

content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												If you belong to movie fans Mission to Mars, The Martian, or Interstellar, then this game will for you.Before play first act, we got simple introduction. Earth is on the verge of ecological destruction. Desperate humanity begins search for new worlds to colonize, and we play as a member of one those responsible for this mission teams of explorers. The aim of the research expedition was reach to the planet, made establish base there, exploration planet to the research and preparation for the next expansion of the settlers. After twenty years of travel stellar, research expedition of The Solus 3 arrive at the place, but the landing on the planet ends in an accident, of which the result killed the entire crew! (of course except of character player) Worse, the damage is most of the hardware, including communications equipment. Thus, we are completely alone, and we can count only on themselves! Just you and mystery planet!The Solus Project is based on survival. The game included simplified mechanics of crafting with logical elements as also the discovery of secrets, hidden by the world and equipment recovered in the course of the story. Player need sleep, must maintain proper body temperature or the level of food and hydration. Must avoid injuries resulting from the fall or confrontation with hostile flora and fauna. You can die by starvation, hypothermia, overheating, drowning, hurricane, lightning storm or even meteor shower!Visually, we get unreal engine 4 with excellent sound effect and music, by what the game encourages you to explore all parts of the world, filled with the many secrets waiting to be discovered. Each sector is filled with monumental ancients structures, which can visit on your own or as a result of the progress of the story. Realy nice to see. Pleasant atmosphere with a touch of fantasy. I had good fun and I recommend try it!9/10 -  requires patience and determination to finish each act. There is a lot of walking and long distance from point to point and sometimes after long walking (special in caves) it becomes plunge.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
												I played this on PC. The game runs pretty well at 1080p. I only got noticeable frame rate drops when there were a lot of overlapping dynamic lights. This is my setup:Intel i5-2500k Sandy Bridge processor8 GB of RAMNVIDIA GTX 770Pros:- The planet's moon affects the tides, causing some areas to become easily accessible or difficult to access, respectively. This combined with the different weather effects makes outside world feels very dynamic and gives the sense that you are truly at nature's will.- The environments and effects are done really well. There is enough visual and aural feedback to give you a sense of your environment. For example, during the day the sun is so hot that you will begin to suffer heatstroke if you exposed for too long. Heat shimmer will begin to appear on the horizon as a visual cue that you shouldn't stay exposed for too long. Likewise, frost will form on the terrain when it is very cold.Cons:- Character movement feels a bit clunky. Character movement acceleration is so low that it takes a while to "ramp up" to full walking speed. This causes your movement to feel a bit unresponsive and sluggish.- You only feel like you're playing a true survival game for a few portions of the game. After a while, the survival aspect kind of takes a step back and the game becomes a full on adventure/exploration/puzzle game, with the survival kind of nagging you on the side. This is largely due to the fact that there are pots of alien soup and pools of drinkable water scattered throughout the game. Eventually the need to manage your inventory and plan ahead goes away completely.- Many of the environments, especially the caves and interiors, start to feel very same-y after a while.Pro tips:- Crouching and then jumping allows you to "spring up" and get a higher jump.- The teleport gun is very useful for traversing the map. You can combine that with jumping to launch the disc farther. You can use it to wander out for supplies and quickly recall back to home base. You can use it to escape bad situations.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												I originally bought this game when it was in Beta, though not from the very start. I love a good walking/exploration tye game, and I enjoy SciFi, so this seemed like it would be great... and it was! It reminded me of one of my first video games loves, Myst, only much more intense and a bit creepier. I had a ton of fun exploring each section of the planet, finding all the little secrets and unfurling the story. I loved it so much that when I hit my first end-point, rather than wait for the game to be updated, I went and played it again from the start on a harder level (and with a focus towards getting all the secrets too). It was even better the second time around, and with each update, and I really loved how the deeper into the game I went, the more and more creepy it became. There were quite a few moments where I was playing too late at night and got very creeped out!So all in all, this is a really wonderful game, especially if you want something you can enjoy over a long period of time rather than just rushing right through. It's a slow game, but perfectly paced for those who like exploration and a nice slow build. I loved the story itself of course (although I did see the end coming, but that was still okay, it didn't ruin it for me), I enjoyed all the puzzles (and having to solve them without any help since this game is so relatively new!), and on top of that I also really loved the game graphic and design. It felt like I was right there on this mysterious alien world-- I can only imagine how that would feel if I owned a VR device! I even enjoyed the survival aspects even if they're probably what I am the worst at. (Actually what I'm the worst at is falling off ledges in this game and hurting/near-killing myself, whoops!) Anyway to sum up, I highly, highly recommend this to anyone who likes scifi, puzzles, exploration, and a hint of a creepy factor! Enjoy!!

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
Product received for free
												You begin The Solus Project as a crew member aboard a colony ship sent to find a new home following the destruction of Earth. After an unknown event causes you to crash land on an alien planet you find yourself wandering out into the wilderness trying to find survivors and a way to contact home.The Solus Project is by and large and exploration game with some puzzle solving with the survival aspects never really causing too much concern. I played the game on medium so if you are looking for more of a survival edge to your experience it may be worth cranking up to hard from the get go.As you explore the hostile planet it becomes clear this is not an empty planet at all as you start to uncover signs of civilisation. To not give away any spoilers I will not talk about this in detail but let’s just say that the bits of civilisation play a key part in the game’s narrative and exploration.You have a number of other items at your disposal such as a teleporter which is useful for getting through gaps and up ledges and a beacon allowing you to return if you get lost in a cave. There is also a basic crafting system allowing the creation of items such as a fire torch but this never seemed to run out and could be out away in your inventory for use later.The inventory system is actually one of my least favourite parts of the game. You can actually hold a lot of items and cycling through these can take a really long time. Especially when stood in pitch black trying to search through mountains of food and water bottles in search of the flaming torch.Visually the game is gorgeous and contains some of the best weather effects I have ever seen in a game. The tornado and meteor showers that occasionally fill the landscape are awe dropping and were one of the first times in a long time I have been genuinely impressed by graphics in a game.The pacing in the game is a little odd. The game is broken up into a series of “islands” connected by underground caves. These cave sections are usually one long corridor connected by a series of puzzles and these often felt too long to traverse. Equally while I get the idea of wanting to make the players feel like they are on a massive planet (even though we happen to crash land literally next to these alien structures) some of the outside areas are a little sparse and could do with being a little more densely packed with stuff to see and things to explore.A few little gripes aside The Solus Project is an excellent adventure game that I enjoyed playing although I do feel that the game actually being a little bit shorter and more concise would have helped it in the long run.This written review was taken from our original video review which can be found:  Here	[www.thegametutor.co.uk]

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												Sluggish, slow, boring, overhyped and VERY buggy. Not even remotely fun. Especially annoying when savegames stop working or when you have to keep trying to work around the various bugs in the graphical interface and menu's. Not much freedom to explore at all. The "big" islands only let you walk along a fixed path and survival ingredients are always very conviently present at the right time when you need them most. Predictable as hell. This whole game is scripted and not dynamic.Gameplay is mostly about letting you walk around a room, a cave or small outdoor sector to solve a puzzle and trying to make the world look bigger than it actually is by making you have to walk from one corner of the sector to the other and back again to push buttons and levers and collect necessary items. This is not a big world, simply a lot of small sectors stitched together combined with a slow walking speed.The story and atmosphere are kind of okay but nothing to write home about either. I get the feeling this is supposed to be more like an "experience" than a game. The VR with an Oculus Rift is decent and very much recommended because I can't imagine me playing this game longer than 60 minutes if I didn't have a Rift. Even if you do like this game, it's probably a one time experience at best. It has very limited replayability as it's just a scripted story.To sum it up, the game just fails at almost everything it tries to achieve:Puzzles are too boring and easy and just included to keep the total gametime artificially long, action is non existent, story is nothing special, survival is a joke, the "big world" is a small world. Graphics are bland but okay, music is absent, sound is okay, game is buggy.I really wished this was more like the old Unreal game and then with a bigger procedurally generated world and with survival aspects. Unreal had good graphics, fast paced action, nice puzzles, an awesome atmosphere, fast pace story telling and very good music. Guess I was wrong about this one and fell for the hype surrounding it. It could have been a winner but I'll never play it again. Maybe nice for patient people with a lot of imagination but even those would have to agree it's not more to them than a 6 out of 10 as there are far better games than this one in the "puzzle genre". For anyone else, it's probably a 3 out of 10. Nice try, but no cigar.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								The Solus Project is an adventure-survival game with an interesting environment to explore. 


YouTube™ Video: The Solus Project - 60fps Gameplay & Review - A Sheepish Look At 

			Views: 2,324		

			Genna plays The Solus Project. An adventure-survival game with an interesting environment to explore. Click here to Subscribe ► http://bit.ly/mrwssub...		

Finally! A survival game with a more unique environment, and luckily for me the game isn't a full-on survival game.The story is that Earth was destroyed, and Earth's citizens are moved out into space temporarily. You play as humanity's last hope, looking for a habitable planet. Unfortunately, you crash land onto an alien world.The best thing about this game is the feeling of loneliness. The atmosphere is very strong. Interestingly enough, this is a spiritual successor to the game "The Ball". It shares the same universe and lore. It gives me similar vibes when it comes to finding interesting architecture. This game's environment is a joy to look at. The graphics look great, and the world is filled with interesting plantlife, rock formations and ruins.As you explore, you'll find interesting new objects, or random weather effects or situations can occur. Many times I was genuinely terrified, which is great. That's due to the immersion of this game.The crafting is quite simple. You can do stuff like combine one rock with another, to sharpen one of them. Using the sharp rock, you cut some dry roots, and then wrap that around a pipe, which you can then light on fire to create a torch. That particular combination might sound a bit complex, but the game makes it quite easy. There's quite a bit of managing your inventory and resources, as the world is harsh. You need to keep on your temperature, amount of sleep, calories and hydration. Overall, I'm having a lot of fun playing through, and can't wait to discover more of this interesting world.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												This is a really fun and immersive experience. I'm not a huge fan of survival style games, but this one kept me captivated with it's fantastic level design, interesting storyline, and really awesome world. The game's world reminds me a bit of Na Pali from Unreal 1, which is one of my favorites of all time. There were some pretty dark and scary elements, but no jump scares fortunately. Just good ol' suspense, playing on fear and expectation.I really enjoyed playing it in VR! If you have a Vive, I would put this on your list of things to play. Keep in mind, that the VR element is still in development. While I could teleport around at short distance, I used the sliding movement throughout the game. It took me a little bit to get used to, but it added to the experience once I did. I don't want to spoil the game, but there are parts that are really awe inspiring when you feel like you're standing right in front of them. It's worth it to me.My only criticism toward the game is the need for food and water. If you play the game on normal, you never really run out of supplies, as they're scattered all over. In the end the food/water mechanic kind of turns into a nanny meter that I need to fill every so often. If the the food and water meters have more of an impact on survival, (I.E. Stat boost or sickness) depending on how full/empty they are, it would add a really useful element. In my opinion, it currently does very little to impact of the game.So, that aside, if you're looking for an immersive adventure on a beautiful alien world, give this one a go. It was well worth the money.Please note: This review is based on my playthrough using the Vive/SteamVR. I only played the normal way (Desktop) to check my in game journal, which at the time of writing this I couldn't access it in VR. This game was designed for desktop play originally and VR was added in later.

												This is VR only feedback.  The issue motivating me to write is the controls in VR.  I love this type of game, with crafting and exploration.  THANK YOU for locomotion option!  Huge plus!  But PLEASE improve the control scheme overall.  Please, study Vivecraft controls for the java minecraft, they are amazingly well done.  If you implement vivecraft style controls for this you would knock it out of the park.  In this game it's difficult to do simple things that you can blaze through in minecraft.  (Left trigger locomotes you wherever your left controller is pointed.  Right trigger is action.  Right Thumbpad brings up menu.  Left thumbpad jumps.  In this case maybe squeeze buttons should be for droppping.  Also, some kind of visual feedback for combining needs to be implemented.  It's so confusing combining heavy rocks into sharp rocks. (pick this up, open menu, drop that, point that at that,, it's too much.  Just maybe make a simple box style combine.)  In VR, to put oil on a torch, just poke it into the oil (or make the + action menu come up when the objects interact.  Rework that system and I'll be ready to recommend this to everyone.  As it stands I was pretty close to a refund, but I know your VR support is still experimental.I like the world, the enviroment, and the setting.  Very cool to watch a night pass in VR and see the moon go by.
