content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												Speaking as a virtual reality user (sitting experience), I thoroughly enjoyed completing The Solus Project.  I could write more about how much I enjoy it than space allows, but others have done so in other reviews, so let me just reiterate their glowing recommendations:  if you are a fan of sci-fi mysteries, puzzles, and exploration, this game delivers in a format that is very worthy as a virtual reality experience.  The Solus Project also has elements of survival, but for the most part those can be effectively turned off through adjusting the difficulty settings.Some specific things I would like to call particular attention to are the VR movement method, and the graphics & performance as it relates to VR.  The movement is pretty comfortable for VR.  It took me about 6-10 hours of playing and taking periodic breaks to overcome the motion sickness of a walking simulator.  There is only one point at which camera control is taken away from you, and that is at the very end, so for the overwhelming majority of the time, head movement is 1:1 with yours.  In other words, it is very comfortable.  Additionally, there is a "camera snap" mode where you can use a game controller to "snap" your direction at 45 degree bearing intervals; this makes VR very comfortable, too.  A word on the controller: very intuitive, and I did not need the keyboard for anything except once or twice for console commands.  Side note: my save game was corrupted twice, but I was able to salvage the game with these commands  fly  and  solteleport 1 .  Secondly regarding movement, the game gives you a really fun teleport device.  After mastering it with various jumping, running and throwing techniques, you can potentially teleport several hundred feet.  Takes practice, though, but still very fun.Lastly, for a VR title, the graphics translated very well to the headset.  Typically in VR conversions, objects and textures pop in or can be blurry (try finding a tank on the ground in DCS World at 5-10 miles away), but the translation in Solus Project from a conventional monitor to first gen VR headset resolution is performed very well considering the hardware limitations.  Rendering was on an i5-4690k, 16gb RAM, and GTX 970.  Only once I had to tone down the graphics, and that was due to alot of stuff moving around at the time, but for the other 99% of the game, it was a solid 60 fps.So that's it.  Game play observations are available in other reviews, but if you want to know about the VR performance, then that is what this review was for.  Bottom line:  if you want to play this on the Vive or Rift, I don't think you will be disappointed.  A great game with a great VR implementation.  Have fun, and good luck!

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												HTC Vive review.Basically Prometheus meets The Martian. Except it's a full fleshed game and not another "experience".I was a bit confused by the gameplay and movement at first but make no mistake, this game is a grower. Once you'll get used to the controls you will be ready to begin a brilliant Sci-Fi aventure combining exploration, discovery and survival.The sense of presence and general atmosphere are amazing. You really feel like you're alone on this forsaken alien planet.As I was exploring this astonishingly well-crafted world I kept saying to myself "WOW", because thanks to VR I was THERE on the top of a giant tower looking at those 2 ominous moons hanging in the sky.Despite being focused on exploration, The Solus Project offers some cool survival aspects. The weather can be harsh (rain, thunder, extreme temperatures) but that's nothing compared to the tornadoes and the meteor showers trying to kill you occasionally. Another positive note is the sound. The effects are great and the music is top notch.I found the story quite engaging and I really recommend to everyone playing this to read all the lore infos on the stone tablets scattered across the world. It really helps to understand the ending.Technically speaking, the game ran just fine on low settings (except for textures resolution on medium) with super sampling set to 130 on my GTX 780Ti.My only problem is the same as every UE4 games in VR: that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ aliasing. It can really be annoying and it's a shame because The Solus Project is a gorgeous game.If you love adventure, good sci-fi and own a VR headset look no further. This is the game you're looking for.Congratulations to the team who made this. I really hope to play a sequel in the future.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												This game is outstanding! It is the BEST SURVIVAL GAME that I've ever played! Many other survival games fall short of excellence for one reason or another, but alas, it has been achieved! This isn't your typical game with enemies running around and fighting. This game is truly about survival. The only enemy you truly fight is the plethora of wild climate changes and climate anomalies, which will effect your health if you aren't careful. This means avoiding rain if possible, keeping cool on the hot days and warm at night, along with getting a proper rest. Sleeping is important, you must find a safe place to sleep as well. The music is great, the environment is stunning, and the game performance is excellent. Gameplay is fun and elegantly intricate with simple ways of achieving complex things (e.g. REALLLY easy to make a torch, etc.). I would recommend this game to anyone, because aside from the survival, there are tons of secrets to be found (which help you in your survival efforts). In my gameplay thus far, numerous awesome events have occurred, and I was immersed deeply in the gameplay the entire way through. This game is one of my new favorites, and I can't wait to get back to this planet to continue my survival, and my mission. I may be the last hope for those that remain out there, I must try to survive and make contact. Enjoy the game everyone! I am loving it, and I will keep my review updated as my story progresses.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
Product received for free
												I love The Solus Project. It takes a genre that has seen a lot of multiplayer games in the last couple of years and instead focuses on single player. Does it work? You bet your♥♥♥♥♥it does. You are the last hope of humanity and get stranded on an alien planet. But it's not as unhabitable as most planets, as you soon find out when checking out ruins of an ancient civilization. As The Solus Project is a survival game, there are hunger, thirst, body temperature and sleep to watch out for. You can check them by looking down, as that displays a PDA with a couple of usefull things. As the planet is quite uninhabitable, you also have to watch out for different weather conditions, which include rain, snow, meteor showers and even tornados. You might be surprised to hear there is no combat in the game. As such, the focus lies entirely on exploring the planet surface, delving into spooky caves and solving all kinds of puzzles (most with the help of a teleportation device you get early on). As such, the tempo is quite slow and might not be suitable for people, looking for constant action. However, if you can appreciate taking your time and checking all nooks and crannies, you will be rewarded with artifacts, which offer mainly stat increases. Exploration is certainly rewarded.The main thing I wanted to talk about are the graphics. The Solus Project looks absolutely gorgeous and up to par to the recent AAA titles. This is expecialy visible on the surface, where everything, including the weather and sky, is very detailed and a true gem to behold. Not bad for a 5 man indie development team. Despite all that, the performance is still good, even on some less powerfull graphic card. I've had no problems running it at 60FPS on almost ultra with a GTX 960 and a i3 4150.However, The Solus Project is still not without faults. The crafting system is quite basic and hunger and thirst aren't really that big of a problem, since you can find food and water almost everywhere. Another problem is (as I've mentioned) a slow pace, which can turn some people off buying the game. As for the VR, I didn't have the chance to test it, however from what I've read in the comments, it has a couple of problems (don't take my word there, rather read the experience of someone who played the game with VR).Conclusion:The Solus Project is a well developed and gorgeous game, which is avaliable for a quite low price of 15€. It's definately worth the price, however you should be aware that it is mostly a visual adventure. Don't expect slaughtering tons of alien creatures, because you will be dissapointed, if you're after that. Final Rating: 8.5/10

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												It takes a lot for me to enjoy a survival game: I find most either too punishing or downright frustrating. The Solus Project manages to be neither of those, while at the same time keeping your stress level just high enough that you never feel exactly safe. The game provides you beautiful vistas and a wonderful soundtrack to admire, but then rips you back into reality by reminding you that you are rarely ever safe. This combination of peaceful and stressful moments is perfectly balanced and creates an incredibly unique experience.I played the game through on my Rift and it is one of the most complete and polished VR games to exist at the moment. VR support is amazingly well done for being experimental. The game is downright gorgeous in VR, and all of the mechanics translate over well. The only qualm I have is that inventory management—scrolling in one direction through each inventory item individually—got annoying near the end, especially when you're dealing with extremes in temperature and really don't want to pull out your torch in a scorching hot environment.The gameplay is relatively simple while at the same time never feeling too easy. Your basic goals are to survive and keep moving forward: you have to maintain your basic vitals (body temperature, hydration, and nourishment) while moving into new areas, each one more deadly than the last. There's an old-school point-and-click feel in the mechanics, with much of your time spent searching for that one special item or finding ways to combine the items available to you. There are tons of secrets hidden off of the beaten path, and hunting them down while oftentimes risking your life is a lot of fun.The game's story is enthralling and plays itself out in both passive (pages from journals, tablets with carved language/images, one-way transmissions to your character) and active (interacting with alien lifeforms) ways. Despite being battered by the elements, I felt compelled to hunt down as many pieces of the story as I could to better understand the situation upon Gliese-6143-C. A few of the later transmissions you recieve are downright harrowing, with incredible voice acting bringing poignant feelings of isolation and desperation across.Near the end of the game I was legitimately sad that my time on Gliese-6143-C was coming to a close. I definitely have to say that I got my money's worth, and I really hope to see more games from these devs!

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												*HTC Vive Review*Obviously I just started the game (only two hours on record), but this game is so awesome in VR that I really had to write a review!You're stranded on a weird alien planet, not knowing what is going on here, what dangers await you, and with a vast, beautiful landscape to look at. Sounds awesome? It really is!I really love how dynamic the landscape appears to be and how dangerous this new environment feels - yes, nothing really jumps you (at least not that far in the game), but you certainly feel threatened. The atmosphere is really fantastic which it manages to uphold the whole time.VR controls:It's really great that you can adjust so many options - do you prefer to walk around yourself? There you go. Do you prefer teleporting around? There's also an option for that. The controls themselves are not perfect (not very intuitive), but after a while you certainly will get used to them.Overall I think this is one of the greatest experiences which I had so far on the HTC Vive and I'm really looking forward to continue the story!---------------EDIT: As of the 07.11.2016, I'm still very excited about this game and also stacked up some more gaming experiences:The developers overworked the VR controls and they are now really great - instead of scrolling though your whole inventory, you now can select the preferred item by looking at it in a big inventory screen. This works really well and is so much better than before!Also you are now able to press buttons on your device via your other vive controller, which makes for instance the whole sleep process much easier than before.Overall, this game is still one of the most rewarding and complete experiences I had so far for the HTC Vive.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
 A True AdventureI remember seeing The Solus Project first showcased at E3 2015.  I was immediately intrigued by the idea of playing as a sole survivor on an unknown alien planet.  Fast forwarded to February 2016.  A friend mentioned this neat new game that came out for early access.  Low and behold it was The Solus Project, released as the first episode.  I immediately bought it and began my adventure.  The game opens up with you, the seemingly sole survivor of a scout ship explosion in oribt above the planet known as Gliese 6143-C.  You find yourself in slight confusion as debris from your ship surrounds you and continues to fallf rom the sky.  But once you get your bearings, the adventure really begins. Your immediate goal  is to build a communication tower to get in contact with the rest of the Human fleet lying somewhere amongst the stars.  I was truly blown away by the world set before me.  Never have I been in an environment so alien, yet there exists elements that give it Earthly similarities.  This perfect balence reminded me that planets like this truly must exist somewhere out there.  Exotic looking beaches, massive rocky outcrops, and bizarre flora define Gliese 6143-C as truly alien.  For a time you feel as if Gliese is completely untouched, but soon you realize it was once inhabited by a race of humanoid beings.  Explore the ruins and stories left behind by these people and discover the secrets behind Gliese 6143-C.Perhaps one of the most interesting elments of The Solus Project is the lack of enemies.  Most of the game relies on you walking from point A to B, mostly unhindered by any physical antagonist.  However, something just as deadly surrounds you at all times--The environment.Yes, that's right.  The environment can and will kill you.  The planet will do what it can to make your adventure difficult.  The weather is caustic and unpredictable.  Daily temperatures can reach 115 degrees Farhenheit, then the next thing you know a brutal storm rolls in and you're running for your life from a violent tornado.Apart from surviving the elements, you must find food and water--Oh, and periodically find a safe place to sleep.  You will be required to plan carefully as to not blow through your supplies.  I highly recommend The Solus Project for anyone looking for a good story while still having a strong focus on survival.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												As played on a high rig PC.A pity this game's interface is such rubbish because it had the makings of something good, special even. But the muddled procedure you have to go through to combine items and 'craft' them is terrible. It took a while before I found I had to discard items and then find a different item from the inventory to modify the discarded one. So if you want to eat canned food you find a tin, discard it, perform clicks to open the can with a sharp rock, then pick up said can again and click to eat the content. Clumsy, barmy, inane. Whoever concocted this convoluted method must have had common sense lessons from a confused monkey that fell out of a tree while trying to learn the alphabet backwards.Graphically the game is pretty good and the scenario is sound enough, only in my view the implementation is awful. The inventory system needs an overhaul (well, trashing actually). Why not have a designated key for eating and drinking from items possessed, if not text options to click on? Simple. This is so basic and fundamental it's quite amazing how some folk like to complicate the mechanics of the simplest of tasks as if eating and drinking is a challenging riddle in itself. Despair. At the outset you have to exit from a small area. However, I decided jumping was the most logical means but there was an artifical barrier that stopped me from simply dropping a couple of feet over to the other side. Hmm, bad start, I thought and wasn't proved wrong. After wandering around the beaches for hours searching for numerous parts to build a comms rig I became tired of eating , drinking, being advised my suit was wet, etc etc, and decided to see 1/ How far I could scale the cliffs, and 2/ If I could swim to the other islands not too far out to sea. I managed to scale the cliffs with some effort while logically thinking that there must be ship debris up there to collect. But no, nothing whatsover despite the wreckage strewn on the beaches  below. An opportunity missed surely. Regarding swimming to the other islands, you can't because you hit an invisible barrier halfway there.Is this really open world? Well, yes, but in a restrictive sort of way. I think this game needs to be thought out more. For starters ditch the clumsy inventory interface and the continual reminders you're wet, thirsty, hungry, etc. Yawn... If this is a survival game let's have options to turn off the hand-holding. On that note I am personally sick of the Simple Simon approach to most game designs these days as if evey player has an IQ lower than a gorilla with dementia.The game promised a lot but there needs to be more freedom and intelligent structure. It needs a better user experience even at budget price. Work in progress I guess but 8/10 for effort and visuals.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												After a buggy start, a patch was forthcoming and my woes were cured. i started the game again and played it through in a DK2. The vista's are awe inspiring, the game play is challenging, the puzzles are well thought out. But the thing that stays with me was the last island... when i approached the massive building there were tornados everywhere, they sweep right past you and lift you off your feet. It was the most immersive a game has ever been, i was wiping my head to get the rain off me! its probably one of the most impressive things i have seen in VR so far! Its one of those games i remember as an actual memory rather than a playthrough. VR can do that to you if its done right and these guys did it! It has its issues, some of the paths are not very clear and you might stumble about looking for certain items to progress for an overly long time.. but since you are actually in the world, thats forgiveble as soon as you look up and see the sky or the massive statues or any number of other eye candies. It ran very well on the DK2 with a sub par machine on high settings. i ran it on medium in the end as some bits were taxing but thats purely my rig. Overall it did very well. I give it 8/10 (it loses 1 point for the ending being totally illogical and 1 point for slightly hard to read PDA in oculus.. both fixable) i wont elaborate on the ending as i dont want to spoil anything. Definitely worth the cash to play in VR. I cant comment on how engrossing it is on a monitor as i didn't try it that way, it seemed pointless after experiencing it rather than playing it. Very nice game. well done!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												The Solus Project takes a rather simple concept of exploration and survival and wraps a fascinating story around it. Obviously it's not as polished as some triple A titles, but you can tell a lot of care went into the game. The music, art design, and gameplay are really all flawless. There's a little less action in this than say DOOM, but some of us like taking it slower and exploring rather than blasting away.The story itself is what draws you in to this game and will have you addicted to finding one clue after another. While it is a pretty great story overall there are a few speedbumps. There are some horror elements which I wasn't really looking for and they use some very cliche scares. That said, they're so cliche they can almost be overlooked. There are some plotholes that don't quite get resolved in any meaningful way, left open for you to interpret as you like. That was the developers intent though, not an accident, and for that I actually give them credit of really pulling it off well. They draw on a lot of rather obvious other sources for some great ideas, games like Tomb Raider and Half Life, stories like The Martian and Lost. They're brought together quite neatly and I was not at all disappointed in the ending.Overall a great game to get on sale.

The vista's are awe inspiring, the game play is challenging, the puzzles are well thought out. But the thing that stays with me was the last island... when i approached the massive building there were tornados everywhere, they sweep right past you and lift you off your feet. It was the most immersive a game has ever been, i was wiping my head to get the rain off me! its probably one of the most impressive things i have seen in VR so far! Its one of those games i remember as an actual memory rather than a playthrough. VR can do that to you if its done right and these guys did it! It has its issues, some of the paths are not very clear and you might stumble about looking for certain items to progress for an overly long time.. but since you are actually in the world, thats forgiveble as soon as you look up and see the sky or the massive statues or any number of other eye candies. It ran very well on the DK2 with a sub par machine on high settings. i ran it on medium in the end as some bits were taxing but thats purely my rig. Overall it did very well. I give it 8/10 (it loses 1 point for the ending being totally illogical and 1 point for slightly hard to read PDA in oculus.. both fixable) i wont elaborate on the ending as i dont want to spoil anything. Definitely worth the cash to play in VR. I cant comment on how engrossing it is on a monitor as i didn't try it that way, it seemed pointless after experiencing it rather than playing it. Very nice game. well done!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												"You dawg, I heard you like secrets so I secreted a secret into your secret."A survival genre game with a definite classic adventure game feel where the thrills are 100% exploration. The Solus Project's high quality aestetics and richly drawn storyline are a welcome change after playing a string of unpolished Early Access survival games, There is zero base-building or environmental alteration. But you do feel a sense of home in a cave or piece of wreckage that you cache found supplies in that you repeatedly use as shelter for a few nights before moving on. This sense of home is more vibrant than a home base you made yourself. When the environment offers you shelter, it has a sense of being a nurturing Other rather than a constructed base that is an extension of Self. It's hard to explain but it is art at its best.Likewise, the story is 'discovered' as you explore in the form of found ship's logs and ruins rather than being thrust upon you via scripted events, quests, or NPC dialogue. This creates suspense in the same way as characters in a scary movie wandering a creepy basement stumble upon a cursed book.  It makes the player feel as though they are accompanying their character on the adventure rather than in other games where you control and direct the character in a procedural sandbox.Just an exquite game that slowly reveals its many secrets at a delicious pace that allows you to savor the plot as your capacity to survive allows you to explore the world around you more fully before you seek shelter in a storm or at nightfall.A must-buy for any fan of sandbox survival games who have forgotten how satisfying a constructed survival game can be when you aren't distracted by sand castle building in a meaningless procedural world (and I love games like that).

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Absolutely brilliant in VR! The environments are very unique and incredibly rendered, and is probably the most immersive game I've ever played, especially while in VR.It has a fantastic story subtly laid out through visual storytelling in the details of the setting, greatly boosted by great use of VR and interactions with the environment. Solus reminds me a lot of other titles that have excelled in this area like Metroid Prime and the Dark Souls series. The gameplay is exploration focused, with some survival mechanics thrown in for good measure (don't worry if you aren't into survival sims; those types of games don't really hold my interest, and it's a relatively small part of the title outside of managing your character's temperature, hunger, and thirst, which are done very well in a non-obtrusive way that only adds a greater immersion.) The most interesting mechanic is the teleportation disc, which is a lot of fun once you get a hang of the physics behind it and get through some great "AHA" moments with some teleporation based puzzle solving. Think Portal with frisbees, and you're most of the way there.You'll be exploring fascinating underground ruins and architecture as well as the unique landscapes, and have to survive disastrous conditions, like waking up in the open with a tornado coming your way, or intense thunder storms or heat waves, to name a few of the interesting dynamic obstacles. To say much more would spoil some of the best parts of the game. There some great surprises here :)I do have to say that I can't recommend playing this in VR if you are easily frightened, because there are some very intense moments, to the point where I'd say it outshines most modern horror titles with some truly terror inducing scenarios and suffocating atmosphere at times, especially with how immersive this game can be in VR. But if you can handle these stretches, or enjoy horror, you'll have a blast!I can't recommend Solus Project enough for anyone who loves games with a great setting and a drive to explore.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												Where to begin... I played through this within 2 days, 12 hours in total. Needless to say I binged it, because it had me hooked. I played in VR with my Oculus Rift and gamepad.The setup seems quite simple, crashed on an alien planet with survival elements. However it reveals to be quite a neat narrative driven game with lots of exploration. Some survival elements like hunger and thirst didn't seem that hard to satisfy (the levels are littered with food and water), but maintaining body temperature gets interesting in some places.Exploration is the core of its appeal and, especially in VR, there are some crazy, ominous, beautiful and terrifying sights to behold in this game. It's perfect  for people that like to immerse themselves in virtual worlds. It gives a glimpse of what future big-budget VR gaming will hopefully deliver more of.On the VR side of things, it's very much a VR adaption, not a core VR game. It is a pretty good adaption but you'll need your VR legs. I recommend playing seated with a gamepad.I did find some bugs and sequence breaks along the way (it felt like I managed to shoot teleporter pads much further than intended), but generally things are pretty solid. Do play with async reprojection (at the time of writing in the SteamVR beta) or Oculus' ATW, since performance can dive under 90 fps in places.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												An amazing game - possibly my favourite game of all time.  If you're an SF fan, and ever imagined living on a distant planet, this is for you!  This is probably about as close as you will get to "The Martian" film as a video game.  After crashing, you are thrown in at the deep end, and must learn to surive before the harsh environment of this alien world kills you.  You must find food, water, shelter & tools, while dealing with temperatures that fluctuate wildly over the day & night, and violent rapidly-changing weather.  And just when you think you're managing to surive, the story takes some unexpected turns (you might not be alone...), which will see you travelling to new places, all the while struggling to survive.  These continually provide you with new challenges, so you never get bored (nor find things getting too easy).And despite being created by "indie" developers, this is a HUGE game, with massive sprawling areas, and tons of gameplay.  And the graphics are amazingly beautiful, while the sounds fit very well.  It's taken me upto 33 hours to finish (probably less due to Steam counting time paused).  (No doubt you could rush through it, and maybe finish it in half the time, but then I think you'd miss half the stuff & have half the fun.)But if you are looking for a first-person shooter (where you kill lots of aliens), or a horror game to scare you, then please look elsewhere!  This game is about exploration & the struggle for survival on an alien world, with a story & several mysteries that you gradually uncover.  There are definitely horror elements (especially later in the game), but it's not the central focus of the game.On the down side, while the major plot points are voiced, much of the smaller parts of the story are told through tons of short bits of text scattered everywhere, which you can find & read.  I'm not a fan of this kind of story telling in games, and even though time slows down while you read them, time does still pass (especially as the text appears gradually), so it's harder to survive if you spend time reading them!  What I now do is glance at the bits of text, which stores it in my "Journal", and then occasionally pause the game & read them from my Journal instead.  At the very least the game ought to completely pause while you read the text.  And I'd have preferred less individual bits of text to read (it's not essential but you will miss-out on the background story of how things ended-up as they are... which will mean you won't fully understand the ending of the game).Another down side is that the game's performance can drop very badly after playing it for a few hours, almost as if it is running out of memory (due to a memory leak).  Quitting & restarting the game will fix that.Apart from that, the game feels VERY polished.  They must have play-tested it heavily, because although challenging, it's almost impossible to be completely lost or overlook something important.  (Despite it's huge sprawling areas & freedom to do whatever you want.)I highly recommend buying this game, even at full price.  It's massive value-for-money.  Just don't expect tons of voice acting...  Nor an ending that doesn't leave itself open to a sequel!

content:
Posted: January 29
												The games' trailer got me hyped, and the gameplay didn't let me down!I can just downright recommend this game. I got immediately hooked by the trailer videos and got the game shortly afterwards.The game places you as a lone survivor of an expedition searching for a new homeworld for humanity. You must learn how to survive and slowly unravel the secrets of the archipelago you find yourself stranded on.The atmosphere always manages to be somewhat eerie und at times, can scare the heck out of you. At one point, the game sent an unexpected, ice-cold shiver down my spine!Important parts of the story are told by your character, however, I highly recommend you always keep an eye out for readable objects in-game since they add a lot to the story. The story itself is nicely told as it slowly but steadily walks you through the events that took place on the islands before you can finally communicate back home.Survival definetely has its place in the game. The environment is hostile and you have to plan carefully to avoid hazards. At the same time, exploring also is a big part of the game. There are lots of challenge rooms and secrets to be found that can also provide perks for your character, helping you to survive.Overall, I can say I really enjoyed The Solus Project. If you like science-fiction adventures with survival and riddle elements, along with a really scary atmosphere, then this game is definetely for you!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Solus project catched my eye when I was looking for a single player space-themed survival game. I do not recall anymore when I saw the forst video clips of it (or heard any news of it), but nevertheless I had been following its stream for a while thinking whether this would be the game satisfying my futuristic survival needs.I finally decided to go for it and boy it did not let me down. Somehow the atmosphere in Solus really makes you think you are alone and you HAVE TO survive. The goals drive you towards nicely, leave room for exploration and there is no dull moment during the journey. Let me rephrase dull here: this is 100% single player survival. You do not meet pals, you do not talk to npcs, etc. By definition that means "dull" but in this context its completely the opposite. I just loved every single hour I spend with the Solus Project leaving no rocks turned trying to solve how do I get out of the planet. Take a word of notice, if you are not willing to spend time thinking, digging and studying Solus you will miss a lot. This is not a fast paced fps mmorpg, do not expect it to be one. This is you, alone on a alien planet. Surviving. At all costs.Highly recommended! <3

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												I don't know what to say about this... but I loved this game!  The story, from beginning to end (especially the ending) had me feeling in a way in which very few games have.  I have to say that this game was well worth the price.  Now for the pros and cons.The biggest strength of this game, for me at least, was they story and feeling of suspence.  Learning bits and pieces of what was going on on the planet and what had happened.  I kept finding myself lost in reading the tablets and diagrams of the planet's previous inhabitants.  The artwork is, without a doubt, beautiful... I would end up taking numberous screenshots of the landscape or architecture (more than I usually would from most other games)  Another thing is the survival aspect.  I love survival based games, especially survival horror, where you have to deal with limited resources and limited inventory.  You have to plan ahead or else have a difficult time surviving or dying.Now for the downsides.  The constant alerting of your character's survial device (PDA?) got on my nerves, constantly say "Operator Wet" "Operator Cold" "Operator Tired" over and over and over within a minute of saying it. I don't mind reminders,  but so frequently, it was annoying.  Another things was trying to collect the radio parts.. you have to bascially scavange real hard to find them and you can't miss one or else you'll have to retrace your steps. I missed one piece and spent near 3 hours running around to figure out which island I'd left it on.  Maybe a... better homing signal or something?That's really all I could think of. There were a few minor irriations... but overall, they can be gotten around. If improved with an update... that'd be awesome and make the game that much better.  So my conclusion is that this game is one of the best I've played.  I'd highly recommend this to anyone who likes survival, horror, mystery, and exploration type games.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10
												Ho-Lee-CARP! Where to start?First off, let me first state that I love Survival-esque games. I've put many upon many hours in ARK: Survival Evolved and quite a few in Conan Exiles so far. There are others too, but those two were my more recent favorites. However, those types of games are better played in groups! And since my friends rarely - if ever - tend to stick to a game long enough to play, or are rarely on at the same times as me, I was thrilled to find Solus Project listed as a Single-Player Survival Game.To be fair, as of yet I haven't fully completed the game. Basically, I play a section, then watch a few play-thrus up to the point I'm at and judging by the amount of videos remaining I'd say I'm only about a fifth of the way through the game. However, so far I've been overcome with Awe and Inspiration! Love and Adoration! And also Fear and Conflict!The visuals are absolutely breathtaking! I could stand at the beginning and just take screenshot after screenshot and have an entire library of amazing landscapes that will leave everyone in my household "Ooooh"ing and "Aaawww"ing all week long! The attention to detail, the perfection in the way the grass and the trees sway in the wind. The way the water laps on the shore. The way the meteors, falling/shooting stars, Tornados and rainstorms seem so real!! The developers knew exactly what they were doing when making this visually appealing and so lifelike!Their time and dedication in placing just the right dabble of lore and history to keep me looking and exploring for more was absolutely perfect! There's always something to look at, something to draw your attention, something to keep you guessing and eager to learn more! They have the small subtle nods to keep you on track, of course. The PDA does good to remind you every once in a while what your main objective is without being too obstructive. But there's always that gnawing alure of, "Where does that hallway go?" "Where did this cable come from?" "What's that glowing thing over there?!"And the music is not only downright beautiful to listen to (this very well might be the only game I actually consider buying the soundtrack from) but it helps immerse you so fully into the game that you sometimes forget you're playing and truly feel a part of what's actually happening! It blends so wonderfully that I had begun to notice that it was swaying my emotions with its rhythm! In soft chiming whispers, I was left in awe at the scenery. In the more somber and sad tunes, I had moments of helplessness where I thought for sure I was either facing inevitable and lonely/slow death (by freezing, starving or injury) or just going to succumb to the depression of truly being alone. And then there were times where the music would slowly and subtly rise and I'd find myself near the point of crying and running away before ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ myself in fear!To be fair, I scare easily. I can't watch zombie movies without having nightmares for weeks! And even though this game is - for the vast majority of it thus far - practically harmless, I've had a few moments of sheer dread! I had moments where things would happen, the music would swell and send shivers all up and down my spine, my heart would start pounding, my breath would shorten and I literally paused the game in a panic, sing the "NOPE!" song and had to walk away to calm down. I even considered trying to talk my husband into finishing that section for me because of all the NOPES! I gave!I managed to get through it! And so far, I haven't had any nightmares from it yet (I'm betting I still will) but that's just the impact I've gotten so far. To have gone through all that and STILL want to keep playing! STILL wanting to continue the story and find out if I will survive despite the possibility of losing so much sleep:You know it's gotta be a damn good game.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												The Solus Project is a first person exploration and survival game, set in the distant future, after Earth has been destroyed. The last Human survivors are aboard a deep space colony ship, and the player is one of several scouts who have been sent out in search of a planet capable of sustaining life. After crash landing on your assigned planet, your goal is to stay alive long enough to repair a communication tower, and report back to the colony.As you explore the planet, you need to keep an eye on hunger, thirst and exhaustion meters. Fortunately there's plenty of food and water to be found, and you have a large inventory capacity, so running out is never really a problem. You can sleep almost anywhere which also restores health. The biggest danger comes from the environment, especially when you're on the planet surface, which is rarely a safe place to be. At night the temperature is freezing, and if you become wet because of rain or swimming through deep water, you can quickly die from hypothermia. Meanwhile, during the day, some areas are really hot, which can lead to death from heatstroke. You'll also occasionally encounter extreme weather anomalies such as tornados, lightning storms and meteor showers. When you venture underground, you'll find many hazards such as spike traps, land mines, killer plants, ice caves, acid lakes and boiling lava.The developers have done a really great job of creating a planet that truly feels alien. As you explore deeper, you'll begin to uncover the ruins of an ancient civilization. You'll find massive buildings and machines, and historical records written in a strange language. And without wanting to spoil too much, you're not alone on this planet. There isn't any combat as such, you don't get any weapons, but there are things down there that want to kill you. I had one particular encounter in a very dark area that genuinely freaked me out a little.You can find or craft objects to help you survive, such as torches to see in the dark or crystals to increase or decrease your temperature. There are hidden artefacts that buff your resistances to negative status effects. And you also get a teleportation device, which functions kind of like the old Unreal Tournament translocator, and can help you reach higher ledges or avoid hazards. The game is let down slightly by a poor user interface and inventory system, which has several flaws. For example, when I was trying to collect some dried roots to combine with a lead pipe to craft a torch, the first thing you need to do is use something sharp to cut the roots down. I had two different sharp objects in my inventory, so the game popped up another menu to ask me which item to use, when it makes no difference. Having crafted my torch, I wanted to collect some more roots to keep in my inventory for future use. But when I tried to pick them up, the only interaction option I had was to set them on fire with the torch I'd just made. I had to drop my torch first, pick up the roots, then pick up the torch. Later, when my torch expired, I found out you can't combine two items in your inventory. I had to drop the roots on the ground, and then interact with it to combine with my pipe to make a new torch. Sure, none of this is game breaking, but its annoying, especially when you consider that there are lots of things to craft, so you'll spend a lot of time dealing with this crap.I also find it strange that a society that has technology capable of travelling to distant planets, and a PDA capable of tracking life signs in real time and translating alien languages, doesn't have any way of recording map data. Okay, there are waypoints on the HUD to guide you through the main quest. But when I'm trying to thoroughly search the area for those artefacts and other secrets, sometimes its difficult to know which areas haven't been explored yet.My final little complaint is that, whilst keys are rebindable, the game won't recognise my mouse thumb buttons, or mousewheel click. On a more positive note, I didn't encounter any bugs, and the music is fantastic, really intense and dramatic, especially when you're in danger. There isn't a lot of voice acting, but those small parts have a decent quality.Overall, The Solus Project is a really interesting experience, which I give a strong recommendation for. Its a kind of sequel to the developer's previous game, The Ball, and although it expands on some of the story, you don't really need to have played The Ball to enjoy The Solus Project. (The Ball is also a pretty good game though, which is worth checking out). It took me 12 hours to finish, so the standard purchase price is fairly good value for money.

												I like pretty much all about this game. It's a mix of exploration and non-horror survival game. There are a few quite scary moments during the game play, but not so much. I don't like horror, so it was good to find a survival game without it. As an exploration game there are some puzzles to be solved as well, but not to the extend I'd call it a puzzle game. If you like you can just follow the story, as I did, or you can do a lot of exploration and discover secret areas.The story, the ambient soundtrack, the pretty graphics and the challenges. number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												I have to say that I really enjoyed this game. The gameplay is well-balanced and the difficulty level is completely customizable.I really thought that the survival mechanics paired with the planet's weather patterns made for a rich and rewarding experience. Also while not on the surface, a somewhat maze-like puzzle experience awaits you (no complex puzzles though, you mostly just wander through the maze and challenging environment to find switches).There are a large number of secrets in this game to add extra challenge/exploration/rewards if you wish, but they are optional.The story is left to discovery by the player. There are fragments of notes and such left throughout the levels, and the story is somewhat left to personal interpretation.There are no "fights" to speak of, but there are occasions where you may need to stealth past or run past certain "enemies". The times when you are trying to escape an anomaly are well-done and appropriately intense, but these are interspersed between periods of less-intense play so as to not give you PTSD.TL;DR: A great sci-fi adventure-survival game, well worth the price I paid of $20 USD. Not intense but not boring either; a well-balanced and thought-provoking challenge in the genre.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												This is currently one of my favorite VR games. I know originally it wasn't designed for VR, but it does it quite well. There has been a few times where I just sit down on the beach in awe and stare at how beautiful the sky is.  I have not finished this game yet, and that is a great thing. Most VR experiences are short. This is a long play through, it has some puzzle elements. Some people say this is a walking simulator. That’s fine with me; it sure is a hell of a one. I sometime feel like I’m on an episode of Star Trek, or in the Aliens movie.  While they continue to improve on the VR controls, my only complaint is the horrible inventory selection system. Having to click through each item is not fun, and when you miss it, you have to go around the bend/wheel again. Not a big deal in the beginning, but when you get further in and have collected a lot more stuff, it gets frustrating.  I really enjoy the atmosphere, and there are some chilling moments to be hand in the game.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												First, let me tell u I have a Vive, and I have only played this game through it.The Solus Project is a probably the best representation of a full, polished vr game. The movement mechanics work well and the addition of teleportation to locomotion is something many games lack, as locomotion can often make people empty their lunch, everywhere. (Not I but I know a few people who do get that.) The game capitalizes on the awe of vr using beautiful landscapes and incredible structures.Problems arise in that the survival elements are limited, it basically consists of keep food and water with you, and a light/heat source. If you are expecting an Ark like survival experience, just know that while survival is a key element in this it is quite limited in content.Instead of a mainly survival game, you get an exploration game with a few survival elements, the game is almost entirely exploration driven and it is fun for a while, and then sometimes boring, and then fun again. There really isn't any settling down and trying to build up a nice camp, it's just walk, walk, walk.Lastly, the game has a horror aspect, if you're in a cave, you may here screaming and intense music. Some of the noises are puzzling, like hearing a human scream can really throw you off. It doesn't really fit. The scariest parts of the game are not when it is trying to scare you, but when it is not, when everything is still and for a brief moment you believe you really are a person, hopelessly stranded on a distant world, alone, and doomed to die that way. That there is what makes this game so good.I'd give the game a 7/10. It still is the most complete game on the market and will probably be so for a while. It's worth $20 for sure. So go buy it.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2016
												Ever wonder what it would be like to survive a spaceship crash and embark on a Giorgio A. Tsoukalos mystery investigation? Well look no further than the Solus Project. This fairly lengthly narrative driven surival game takes the normally (to me at least) dull eat food, drink water, don't freeze to death mechanics of a surive in the woods game and combines them with a puzzle exploration openish? world of neat rocks n' things.To me this game was well worth it's not too steep price, and was definitely something I would consider an enjoyable experience, despite the game itself not having much going for it other than a spectacular atmosphere. Even knowing that 90% of the time I was completely safe, as stated in the description there's no real enemies, the atmosphere created such a wonderful feeling of anxiety and nigh terror that I would still tense at every random background ambience noise.A solid game, worth picking up if you just want a chill game to play looking at some neat things. The only drawbacks are that the game is fairly easy, even the survival elements are most of the time fairly trivial unless you drop all your food and forget to pick it back up (which I only did once) as there's a pretty consistently spaced supply of unlimited food and water. So don't pick this up if you are looking for a challenge, but otherwise I'd recommend it.Overall rating: 8/10

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												Phenomenal! I haven't completed the game yet, but i'm extremely impressed with the obvious amount of work the devs have put into this game. Story is great, should be a book written so we could read and get even more details that we may have missed in the game. Great imagination went into this game, even a little humor.I've been playing this in the Vive on medium difficulty. I have been terrified, awestruck, elated, captivated, happy, sad, exhilarated, and have experienced many emotions while experiencing this VR survival on another planet.This game is well worth more than just the $20 they have been charging. I wish these devs would have been the ones to make the Everest Experience.By the way, there are a few very minor glitches with this game in the Vive, but they are so minor that they don't really even effect the game or gameplay. The biggest glitch I found for Vive gameplay was when I was at this ladder that I was supposed to go way way way down, but the top of the ladder had no white lit up ladder that Vive players or supposed to teleport onto, I finally just took the risk and used the Vive touchpad to walk forward off the edge where the ladder is, hoping I wouldn't just fall to my death, but somehow instead of falling I ended up walking down the ladder.At the end of this same ladder, I kept walking to see if that is how to get off the ladder, but all of a sudden at the last step, I fell off and died. I tried the ladder again, but this next time once I was almost to the bottom of the ladder, I used the Teleport device to get onto the ground safely, but make sure the Teleport disk does not land on the white lit ladder at the bottom of the main ladder or you might end up in an infinite loop like happened to me once.Sorry for the rambling, I highly recommend this game, best when played sitting though, because the head height didn't match my real height, I felt like I was 7 feet tall in the game when I stood, but sitting down worked out great the whole game through so far.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2016
												The Solus Project is an atmospheric exploration and puzzle solving survival game. It's package provides both VR-enabled and normal gameplay experience.The sole survivor of an event whereby your spacecraft was destroyed, you awake on an alien world. It's up to you to work out the whys and wherefores as you explore your seemingly uninhabited surroundings. Collecting resources, making tools, gathering food...all of this and more is required to keep you upright and breathing. Occasionally an overhead relay satelite will align with your communication device and for all too brief moments you'll be able to hear your mothership trying to contact you. Unfortunately your personal communicator lacks the power to answer...Technically TSP is an Unreal Engine game. On my, admittedly beastly, PC it runs with no graphical issues at 4K although levels take a noticably long time to load. Not too sure what that's about but once loaded all is fine.I personally enjoy playing the game. There is some handholding regarding where to go and what to do, but certainly nothing of the sort when it comes to working out or solving the puzzles. The story is interesting, the world is huge and the environments, levels if you will, are clearly lovingly designed. I give it 7.5/10.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								I REALLY enjoyed the first three levels of this EA game!  Beautiful alien world with a hint of Egypt in the tombs.  I spent quite a while in the game, but towards the end I just headed for the ending, as opposed to searching every corner.  But now I want to replay with a greater attention to detail.  I do think there is room for more thrills (such as giant balls or other objects rolling/sliding down stairs behind you, or directed-falling as seen in Tomb Raider 2013, for example, and more to see or do in the caves and tombs).  Wonderful atmosphere, and story, with the music, sound and weather effects topping it off. At the end of the initial first three levels, I find I'm tiring of the caves and tombs, and hope more outdoor areas are soon to be discovered.  Of course a few minor bugs along the way, but nothing you wouldn't expect at this point, and definitely not game-breakers.With a touch more WOW-factor in the caves and tombs, this seems like it could end up being a classic of the genre.  I wouldn't mind seeing a few ideas "inspired" by Mind: Path to Thalamus, such as in seeing clearer pathes through reflections, etc., and maybe a few more puzzles.  But overall, this is a gem, in my mind!  Can't wait to see more!!!8.5/10

												Ate goop from cave. Gained 1000 calories. Would eat goop from cave again. 10/10Tl;dr: If you are wondering whether to buy for $20 and you have a Vive - YES. number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												I'm not a particularly huge fan of survival games, but I love a good mystery and adventure and this appeared to be a good mix of elements. I had no idea what to expect when I started this, and hadn't heard of it until it released, and I have to say I am really impressed and fully recommend this game, it is well worth the full price. More specifics are below.Edit: Added computer specs, approximate performance and fixed some typos. Technical Points Graphical Fidelity is great. It isn't the prettiest game out there but is has its own style and feel and it is well fleshed out. Game performs well on midtier hardware.Audio quality is top notch. The sounds are high quality, the music is intertwined with cues and ambience, creating very moody atmospheres, creepy and foreboding moments and refreshing and calm periods. Caves sound like caves, storms sound like storms. You will learn the various audio cues for different things, be it threats, weather, puzzle completion or secret discovery. I cannot overstate just how well the audio matches up to every moment in the game.Options are plentiful and includes resolution scaling (supersampling). Difficulty is a slider and I assume adjusts rates of hunger and thirst and frequency of weather events and such things. Borderless Fullscreen Windowed Mode is supported but as of this writing isn't an option in the options screen but can be set in a config file, hopefully this will be made selectable in game.Exploration is just as much a part of the game as survival. Level of involvement is largely in your control. Many secret areas exist and offer additional lore bits, but you are fully free to ignore those and only focus on the storyline. Exploration does tend to better prepare you, and exploration never goes unrewarded.Will have VR support eventually. VR support is present but is still very 'work-in-progress' as of this writing. Beyond this I cannot comment as I do not own any VR hardware. More Subjective / Philosophical Points Narrative and Story design is phenomenal. I was very engaged with the game, and as I progressed I only found myself wanting to know more and more importantly discover more. I think this is an excellent example of game writing that does much more showing than telling. You see your environment, you discover things, some lore bits scattered throughout the world are picture based only, and hint at various dangers or terrain that you might later face. Very little dialogue exists, and the physical world gives you just as much information as your one basic forward objective does, if not more. There is a mystery to unravel, but at the same time the game does not reveal everything. Space is given for interpretation and speculation, and maintains mysteriousness and creepiness of the game from start to finish.The game does not hold your hand. There is almost always a forward vector that gives you a very general direction, but exactly how you get there is never explicit. Weather is unpredictable when you are outside, and your journey requires you to survive. The planet you are on is not nice. The game is fair, however. There are plenty of resources scattered about, and sleeping also saves the game. Most arduous areas usually have a save and camp spot before them, so that you have the opportunity to mostly focus on what you're doing, at least for a little while.Level design is incredible and uses the environments to their full extent. Some areas become accessible later, and even backtracking through some areas later in the game will reveal something new or changed. Things you do have an impact as areas that were blocked off early on will be accesible after you do things in the story. All areas as far as I know can be gotten back to, with some travelling if you're up to it. There is no map in the game, but this is made up for with some subtle and some not so subtle landmarking. Areas have literal milestones that will tell you about how far you are through a particular area. Other things can also mark areas, such as markings or arrangements on the ground, to simple stacks of rocks in caves.The game is excellent at evoking real creep. There aren't really any directly malicious threats in the game, but the game does a great job of making you feel otherwise. Some areas I was hesitant to enter, or was hesitant to activate some mechanism just because I was somewhat afraid of something happening that might not be pleasant. Computer Info i5-4670K Stock Clock/Boost, Hyper 212 EvoMSI Gaming GeForce GTX 970 (OC'd 150 MHz)2x8 GB Corsair Vengeance DDR3 RAMMSI Gaming Z87-G45 MoboWindows 10OCZ Vertex 4 and Samsung 850 Evo SSDsAverage 60+ FPS in all areas with max settings in Borderless Fullscreen Windowed Mode, as well as up to 140% render scaling (supersampling). A couple of areas with many light sources may drop below 60 FPS with above 120% render scaling. 1920x1200 Native monitor resolution.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												Good: For the first few minutes you play this game you think it's really going to be amazing. You've got a standard survival scenario and a set of interesting-looking islands to explore ... the sound effects and music are good, the graphics are good, it's very promising.Bad: Then you quickly realize that what you're actually going to do is explore a set of very linear caves, occasionally puncuated by a stone tablet or obelisk in an alien language that your PDA will translate for you, and maybe a button-and-lever puzzle or some variant on that. And that's all you're going to do.I like adventure/story games. I like exploration/open world games. I even like survival games, if they're not too frustrating. This game would probably be pretty good if the people who made it had concentrated on one or even two of those things. But they seem to be determined to do all three at once, and they do a horrible job of it.Imagine if the devs had concentrated on story and puzzles and just made this a really good cave-crawl mystery. Or imagine if it was purely an "explore, get resources, try to build what you need to get rescued" game. Either of those would have been better than this. The story's not compelling enough and the puzzles not interesting enough for this to make a good adventure game; the exploration aspects are just "look for secrets"; the survival aspects mostly involve your PDA nagging you to sleep what feels like every five minutes.This is doubly disappointing given that The Ball had puzzles which were actually novel and interesting. The Ball was fun to play even when I had to cheat (usually because I got tired of doing the same jumping puzzle twenty times when it was impossible to aim jumps accurately).With this game, the first time I encountered an enemy in the game who could actually kill me (in the Hallways of Darkness), I stopped and tried to decide whether it was worth figuring out how to get past it. Then I tried to decide whether it was worth it to turn on cheats and use those to get past it. Finally I realized that I wasn't interested enough in what was going on in the game to care any more.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
Early Access Review
~Key provided by developer/publisher. This does not affect my review.~


The Solus Project 
A Screenshot of The Solus Project
By: Snowfox




Tags: Early Access, Adventure, Survival, Indie, Sci-Fi, Simulation, Exploration, First-Person, Story Rich, Singleplayer, Survival HorrorIntroductionYou play as a lone survivor of a crashed ship on a strange (and for the most part uninhabited) alien planet.  Tasked with finding a way get back home, you will face harsh environments and uncover timely mysteries.OverviewIf you want a casual atmospheric survival game set in space, look no further! This is one of the most beautiful and immersive games I have played in quite some time. While it’s no sandbox like some others with similar concepts, what The Solus Project has to offer is quite interesting. The levels are crafted even to the smallest detail, focusing on a more linear approach instead of sandbox survival. Don’t be fooled though, hidden within these levels are multitudes of secrets waiting to be found. The crafting system is not too complex but was detailed enough to keep me interested. Things you find on the islands can be combined, for example, you use two rocks to make a sharp rock and use that sharp rock on a closed can of food to open it. Recourses are scarce, so be careful what you do (I accidentally burned some important material by using a torch on it…. oops)The environment is very complex and includes all sorts of weather; scorching heat, tornadoes, storms, and even meteors. This is without a doubt the best feature that this game has to offer in my opinion. Another detailed part of the Solus Project is the in-depth day/night cycle. Every detail is there: temperatures, winds, humidity, and cloud coverage.  Very unforgiving: a single mistake can get you killed. This game is in early access at the time I write this review, and content is being added regularly by active devs. I only found a few problems with the game: The running sometimes glitches (and movement in general is a little awkward) and Saves are not working properly for me (I’m not sure when the game saves and when it does. I thought I saved at a shrine, only to find myself back at the starting area when I started up again.)SummaryOverall, I recommend that you give this a try if you enjoy atmospheric games with phenomenal attention to details.

												Very very happy with the game. Incredible sounds, sights, and story. The game is immersive, very immersive and very good.My only complaint was that the game led me on the forward vector chase while not letting me know how important the Tower parts were to find. You cannot end the game without collecting all the Tower Parts. At the very end I was left having to go find them all when it would have been easier not leaving an area until I had all the tower parts in that area. Game didnt warn me. I had to use a cheat code for the last tower piece which I could not find anywhere. For that reason I give you the code. Use it only if you must. solgive pieceWould I go back and play the game again now that I beat it? Probably not. But the story run through was very open world and survival. You can really take your time. There is no base building but there is exploration and crafting. You need to watch your temperature, drink water and eat food. There are weather anomolies that you need to hide from. There is no first person combat but the game keeps you sucked in with no need for it. I can tell that whoever was making this game put a lot of love into it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
												The Solus Project feels like five hours of an excellent game stretched into 10-15 hours of a mediocre one. The planet feels alive with plants, water, day-night cycles, and a gorgeous weather system. But nearly every strength that this game has is mitigated by an equivalent weakness. I would still buy it again for the truly unique setting it offers... there are some memorable moments to be found here which are worth the purchase price, but I won't be returning to Gliese.THE LONG VERSIONGraphics: They are stunning, with beautiful landscapes, days that waver in the hot sun, nights full of stars, awe-inspiring thunder storms... But after a while, every area, every part of the game, starts to become pretty much identical in content, style, even visual color. Day and night are very different, but since the majority of the game takes place in underground caves and ruins that all look the same too, you won't get to appreciate it. The magic gets lost as each island looks like the last one, every cave is blue and gray. There are plenty of areas and secrets to explore, but I stopped bothering.Gameplay: This is a good introduction to the mechanics of survival games, and my first in the genre. The information is clearly displayed in a handheld device which you can easily look down at without ruining the immersion. This game makes it easy to manage food and water needs, body temperature, and sleep. It presents clever immersive clues to your condition, such as frost on your HUD when you're getting cold, or slowed speed when you need rest. The downside: It doesn't feel like it adds much to the game. Water and food are scattered along the very linear course you have to take for the story, so there's no real need to be resourceful. You end up sleeping just to make the awake-hours meter go back up. The mechanic doesn't stay very interesting. I ultimately didn't feel like I was surviving on this planet, just managing numbers while I ran from point A to point B.Story: A really interesting and unique sci-fi story is marred by a maddening delivery system. It's mostly delivered through tablets, monuments, and papers you find. But you have to scan and read them onto the small hand-held translator. It displays the text slowly and in pieces. When you have six long monuments to read all in one room, this becomes annoying in a hurry. The crew logs are given one page at a time, often out of order. You'll find sheet 9 of 22, then sheet 5... by this point, you're going "come on, COME ON" at the snail's pace text as a tornado closes in.And the ending is a huge letdown as well. It's generally not a good move to have the player toil towards a goal, then make it completely pointless with two lines of dialogue... especially with the weird '50s sci-fi turn it takes.Exploration: This is where the game really could have risen above being a linear sci-fi game. Each area will alert you to the number of "secrets" remaining, and when you start on this strange world, the islands feel huge and ripe for discovery. But after you brave your first cave with resources at the ready, your reward is nearly always an artifact which grants a minimal stat boost. After finding my third or fourth "secret" which was just a 1% resistance to starvation boost, I stopped exploring much. And again, when you know the back of the island will look exactly like the side you're on, why bother going over there? I should also mention what I affectionately dubbed A-hole Island. Ever wanted to experience a tornado, a meteor storm, a lightning storm, ANOTHER tornado, then ANOTHER lightning storm in the course of five minutes? Me either.Of note also, this game suffers from extensive backtracking. Get the running boots at the start of the game. You'll need them.

												Enjoyable scifi adventure with a lot of free exploration. Graphics are a mix of of Unreal and Quake 3. Lots of hexagonal basalt columns, inspired by real-life's Giant's Causeway (Northern Ireland) and Isle of Staffa (Scotland), give an alien look and feel to the game. You solve puzzles using only a teleporter, a firestick, a rock and a hammer. Lovely outdoor islands, boring tunnels/corridors. Score: 7/10. Minusses:- only works on Win10 (it seems)- bad savegame system- no map- lots of backtracking- lots of samey-looking, uninspired tunnels/corridors

												VR Review: This is one of the most accomplished games on the Vive, and it's the type of game that I would like more of, An adventure in VR that takes you out of your normal life and gives you somewhere else to go, The survival aspect of the game is honestly a pain but the devs give you a slider to reduce the impact of survival and even turn that off if you so wish, Some of the environments are stunning along with the fantastic weather effects, You will truly feel like you are on another planet, the sense of presence is great in this game.Now this is not a horror game but the miles of tunnels and caves under the planet are truly some of the most creepy and scary I have had on the Vive, I have played Brookhaven and that did not scare me a bit, but this I dread going back into the caves, You are not the first to set foot on this planet and you may not be alone, Your main task is to get a signal back to the human race that are relying on you to scout the planet to see if it's a new home for us and our species after the Earth was destroyed, You need to collect parts from your downed ship, and puzzle together the mysteries that you will encounter. A must buy for the Vive.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12
												Review of a Vive experience.Today I crashed landed in an escape pod on an alien planet. I wandered around on a beach for a while in a daze. An alien beach. This fact sunk in when stopped looking at all the debris at my feet and noticed the several large planets staring back at me on the horizon. Looking up further I saw an intense meteor shower in the upper atmosphere above me. This was, no doubt, the remains of the ship that I was traveling in not minutes before. The enormity of the situation was inescapable. I was marooned on an alien planet. It was getting dark and colder. Fast. The spacesuit I was wearing would apparently only provide limited protection as I could already feel the temerature difference. I had to find shelter and had to somehow keep myself warm. Visions of Tom Hanks dancing around a fire suddenly sprang to mind and I couldn't help but laugh. I was startled to hear the panic in my own laughter. As I wandered in search of shelter I found what appeared to be a thruster from the ship I had been traveling in. It was huge. The nozzle of the thruster was wider than a man was tall. And the damn thing was still on! As I got closer I could tell that see that the thruster was still attached to a fuel source. A heaping pile of junk expelling plasma or exhaust out of the end. I forget which. I didn't have to get very close for it to warm me up. I dared not get any closer. Not far past that surreal scene I managed to find a cave. It was there that I spent my first night.All these experiences felt that much more real using a V.R. headset. I keep reading other reviews that state that the vr experience is terrible with this title. Not true.Set resolution to 150% and turn off AA! I also have my supersampling set at 2.0. If the devs are working to make the VR experience even BETTER then I'm all in.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15
												playing with the vive, around 6-7 hours in taking it slow. so far so good, one of the few vive game with a  full story and realised world. the ganeplay is exploration/puzzle witha  bit of survival, well suited to the vive as its about immersion and imagining youve crash landed on a deserted planet.controls are good could use a few more options perhaps, but better than most. graphics from a technicval perspective nothing special, but desiggn wise art direction its intresting has an alien type vibe, but a bit like home, things are not as colourful or as extreme as no mans sky more muted and subtle. you may want to use supersampling or in game resolution option if you got the horsepower because theres some terrible jaggies on display on some of the fauna and flora. it is  distracting because you spend a good deal of time looking at some of the plants which are very thin and needle like, and break up in jaggedy eyesore. nitpiking aside its workmanlike with a few ooo moments staring up at an alien planet moon setting and rising with comets wizzing by.  gameplay is slow puzzle based, and i may have to accept this is not a massive game unfortunately and is basciallly linear. there are a few secret areas but they dont offer much  except stat buff. if your type of player who only goes for open world you will feel restricted here, although there is a bit of exploration and you can take your time and poke around the areas a bit.anyway only reason i got this is because im looking for vive games, and this ticks all the boxes, you do feel transported to another world and the survival elements  such as weather/food/water/shelter offer a hint of what survival games in future for the vive will feel like. this game doesnt offer anything special for vive, theres some neat stuff holding your pda in one hand and your torch in other is quite immersive, but it hasnt been designed for vr exclusively so its limited in that sense.good stuff overall.

content:
Posted: February 24
												Just finished the game and I have to say this has been one of the most enjoyable games I've ever played.  All credit to the developers for producing such a great game, story line and VR experience.  I thought it had about 16 hours of gameplay (which is long for a VR title) but finally finished it after 50+ hours ... and it kept my interest right to the end. Apart from a few issues brought about by use of the teleport facility which, on occasions, allowed me to jump to areas of the game that the game logic hadn't anticipated it's been a bug free stable experience for me.  Thought the ending was great too and I don't say that of many games.Highly recommended!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												The Solus Project is the first VR game I actually play. I have some other titles and demos which support VR and they are fine for testing and the "Mhm, looks nice" or "Promising" moment, but I rarely spend time in there for the game, its atmosphere and story itself. In this game VR is fun and impressive enough that I rather wear my headset and stand/walk in my room for hours than sitting in my comfy chair and look at my monitor.The VR support is done well enough, although some things are still rough. For example I wasn't able to play before switching to the release candidate branch. Sound sometimes only works when going to the desktop and focusing the game window. Saving in the wrong place can corrupt the save (will load in a black room). There are also some things I don't like much, like teleporting. It's feels a bit immersion breaking, just changing the place from one frame to the next, but normal walking isn't really an option due to VR sickness risks. None of those are showstoppers however and don't prevent me from enjoying the game in VR for several hours per session.Aside from VR I like where the game and story is going so far, but then I do like the genre (Explore/Adventure/Walking Simulator) a lot in the first place. If you do to and if you have a Vive, then this game is a safe pick for a very fair price.As performance, I have a GTX 1070 on a i5 3570K and play with Medium Quality settings.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												I played the whole game in VR and loved it.  One of my favorite experiences so far and gave me confidence that VR won't be a gimmick limited to wave shooters.  The sci-fi story and feel was amazing.  While not a direct comparison, I got a heavy Metroid vibe with the alien environments, lore, and sense of isolation.  It does have a bit of a learning curve, so don't give up on the VR aspect of it right away.  After you've got a grasp of the survival and crafting mechanics, you should be good.

content:
