												I'm not sure if I can put into words how much I love this game.  I played it through to the end and now I'm playing it again!  I literally stay up all night with this game.  There are so many things to do, explore, and figure out.  I've trulyl never played a game I have enjoyed so much.  I even think this is better than Myst, which is one of my all-time favorites.  The story line is immersive, the exploration is open world and you could really spend hours exploring each island.  Or you could speed through each island, it is truly up to you how you want to play this game.  The puzzles are challenging but intuitive.  I would rate this game a 10/10.  I am hoping for a sequel!!

I played the game on easy (25%) but there is no way I could have finnished without the online guides.  The steam guide is very good ... and there are several You tube channels which walk you through the tough parts of you get stuck.  Highly recoomend ... even if advanture games aren 't your thing.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
												This game is wonderfully crafted. It has a few holes, but it holds up well as one of the best adventure games that I have ever played. Much of it reminds me of Metroid with the adventure aspect, backtracking, item searching, puzzle solving, beautiful architecture, and immersive atmosphere. The story really kept me going too, and being able to figure out the mystery and then experience the reveals in the game felt good. I am really hoping for a continuation. An ending like that deserves a next game chance to change things.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												There's really nothing in this game that I didn't like. I loved the graphics, I really liked the realism, but most of all I couldn't get enough of the story!!! I read every single lore tile I could find. I own The Ball, the precursor to The Solus Project, and I found it really amazing how they took thier previous game that had basically no plot and gave it a story. They explained what the ball was, not exactly how it came about, but I really liked how things that showed up earlier in the game would be explained later on. Like how the smoke monster came from inside the ball when the people of the uprising broke it open. One of the things I found most intriguing was how I constantly found myself in places I had been before. This is turning into a long review but I'd just like to applaud the creators for making this game so realistic. The environmental stats, the weather, fall damage, avoiding over/under heating. All of it made it seem so real, that on top of everything else, you were constantly being reminded that the survival of mankind rested on your own.I would absolutely without a shadow of a doubt recommend this game to anyone interested in adventure games, it was absolutely worth it!!!!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2016
												A 15 hour journey that is quite good. The end fails I believe and gives no satisfaction but the adventure there is interesting at most points. Occasionally quite disturbing and atmospheric. I feel the games mechanics get far more in the way of itself then really adding anything of value. It throws regular campsites of infinite food and water. This I don't believe is a well refined system. The temperature mechanics were good though, I felt like it was a very alien world with the wild variations and it added an interesting challenge. Although towards the end I couldn't hold my orb of coldening with a flashlight at the same time so I was always blind. Having to futz with the menu to switch between items. Frustrating.However gripes aside it was a good experience and is recommended.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Let me tell you first I'm a huge sci-fi, space exploration fan. I'm a sucker of games with sci-fi, space, futuristic technology setting. So it was clear I had to check this game out once in my life. At the beginning I was very sceptic about this game, I watched youtube videos on it, read reviews and alot of people were saying it is a great game etc.. Nonetheless I never was totally convinced and I wasn't sure if I should spend the money on this title and then get disappointed like I got with many other indie games who never felt finished and kept staying in early acces for ages.. So I kept "Solus Project" in my wishlist for a long time till finally I had the opportunity to buy this game on sale and I finally gave this beauty a chance.After my first playthrough I gotta say that I was totally proved wrong with my scepticism. This game totally got me immersed in it's beautiful world design. And yes, finally to me this game feels complete. You have to survive on an alien world (not that difficult like other survival games out there if you know what you're doing on normal level). Besides surviving and not dying (which after a couple of gamehours feels like something you just do automatically eg. make fire, eat, sleep etc.) you can also go out and explore the mysteries and what's going on on this planet. Also alot of lore and information lögs and secrets to be found for the real explorers out there.It looks georgeous, it has a pretty badass weather simulation which is helping you getting the feel of survival. And you have also a real goal if you just wanna do a speedrun without exploring too much, you can do that. But to me this game is all about exploring and experiencing the beauties and dangers of this world. Just watching the environment and sky while exploring and walking around just kept me in awe of this planet I'm stranded. The only thing I've missed in this game was the possibility to travel longer distances in a faster way (eg. if you wanna go back to already explored areas you have to travel back by walking which sometimes can take hours.. )The story is ok but honestly to me it wasn't the story who made me love this game, it is just the way everything is balanced out in this world. The interaction of the weather climate change, rain, snow, day night cycles, caves and how it affects your body temeperature etc. just feels on spot. The soundtrack is good (complements the game really well) and adds more drama to the situation. The World, sky at day&night looks stunningly gorgeous and gives you totally the feel that you really are there on this planet, a very immersive game! Just the look of the game made me wanna explore more of this beautiful world. I truly felt like an exploring new worlds pioneer. :)This is definitly a must-have for every space explorer pioneer, sci-fi and survival lovers out there! If you're looking for killing and shooting stuff, aliens etc. this might not be the game for you. If you're a curious, patient gamer and are into adventure/exploring/survival-games and if you like to got immersed and find out more of what's going on on this Planet, just give this a try. Overall price/package conclusion = TOP!! To me definitly best indie game of the year, please more of this!!(sorry for my english it's not my native language..)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3
												VR reviewI am playing this game with my VIVE for 10 hours now and think that I have finished it for about 50%. I have the latest patch installed and the game runs with perfect performance on my not-so-high-end-anymore i7 2600k/GTX 970 combination. VR support is absolutely flawless so far and the handling through the VIVE controllers works very good. The game supports two ways of movement, the well-known teleportation system and the possibility to seamlessly move over the floor in the direction you are currently looking. Although the latter method is a bit slow (i.e. the movement is a bit slow), I use it whenever possible because IMHO it offers much better immersion. So I use the teleportion system only for climbing, for which it works very well.Regarding the game itself, when I was buying the VIVE I was especially hoping for a game that puts me on an alien planet full with mysteries, ancient ruins, and fantastic surroundings. A different, exciting world for me to explore. Well, the Solus Project is nothing less than the answer to these hopes. It looks great, even phenomenal sometimes, e.g. while standing on the shoreline, watching the two moons rising above you together with the occasional falling stars, or when exploring a gigantic cave filled with ancient structures of an old civilization. And the sound is even better than the graphics, providing very intense and even scary moments regularly. By the way, I am using a 26 years old AKG K-280 Parabolic earphone and this game simply lets me believe that it must be the best earphone ever built :)I have read some complaints about this game in other reviews stating that it not difficult and complex enough. I guess this is not completely untrue. For example, in the Solus Project you must eat, drink and sleep regularly. But throughout the game you will find more food and water than you will ever need. You will even find camps (marked with a white icon directly in the world) with unlimited food and water resources regularly. Sleeping is also no problem since you can do it in most places. Interacting with the world is also not very complex. Finding a key here, repairing a lever there, and putting a stone on a plate on the ground. Nevertheless you will most probably die a few times in the game, since it contains a number of different traps, which you will simply overlook from time to time (note that your character has enough health points and will usually not die because of a single trap only).Regarding myself, I must admit that I am happy with the difficulty of the game as it is, because it gives me enough time to explore the world very thoroughly. Since the world is so beautiful this is simply more important for me than a more difficult game. And being able to finish the game all by myself without the need of a guide from the Internet is also not a bad thing, I guess.Note that each area (cave, etc.) of the game contains about ten or more secret locations, and it is a real challenge to find them. Usually the game will reward you with an upgrade to one of your stats when you find one of these secrets. So, yes, this also means that your character can improve during the game (health points, resistances).Regarding saving, the game lets you save on special obelisks that you will find along the way (often enough). Beside this, the game automatically saves when you are sleeping, which means that in fact you can save almost anytime, which is really useful when you are about to try something dangerous. Note however that the game always uses the same single savegame.To say something negative about this game at all, it took about 1-2 hours to become great. Because it started with an intro that did not even look average to me, and the first two (rather small) areas in the game didn't look especially good, either. I can promise you however that the visual appearance of the game will strongly improve after that weak beginning.Conclusion: The Solus Project is a not-to-complicated action adventure that looks and sounds so great in VR that everybody with the slightest interest in SF should play it!Update #1Four hours later and while exploring a large surface area I wanted to add that the survival aspect is more present here than in the caves before because it becomes very cold during the night. So you really have to do some planning, do the exploring during the day and seek shelter during the night, or you will freeze to death.And I also wanted to add that there is an option that controls your movement speed when not using the teleportation system, and its initial setting was only 50%. So please forget what I said about the slow movement speed!Update #2Four hours (18) more I must say that the game still gets better and also more complex. I have discovered two secret caves that I am exploring right now and they are quite challenging. They are more dark, narrow, and contain lots of crossroads so that I have started to take notes about the ways I have already explored. And food and water is very rare so that you have to be careful to find your way out early enough. Great!

I find myself using both the teleport and the walking system however, to avoid feeling sick when I walk I pretend that I'm riding on a hover board by turning my body sideways just like I would if I were skateboarding and so I just pretend that I have a hover-board with me on the planet.  My suggestion to the devs you guys should just make it officially part of the game the mechanic is already there and all you'd have to do is change the footsteps sounds to a very subtle hum or something. content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												Very very happy with the game. Incredible sounds, sights, and story. The game is immersive, very immersive and very good.My only complaint was that the game led me on the forward vector chase while not letting me know how important the Tower parts were to find. You cannot end the game without collecting all the Tower Parts. At the very end I was left having to go find them all when it would have been easier not leaving an area until I had all the tower parts in that area. Game didnt warn me. I had to use a cheat code for the last tower piece which I could not find anywhere. For that reason I give you the code. Use it only if you must. solgive pieceWould I go back and play the game again now that I beat it? Probably not. But the story run through was very open world and survival. You can really take your time. There is no base building but there is exploration and crafting. You need to watch your temperature, drink water and eat food. There are weather anomolies that you need to hide from. There is no first person combat but the game keeps you sucked in with no need for it. I can tell that whoever was making this game put a lot of love into it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
												The Solus Project feels like five hours of an excellent game stretched into 10-15 hours of a mediocre one. The planet feels alive with plants, water, day-night cycles, and a gorgeous weather system. But nearly every strength that this game has is mitigated by an equivalent weakness. I would still buy it again for the truly unique setting it offers... there are some memorable moments to be found here which are worth the purchase price, but I won't be returning to Gliese.THE LONG VERSIONGraphics: They are stunning, with beautiful landscapes, days that waver in the hot sun, nights full of stars, awe-inspiring thunder storms... But after a while, every area, every part of the game, starts to become pretty much identical in content, style, even visual color. Day and night are very different, but since the majority of the game takes place in underground caves and ruins that all look the same too, you won't get to appreciate it. The magic gets lost as each island looks like the last one, every cave is blue and gray. There are plenty of areas and secrets to explore, but I stopped bothering.Gameplay: This is a good introduction to the mechanics of survival games, and my first in the genre. The information is clearly displayed in a handheld device which you can easily look down at without ruining the immersion. This game makes it easy to manage food and water needs, body temperature, and sleep. It presents clever immersive clues to your condition, such as frost on your HUD when you're getting cold, or slowed speed when you need rest. The downside: It doesn't feel like it adds much to the game. Water and food are scattered along the very linear course you have to take for the story, so there's no real need to be resourceful. You end up sleeping just to make the awake-hours meter go back up. The mechanic doesn't stay very interesting. I ultimately didn't feel like I was surviving on this planet, just managing numbers while I ran from point A to point B.Story: A really interesting and unique sci-fi story is marred by a maddening delivery system. It's mostly delivered through tablets, monuments, and papers you find. But you have to scan and read them onto the small hand-held translator. It displays the text slowly and in pieces. When you have six long monuments to read all in one room, this becomes annoying in a hurry. The crew logs are given one page at a time, often out of order. You'll find sheet 9 of 22, then sheet 5... by this point, you're going "come on, COME ON" at the snail's pace text as a tornado closes in.And the ending is a huge letdown as well. It's generally not a good move to have the player toil towards a goal, then make it completely pointless with two lines of dialogue... especially with the weird '50s sci-fi turn it takes.Exploration: This is where the game really could have risen above being a linear sci-fi game. Each area will alert you to the number of "secrets" remaining, and when you start on this strange world, the islands feel huge and ripe for discovery. But after you brave your first cave with resources at the ready, your reward is nearly always an artifact which grants a minimal stat boost. After finding my third or fourth "secret" which was just a 1% resistance to starvation boost, I stopped exploring much. And again, when you know the back of the island will look exactly like the side you're on, why bother going over there? I should also mention what I affectionately dubbed A-hole Island. Ever wanted to experience a tornado, a meteor storm, a lightning storm, ANOTHER tornado, then ANOTHER lightning storm in the course of five minutes? Me either.Of note also, this game suffers from extensive backtracking. Get the running boots at the start of the game. You'll need them.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								So I stumbled upon this game via the store, read the description and thought to myself "meh...why not". So i bought, installed and started it.First thing that struck me was this genious of main menu soundtrack. This one blew me away...right away.I had not a real idea of what i should expect on this, i still thought is some space-survival - nothing more, nothing less. Oh dare me to be this stupid indeed. As soon as it started i found myself within a great adventure. Although some of the animations are - and I am far from an expert to rely on a whatever amount of experience in "rating" games - not quite good, this game caught me right away. Making use of the debris, the nature, exploring this indeed very alien place, but on my on - at first. I still have part 3 upcoming to me, as I haven't had the time yet, but I am SURE, it will keep up its pace and beliveable storyline.Another point I would love to mention is the fact, that the developing crew, especially the art and environmend designers made a really fantastic job here. You can somehow relate to this place you got stuck into and feel the need of exploring at every moment.My rating so far is a solid 8/10.Get the animations smoother, and the full scale is yours. Great game, total recommendation!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												This is the best and most immersive game I have played for VR to date. It has a completed game feel that other games do not, and a great length of gameplay to sink into. This is probably due to the game being made before VR, and then having VR functionality added once the Vive was released, but the VR system doesn't feel like an afterthought. I get a lot of satisfaction exploring, solving puzzles, and wandering the world. Even organzing my food, water, and other stashed items on the shelves of the empty shelters I find feels good in gameplay. There's something special about being able to reach out, interact with the world around you with your hands, and make it feel like your 'home', however temporary. The atmosphere it gives is quite alien, and leaves you with a sense of risk associated with your actions. I really can't give it enough praise in a market saturated with very dull, dry, and short VR titles. If you're on the fence, BUY IT! I am really glad I did.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												I am not even through the game yet (1/4 way maybe?) but have been playing for over six hours. I had to take a break and give this game a review because it is amazing! This game is tagged as a "Horror", which is true, but I would probably label that more like "Errie & Environmental". There are "things" that can kill you, but this isn't a combat type game at all. Getting around the "things" is just that, evading and playing it smart. The world is incredibly immersive and beautiful. The audio is 10/10. The environment is rich, alive and ever-changing. This game has a survival aspect, but it isn't your standard "do everything you can do to survive or die" mentallity, which I like (discliamer: my first playthrough is on easy). Also, there are SO many secrets, side paths, and things to explore that the gameplay time could EASILY reach 60+ hours for a single playthough. The story so far has been great and has kept me wondering what is next. The interface is great, the graphics are amazing, the audio is stunning, and the story... and those, ummm... "things"... have kept me on the edge of my seat. 10/10 in my book. MUST BUY!

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												Note: Review is non VR with Steam ControllerPros:-Rich Lore-Good Variety Of Items-Lots of Locations, each with different hazardsCons:-HP means nothing when you get one shot most of the time-Lineir pathing-Twisters... (Sorry but there d*cks)I liked my time with Solus Project, you start on an alien planet with no idea what's going on and have to find out what has happened and relay comms back to HQ.The story always kept me guessing with what to expect next and the rich lore helps you to understand this, the devs worked really well on this aspect, although I felt a bit let down by the ending.Exploration wise there are lots a different areas to explore although the lineir pathing keeps you to one area at a time where I think a more open world would have done better here (like Ori). The items you can get help combat each different location  so it's not too bad.I think this game would be a lot more fun to play with VR as you are more engrossed with the atmosphere (not that there isn't any there this would just be more immersive if so)Nevetheless I would recommend this game (more so if you have VR) around 7/10, there's simply some issues I had with this game (did notice a few bugs) but the amount of effort the devs put in shows through when it does.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												I got this game off a whim and I have to say I do not regret my decision, this is one of the most fun and intriguing survival games I have ever played. The work put into putting a mystery in almost every crook and cranny in this world is just amazing. The storyline in this game is very well crafted, and at the same time isn't overwhelming whereas you can't explore on your own, this game pretty much allows you to explore every part of the area with very few restrictions. There also being extra areas to explore for those more hardy explorers. Surely it isn't a super dedicated survival where you need to craft your way into a mansion-like base, but it really does excel on the exploration factor and the mystery of the past occurrences factor. I will defiantly play it over again. 9.5/10

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												This is the best and most immersive game I have played for VR to date. It has a completed game feel that other games do not, and a great length of gameplay to sink into. This is probably due to the game being made before VR, and then having VR functionality added once the Vive was released, but the VR system doesn't feel like an afterthought. I get a lot of satisfaction exploring, solving puzzles, and wandering the world. Even organzing my food, water, and other stashed items on the shelves of the empty shelters I find feels good in gameplay. There's something special about being able to reach out, interact with the world around you with your hands, and make it feel like your 'home', however temporary. The atmosphere it gives is quite alien, and leaves you with a sense of risk associated with your actions. I really can't give it enough praise in a market saturated with very dull, dry, and short VR titles. If you're on the fence, BUY IT! I am really glad I did.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												I am not even through the game yet (1/4 way maybe?) but have been playing for over six hours. I had to take a break and give this game a review because it is amazing! This game is tagged as a "Horror", which is true, but I would probably label that more like "Errie & Environmental". There are "things" that can kill you, but this isn't a combat type game at all. Getting around the "things" is just that, evading and playing it smart. The world is incredibly immersive and beautiful. The audio is 10/10. The environment is rich, alive and ever-changing. This game has a survival aspect, but it isn't your standard "do everything you can do to survive or die" mentallity, which I like (discliamer: my first playthrough is on easy). Also, there are SO many secrets, side paths, and things to explore that the gameplay time could EASILY reach 60+ hours for a single playthough. The story so far has been great and has kept me wondering what is next. The interface is great, the graphics are amazing, the audio is stunning, and the story... and those, ummm... "things"... have kept me on the edge of my seat. 10/10 in my book. MUST BUY!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												I played The Ball and really enjoyed it, so I had a feeling I would like this game too. I was right - I absolutely loved it.There's so much to explore while at the same time trying to keep yourself alive. I thought I would have a hard time keeping myself hydrated, fed, at a good temperature and with a decent amount of sleep... but I didn't struggle with that too much. A few times I almost froze to death, but I really only have myself to blame haha.The only real trouble I had was self made: I just wanted to explore every nook and cranny in the game but there were just so many things I had to stop exploring and get myself back on track with the story because I wanted to move it along. I think I will enjoy having more to explore in a second playthrough and I definitely want to find all the secret areas I missed. There is definitely some replayability here for me.I thought that the story was pretty well done. I did a lot of reading about the planet's history of The Sky Ones in my adventuring, and while I normally avoid stories with a lot of reading and text involved, I felt that this game had a respectable amount and it helped to get a better understanding of what was going on.This game really felt similar to The Ball with the mysterious underground buildings and, well, uh, hovering balls! There was a great atmosphere in The Solus Project and the graphics were really solid imho. I found myself spending a lot of time just appreciating the alien landscape, the setting sun and the night sky and just taking screenshots of everything. I'm a sucker for beautiful alien landscapes and the glow effects like in this game.Overall just a really solid game. A+++   6413/10   Would crash land on alien planet again.

												So far I've invested about 10 hours into the game, and it really took me by surprise.  I love stories and plots that involve some ancient-yet-advanced tech, not sure why, and this game has plenty of that.  What I didn't expect, was a dark story and some of the creepiest gameplay elements I've ever come across.  Granted, I tend to stay away from scary/creepy games just because they don't particularly interest me, but this one brings it in so subtly that it literally sneaks up on you.  I'm definitely happy with my purchase during the 2016 summer sale, and really feel like I've already gotten my money's worth (and I haven't even gotten to the end yet).

												Excellent Game!  Combination of mystery, crafting, story, graphics, audio etc. were on point.  Best game I've played in quite a while.  Ending is both puzzling (in a good way) leaving you wanting more (sequel????????) and also a bit harsh in that you feel like there should have been more.  I hope they make a sequel to this game.  I really got a prometheus vibe from this game. Overall I felt like it was telling the story of an advanced race of beings experimenting on several races of lesser beings which feels alot like the movie Prometheus.  It would be very interesting to see where they take this franchise next.Game also has great value.  I played for about 16 hours or so and I feel like I might have missed some things.  Meaning for the cost, you get alot of game and at no point do you ever feel like you're just grinding for no reason.  Perfect.

Posted: October 9, 2016
												I'm part way through this playing in VR with my Vive. The controls are a bit clunky but once you've got the hang of it, the game is simply wonderful. It's perfectly paced, challenging, unsettling and fun. The alien world is beautifully realised and genuinely convincing.   VR adds a lot to this - you feel like you're really there which is both brilliant and slightly disconcerting.It takes a while to get going and the first half hour is a bit confusing but it's completely worth the effort to get started.I don't know how good the game is without VR, but anyone with a Vive and a bit of patience really has to get this. It's head and shoulders above all the mini games and other stuff around at the moment. It's also a huge game with massive vistas and a great sense of scale and exploration

content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												Recommended for players more into puzzles and storyline than outright fighting.  Gameplay is simple, but the story is anything but, being exploration heavy and requiring the player to ration resources as they delve into the unkown.Survival in Solus is about wits, brains and judgement.No instant gratification, no fast paced action or explosions throughout, no swordplay or gunplay involved, just a good old fashioned thinking mans adventure game.If that sounds boring to you, read no further.*waits for them to leave*Alright, here's the rub.Just because you can't fighti in this game, doesn't mean your character isn't in mortal peril.  You have to scavenge for food, water and resources as you explore, and you are constatnly getting killed off by the weather conditions alongsied natural disasters that are happening all around you.This is a hostile world and it wants you dead.  And of course, there are secrets.  Go after the secrets, expect even more challenging deaths.  Use you tools, be smart with your inventory, and you might get to see whats erally going on with the world around you.Highly recommended.

												10/10, scared me again! Very Fun game!! Kinda creepy at some parts, but very nice game.Q: Is there a Second Device (Crystal input required)? I found one in Act II if I'm correct and I put a Hot Crystal in it...I want to make a Cold Device, too. The Hot Device has helped me more often, as the Torch with reflective surfaces hurts my eyes and makes it hard to look at stuff. I was hoping for animals, but then I realized this planet is probably the hardest place for small, stupid creatures to live... because Tornadoes would sweep them up. I also take breaks a lot, as my heart beats too fast. Would Highly Recommend Playing. IF YOU HEAR DEEP, BELLOWING NOTES: RUN. RUN TO A SAFE SHELTER. IT IS NOT SAFE. *Static and Wind* -OH NO... OH GOD PLEASE N- *Deep notes* -NO NO NO N- *Cracking noises* *Static*  [End Transmission]

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												As for the VR version: Yes, the controls could be more intuitive, but they are workable, and taking a bit of care not to abuse the currently rather unrestricted teleportation system, the game offers a very immersive and detailed environment you can lose yourself in. The fact that the survival aspect is rather light makes this more tolerable in VR, where going about  things tends to be a bit slower and many may do it primarily for the experience.I'm confident that the developers will continue to polish the VR integration. Personally, I'd wish for the controls to become more intuitive, e.g., picking up and combining things by touching them, operating the PDA visually/directly with the right hand, etc. I'd also prefer a right hand rather than a controller model, but that's only cosmetic.With a bit of good will, this is an impressive VR title you can lose yourself in. It also runs with good performance and OK looks at 150% on low settings (ultra textures) on my i7, GTX 970 OC Windows 10 system. Recommended!

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												Note: Review is non VR with Steam ControllerPros:-Rich Lore-Good Variety Of Items-Lots of Locations, each with different hazardsCons:-HP means nothing when you get one shot most of the time-Lineir pathing-Twisters... (Sorry but there d*cks)I liked my time with Solus Project, you start on an alien planet with no idea what's going on and have to find out what has happened and relay comms back to HQ.The story always kept me guessing with what to expect next and the rich lore helps you to understand this, the devs worked really well on this aspect, although I felt a bit let down by the ending.Exploration wise there are lots a different areas to explore although the lineir pathing keeps you to one area at a time where I think a more open world would have done better here (like Ori). The items you can get help combat each different location  so it's not too bad.I think this game would be a lot more fun to play with VR as you are more engrossed with the atmosphere (not that there isn't any there this would just be more immersive if so)Nevetheless I would recommend this game (more so if you have VR) around 7/10, there's simply some issues I had with this game (did notice a few bugs) but the amount of effort the devs put in shows through when it does.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								The Solus Project looks to be shaping up to be very good old school, but new school game indeed. There is no rule that a game has to be sandbox, multiplayer or involve zombies or survival. Remember those days? Well in The Solus Project there is survival - food, hydration and there is an environmental struggle also. This is all wrapped up in some very nice visuals and what seems to be a decent narrative (remember those?) Below is a video showcasing some of the basic mechanics of the game, I hope it helps in some way to help you making a choice on this title.


YouTube™ Video: The Solus Project Part 1 - HD PC Gameplay First Look 

			Views: 50		

			The Solus Project Part 1 - HD PC Gameplay Walkthrough Welcome to my The Solus Project playthrough, with family friendly commentary on the trials and tribulations of surviving on a strange planet.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								     Normally I play a lot of Bethesda games for their large mod database on the internet and I can go ham and not worry about "immersion", so I picked up the Solus Project for a different kind of experience.  If you've played Myst, it's a lot like that combined with a Metroidvania travel here and do this, and go there and get this object type playstyle.  I played it on easy mode until I ran out of the story (it’s still being released a bit at a time because it is Early Access), but on the harder difficulties you can get your fill of survival.  Temperature and wetness contribute to potential hypothermia as well as varying weather such as sunny weather, snow, rain, meteor showers, and tornadoes.  There are also plenty of secret areas to get items that boost your resistance to hypothermia, increase movement speed, etc. and you are guarenteed not to find all of them in the first go.     There is a story here about Gliese as well as plenty of notes to find and read about your mission and fellow Solus Project astronauts and trying to communicate about your crash landing.  Go to the spoiler tag to reveal what I've uncovered and think of the story.  From the in game texts strewn about on monuments and such it seems that a race of coneheaded people were taken from their planet by much taller humanoids which they named Sky Ones (because these aliens came in spaceships.)  These Sky Ones showed them how to make stone buildings and other sciences.  But there is a sinister element here.  The Sky Ones are underground dwellers.  The coneheaded children are sent to an underground monastery to participate in a ritual called the Flameless Rite, which if I understand the pictures and stone tablets correctly essentially involves running around with a torch that attracts a creature of some sort that is smoke, spikes and rays of light (you don’t actually see what the creature is inside the smoke) which then eats the child and flame.  I can only guess but what I gathered is that lots of coneheads are sacrificed to these “dark spirits” as they call them to power them up and the “dark spirit” is used by the Sky Ones to power their machines or for some other reason.  Of course all of this is done under the guise of some religion so the general conehead populace doesn’t realize they are food, leading to some wise rebels wanting to expel these superficially kind but sinister Sky Ones from their world.  As part of the main story you follow a giant cable from the surface to underground and manage to activate it using a tower which doubles as a lightning rod that funnels the energy.  Overall, it becomes kind of a horror atmospheric game without really meaning to at times. I recommend it for a change of pace and because it’ll leave you wanting to find out about what happened on Gliese as well as the Solus Project itself.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												I spent the past 2 days playing through and holy hell it was bloody great. It kept me engaged and it made me want to keep playing till the end.My favorite thing about the game was the disasters. I just wished there were more. The music, the scale of them they were amazing. The ambiance was amazing, everything looked nice, the survival gameplay was good. Especially the heat mechanic in the later areas.The only problem I had was playing on normal difficulty. When I got to the first monster I literally couldn't do anyhting to get past it. it would always come for me no matter what, so I had to drop the difficulty down. Other than that dodging the other monsters was easy but amazing. Especially when it was pitch black and you just hear the music then you see a flashing light head your way.Overall I rarely pick up a game and play it completely blind but I'm happy I did so here. It cost me 16 hours of my life but it was worth it. Good story, great environments, good gameplay mechanics and amazing atmosphere.

The environment gorgeous, even if you have it on the lowest graphic settings (so if your card is♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ don't worry). content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
Product received for free
												#####12.9 hours playtime as of release of review. This review is for game version 1.02, and may not accurately reflect the current state of the game.##### Overview The Solus Project is an exploration game, set in the harsh wilderness of an alien planet. You will traverse across unique and dangerous landscapes solving intriguing puzzles and finding out what is really happening here. The game by default is also a survival game, where you need to keep yourself nourished, hydrated, and at a suitable temperature. The survival aspects and be turned off (which I personally did) and allow for a casual exploration game. However, you will soon come face to face with some freaks of nature, including the giant death winds (tornados) and the monstrous fireball bombardments (meteorite showers).  Components Visuals - I found the visual style of The Solus Project to be immersive and stunning. The landscapes are varied and expansive, while the caves are claustrophobic yet still beautiful. This game holds many visual treats inside these caves, like stunning crystals, and acid lakes. The lighting effects are magificent. This is the kind of game that will make you want to stop and take screenshots. Overral, the visuals of The Solus Project are awesome.Audio - The sound design... The sound in this game has got to be the most immersive sounds I've ever heard in a game. It will make you feel like you are really there (P.s. A note on immersion: this game supports virtual reality). The soundtrack for this game had been meticulously crafted in a way that it is immersive no matter where you are or what you're facing in this game. The music will match your surroundings and will always add ambience or tension. Not to mention this is some of the best sounding music I've heard in a game. I listened to the whole soundtrack on Spotify and it just blows me away. The quality is just insane. And the music helped make the most tense and frightening moment I have ever experienced: facing a tornado. Even if you are safe and sound in a small cave, the music that plays whenever there's a "climate anomaly" makes for a seriously chilling moment. If you want to see what it's like, here's a video showcasing the terrifying encounter: https://youtu.be/f0JmziB5j-I?t=2m5sOverall, I would have to say that the audio in this game is out of this world. Gameplay - The Solus Project pits you against the odds as you fight for survival and uncover the many mysteries in this game. You can craft items such as torches, which provide heat and a light source. The crafting didn't feel very intuitive but it gets the job done. Thankfully it isn't an important component to this game, as it is used sparingly. While mainly being an exploration-centric game, there are also enviromental puzzles throught the areas that require solving in order to progress. Early on you get a teleportation disc launcher, which is a major gameplay aspect. The basic gameplay comes down to solving a puzzle on an isand, then going through a cave and coming out onto another island, rinse and repeat 5 or so times. Yet the mechanics of the game never felt repeated. The progression is smooth and you're always making progress, even when scouting the area. Eventually you'll encounter things which I won't spoil, but I will warn you that this game is borderline horror. And it's not just the chilling atmosphere.Story - Earth is destroyed. You are part of an intergalactic fleet looking for a suitable homeland for humans. However, not all goes to plan when you ship crashlands onto a mysterious planet, Gliese-6143-C. You must attempt to relocate any survivors and try to establish a connection back to the rest of the fleet. The story adds to the intensity of the experience as you carry the weight of humanity on your shoulders. The fleet needs to find a suitable planet or everyone will eventually perish from the finite resources. Functionality - This game was made in Unreal Engine, and it runs greatly as I would have expected. There is a broard range of settings and customizable difficulty. This game never crashed on me, and there is virtually no glitches that I encountered. One nitpick is that the loading times are a little bit long, and it can break up the immersion slightly. Overall, The Solus Project performs technically well. Pros  Dynamic environements; the moon affects the tide and the weather affects the flora Incredibly detailed levels with hundreds of secrets Stunning audio and visual design Clever puzzles and enviromental obstacles Always feels fresh; doesn't get repetitive Customizable difficulty; anywhere between a casual stroll to an intense survival experience Cons  Loading times are a little long Crafting and inventory management is a little fiddly  Conclusion If you're looking for spectacular linear exploration game with survival aspects, then I highly suggest The Solus Project. I can't stop thinking about this masterpiece, this game would definitely be in my top 5 games of all time.I give this game a 9.5/10, an unforgettable digital masterpiece.

												Not a fan of horror games in general but this game didn't overdo it, which is nice.Survival games are something I play alot, and The Solus Project have a nice mix between survival and exploration which makes it so much better than your generic survival game.Probably have the most detailed story of any kind of survival game I have, and I have a few. content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
												Been playing this with Vive and it is one of the most complete experiences available for the headset right now. I feel that being able to enjoy this game in VR requires effort and time getting used to but it is worth it. Devs are very active and seem to be focusing all their effort on improving VR experience so the "requires getting used to" statement most likely doesn't apply that much in the near future.  Game's description states that that Vive is supported. While this is true, VR quality is not on par with content specifically made for VR. As of now, user interface is clunky and locomotion is odd and requires developing vr-legs. The day I bought this I felt bad for spending 20e on a game which didn't seem to be enjoying. On top of that it took some tinkering on getting everything smooth on gtx 970.  It took me about an hour to get over the annoyances and develop short VR legs. There is a teleport gun available almost from start but I don't believe it is useful to rely only on it when it comes to moving around. For the leg-development process the game offers a nice opportunity as there is an option to change the movement(/hovering) speed.  The actual gameplay is great and matches the positive reviews before the VR introduction. Of course enhanced to the power of 2 from actually being there, exploring a ♥♥♥♥in' alien planet.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												So far this game is a blast, I got a good jump out of it, enjoyed learning how the controls work, loved the VR adaptation from the original game and am still happily just trodding through it, taking my time to run around and see the sights.  This doesn't go without some obvious porting flaws.  I've found that after realizing the game was adapted to the VR that I can walk through walls when I want to, this includes door to hidden/locked areas.  This means I can either use the 'walk-through-walls' approach, or even the VR short distance teleporting to get through walls and such (I've already gathered several secret items this way and hate myself for it).  The movement mechanic I think is fantastic (you can change your run speed in the menu rather than a run/sprint mode that you'd typically find), but the way that movement is handled with the left joystick makes a lot of sense to me.  All-in-all: I think this game is great, not as hard as it seems like its slogan lead me to believe, but great.  If you're looking for a good VR Purchase, I think this game should be near the top of your list.  I'm looking forward to seeing what future VR updates have to offer.A non-spoiler tip that took me a bit to figure out for those of you that purchase this, you can't pick up notes to read them, rather you point your right hand at the object and its description/text will appear on your PDA.  This is neat, but it took me a bit to figure this out.  I like it!  I do wish that the Steam VR understanding of left-hand/right-hand would translate to the game and I would hope most games would let you set your 'handedness' in the future, it seems it would be simple and if you can get it into the Steam VR config, each game doesn't need this own setting for you (same goes for inverted controls on current games...), but there are times when my right hand and left hand got swapped from what I expected when the game started, hopefully this is just a bug that will be addressed in a near release.Get this game.

								cool mysterious sci-fi exploration game with some survival elements.so far there hasn't been any action yet, just exploring islands, caves and alien architecture.I really dig the the atmosphere they're trying to create with this game, a lot of the story comes from the environment and the things you discover. (then again, Mars's surface looks pretty much the same as well)

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												The Solus Project is a sci-fi exploration/survival game set on a distant, seemingly uninhabited planet that you've crash landed on. Despite very little dialogue, or substance to the story, my early access to this game still managed to suck me in.PROS:- Beautiful, immersive environment, atmosphere, sounds and weather. The juxtaposition between the dream-like cosmic surface world and eerie, cryptic caves is well done. The weather system is dynamic ,and  at any point you can experience meteor showers, rain, earthquakes, temperature fluctuations, all which have an effect on your characters well being.-The survival feels intuitive. A PDA companion gives you lots of great vitals on your body, survival status and environment such as body temp, humidity, sleep/energy levels, weather temperature etc. What makes this great is that every little thing affects these vitals accordingly. Get wet from a rainstorm or swimming in the ocean? Your body temp will lower and you'll become at risk for hypothermia, but you can bust out a torch or start a fire and watch it come up in response. There are plenty of other ways to help maintain homeostasis. Tons of little things like this make you feel like you're actually surviving on a strange planet.-There is an in-game adjustable difficulty. Want to mainly explore without worrying about dying of thirst? Slide it down for an hour, seamlessly. Want to have a complete immersive experience with no objective markers or help markers, and a completely hardcore survival difficulty? There's an option for that too.-Exploration is rewarded. The different areas are littered with bits of lore, random items which may or may not be useful (I've found everything from a teleport device to a solar-rechargable flashlight), "relics" which can boost various survival stats, things that give you temporary buffs, crafting and survival supplies, small puzzles and other random stuff which never gives a dull moment.NEUTRAL:- No immediate combat. There doesn't appear to be any enemies thus far in the game, thus your only enemy is surviving and not falling to death.- The game is not completely open-ended. You are free to explore each area, which is rather large and packed with secrets, but ultimately there is an end goal/story of establishing communication which will lead you from one area to the next.CONS:- This is a fresh early access game, so expect about 4-6 hours of content from this first piece of the game, as well as some bugs which will cause the game to occasionally crash, thus losing any progress between saves.VERDICT:An extremely promising game with a lot of fun aspects and potential. Worth supporting through early access. The beautiful environments, rewarding exploration, and cryptic lore leaves you wanting even more. I can't wait for them to add more content.ART/DESIGN/MUSIC: 9/10GAMEPLAY: 8/10STORY: 8.5/1025.5/30 - Should be near the top of your wishlist if you're a fan of survival/space/sci-fi

												I liked this game but it did have some issues.Pros Looks fantastic Atmospheric Music and sound effects Survival mechanics including heat stroke and hypothermia Encourages and rewards explorationCons Mediocre and cliched sci-fi story with a disappointing ending Survival mechanics that included hunger and dehydration but the game included so many resources that you were never in any real danger of starving or dehydrating  The game was all about exploration, but there was also a critical mission that needed to be done and wandering off to explore caves and such really took away the urgency of that main missionOK, I really liked this game and the story was OK, but cliche. If you like the whole Stargate/ancient astronauts vibe, then you will like the story even if there wasn't really anything innovative about it. And yes, the ending was a letdown to me. It really deflated my sense of everything that I accomplished and experienced through ther rest of the game. The setting is really immersive and enigmatic, but for a game that encourages you to try to explore every nook and cranny, it seems unfair that you could (on rare occasion) get yourself stuck in a place where you have no recourse but to just let yourself starve to death or just quit the game and reload. I am not talking about glitching through walls or through the floor. I mean that there is a teleportation device that you can use to teleport short distances to reach otherwise inaccessible areas. And sometimes you could teleport into some nook somewhere but you couldn't teleport out. That was frustrating the couple of times it happened to me. I guess another annoyance I had with the game was there was a fair amount of backtracking at times. But at least the environments changed becuase of your earlier actions so that keep things a little fresh as you were going over old paths. I really do recommend this game though, it could be pretty creepy at times, and awe-inspiring other times.

Posted: December 4, 2016
												A very atmospheric, detailed, feature rich and lengthy game for VR at this point.On Vive, I find it frustrating that they removed backward trackpad movement just to add a recenter button, and it's odd that you have to use a button to couch/duck. I'm personally finding it difficult to get into because of this disconnect, and I may end up refunding it for that. (A personal preference that I'm sure differs from many peoples', which is fine. No point arguing about it though, since argument can't change preferences.) If I hear they're definitely re-adding backward movment before my 2 weeks expires, or at least a way to edit the .ini file for correct trackpad movement, I will update this review.Anyway, the game itself gets a big thumbs up. It's immediately captivating, and has some of the most complete and high-quality features seen in a Vive game so far. Highly recommended, if you don't mind the lack of backward trackpad movement. You CAN use controller tilt for full forward/backward movement if you're good at it. For me, it feels off for this game and its tight platforming and jumping, although I loved it in "A Legend of Luca" where you only have to deal with walking/running.

Posted: April 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game casts you into the cosmos, stranded on an unknown world. The elements of survival (while basic) make it all the more realistic. I expect them to add a lot more items and functions to that system. That being said; the weather system is the best I have ever seen in a game; the random tornados, lighting and meteors especially knock your socks off! Beyond that the thrill of navigating a (seemingly) dead world is fantastic-even more so when you realize the ancient civilization that  once lived there. Uncovering their history is exciting. I would only say that the game is rather linear (which makes since considering the discover/progression of the game). That being said I highly recommend this for anyone who wants to feel trapped on a planet.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
Early Access Review
The Solus Project is gripping, harsh and amazingly fun!I bought this game because I liked the look of the game and the promise it made of what it was. And boy was I (and still am) right!The Solus Project is an adventurous puzzle survival game. I made the mistake playing this game on normal difficulty thinking it wasn't really that much of a survival game. But heat, cold, dehydration, starvation, alien traps, tornado's and even meteor showers can kill you as soon as they get the chance. Keep this in mind when starting this game.You are on a mission to save mankind when your ship crashes on an uncharted planet (Gliese-6143-C). Now you have to survive and try to establish contact. But you will soon notice that this planet is not what it seems...The Solus Project is really well made and the environments (inside as well as outside) are beautiful and full of stuff to explore. At the moment of writing this I'm getting a sense of what I'm supposed to be doing, but there are more mysteries on this planet than it first revealed. Am I alone here? Are there other survivors? What happened here in the past? You are slowly figuring this out when playing the game.I for one cannot wait to play more of this game.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												I really enjoyed this game and played most of it in VR.  Here are the things I like about it:1. Tornadoes - The tornadoes are scary and the music that comes with them make them even more terrifying.2. Nice graphics and great sound effects and music.   I loved the cave with all the giant, glowing mushrooms.  I also loved the giant moon, that was my favorite scene.3.  First person and very immersive.4.  Very Interesting story line.  The further you get into the game, the more you learn about the alien race that used to inhabit the planet and what happened to them.Tips on playing:1. When in doubt, use your teleporter.  It serves as more than just for teleporting you back to a cave when the weather gets bad.    2. Food is everywhere, you don't have to stock up on it too much.3. Don't swim with your torch ;)**Warning Spoilers below**Suggestions for improvement (I know the game is no longer early access, but I think these would have made the game even better):1. There should be a suggestion in the beginning to use your teleporter to get into the first cave.  I was completely clueless on this and didn't think I could shoot it in there for some reason.  I actually stopped playing for quite some time because I got stuck on this and couldn't find the solution.2.  The player seems to care less about the aliens he actually encounters.  For example, when you get to the top of the windmill and activate it and then make a log afterwards, he says absolutely nothing about the reptilian/predator looking entity that was chained up trying to literally bite your head off.  I think that would have been important to note because it is the first alien contact you have.  That was not the only instance.  He reported once that he "thought" he saw one when in fact it was standing right in front of you.  Unless you really weren't paying attention, it's impossible to miss.  That probably should have been said the first time you saw one for the very first time standing in a window (which he said nothing about!).3.  I know VR is "expiremental" but there was some shimmering lights around plants and some other things that threw off the feel and graphics a bit.4. There should be more than just the 15 components around the islands.  I thought I got them all but was left 1 short.  I tried my best to retrace my steps, which took forever! but was not able to find that last one.  Had to use a cheat command.  Also, not everyone thoroughly searches everything, which is why there should be an abundance of the parts.5. There should be manual save options so I can go back to an older save.  I ran into a couple issues and was not able to load an older file so had to use cheat commands (like the time a pillar got stuck up on a ledge somehow).

content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												Let's start off with some backstory, just to be clear...When I was 8, the first Unreal game released. Not Unreal Tournament, no... Unreal Gold Edition with Return to Na'Pali. A campaign game, very shooter focused but also many RPG elements. Prior to Unreal Gold, my experience with gaming was purely simulators, mostly flight combat. I never owned a console, never experienced Zelda, but that game sold me on a genre I never knew existed. I completed the campaign and the expansion 4 times before downloading any modpack mini campaign I could find and playing those, too. Since then many games have released that had RPG elements which I've enjoyed. The newer Tomb Raiders, Fallout series, Elder Scrolls. I've loved them all, but none as passionately as that first, little-known game that truly taught me how epic a story a videogame could convey.Flash forward 18 years. I happen to be browsing Steam when a game pops up that seems to have some interest. "Okay" I say, as I watch the trailer like many before. "I'll give it a try, why not it looks entertaining"I had no idea what I was getting.I think the first hint was probably the crosses with the aliens everywhere. Not simple crosses, no... crosses for aliens with 4 arms. But why, when these aliens all have 2? Where had I seen such crosses before? Could it possibly be? Nali?Enter aliens. "Wait, is that a Skaarj?" "No but damn that's similar, and the staff reminds me an awful lot of the Krall..." Then I start thinking about the plot. A technologically advanced mysterious alien race which subjugates a physically more frail other alien race that is still primitive in development, and uses their technology like magic? Well okay, also familiar... At least they don't have to mine Tarydium.So I complete the game, hyped up and craving more, but also still curious about these glaring similarities... Come to find out in an interview the developer seems to share the same passion I do for a little known old game...Overall, I thought the added survival elements really helped modernize it over the inspiration. They are well balanced if you know what you are doing, and select the correct level of difficulty for your preferred playstyle. The added spookiness over UG was unexpected but welcome, and never quite the jump scare most people go for, but a more subtle reaction in the gut. Walking up to a corpse, seeing it lean upright and stare up at me as I stand next to it... I didn't jump back but had to utter aloud "Ohhhh no you did not just do that..."Honestly, the only thing I think this game is missing is an ASMD...Needless to say, I'll be raving about this one to friends for a while yet. The moment I get my Vive there will be a second playthrough happening.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Another survival game.Well, not just /another/. Solus Project is different because the surviving is on another planet. The sf backstory is pretty good, and the visuals are truly evocative of being on another world. The Unreal Engine does a good job here. Its not totally at a triple A level but its at least double A. The sound quality is good, music comes in small doses, usually during a "you done goodly" or "OMG" moment. Setting the game to Ultra really put some stress on my 980 ti, not sure if the game needs more optimization or what. As far as the game play goes, you really are in a survival situation, the planetary temps get horrifically cold at night and you need to keep up with food and hydration constantly. A little /too/ constantly because there is a lot to discover and just when your close to finding some secret you have to stop and go find a plant to eat. The game comes in three levels of difficulty. I've only tried Normal and it keeps you busy, hard must be hellacious. Theres a little phone/computer you carry that gives all your stats and reminders such as "User cold and wet" or "Starvation imminent". The crafting is pretty rudimentary, mostly using this object on that object to get a result, for example hitting a tin can to open it so you can eat the food inside. For this genre its got a lot going for it in terms of the story, but going back and forth between survival and exploration is a bit annoying. A good buy though, I reccomend if you want a different spin on the survival game genre.System Specs: Cpu: 4790K Gpu: Gigabyte 980 ti G1 Mem: 16 Gigs Crucial TacticalAddendum:I have to add on to this review. After you get away from the crash zone your "leash" to thesurvival part of the game gets longer. And theres much more interesting things to discover.I won't put any spoilers here but the feeling of things being /alien/ is nicely done.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												This game is amazing! The "story", if you want to call it that, is good. It is literally exploration, and only what you seek out and find, that makes the story. What i am trying to say is, you can basically run through the game and not read anything or pay minimal attention to the things around you, but why would you do this?But now a few other, minor things that should be mentioned, for example the performance.It uses the Unreal Engine but sometimes stutters really bad, that has to do with the sky and ocean reflection updates.If you receive these kind of stutters, then there is a fairly easy fix for it:go and open:steamapps\common\TheSolusProject\Solus\Config\DefaultGame.iniin the config find and change following from True to False:AllowOceanUpdate=FalseAllowSkylightUpdate=FalseThis will help a lot, also go and enable FXAA in your driver settings, if you are on an nvidia card, this did help tremendously with my frames per second, boosting it from 45-50 to 90-95fps.TL;DR: Good game for little money for all explorers and spelunkers that know how to basic computer

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
Product received for free
												I initially found The Solus Project to be visually enticing but difficult to get into. Interestingly enough, I approached each session of playing it with the same attitude. I sighed at the prospect of starting it up, but once I was in I found myself sufficiently immersed to keep on going until it was finally done. I felt the same about writing this review as well: unsure as to what I was going to write, but found plenty to write about once I started. Its level design and world building are great, its audiovisual style stellar, but it fails in making for a consistently solid gameplay experience. Don’t take that as a too harsh indictment of the game. If anything, The Solus Project is at its worst decent and a mark of wasted potential more than anything resembling a failure. It’s definitely one of the better survival experiences out there and others would do well to take a few pages from its book.Full Review Here: http://pressa2join.com/reviews/the-solus-project

Early Access Review
								I won't go into detail because there are many other reviews that cover most of what makes this game amazing.But I want to leave a positive review as well because the devs deserve it!The quality of the game is absolutely amazing -  no bugs, no issues at all - the only reason this game is in early access is because there are multiple episodes which will be released over time (for free). The mixture of surviving and story telling is awesome and works perfectly well.The visuals are absolutely beautiful and oh dear the sounds and music of the game, they add so much to the game to make it more immersive. Seriously the soundscape of this game is one of the best I've ever listened to in my entire gaming experience.A big plus is also the perfect optimization I have a GTX 980ti and it can handle the game perfectly well of course. But I also tested it on another PC with a 4 year old GTX 680 and I can run the game with stable 60 FPS on every setting maxed out (resolution scale 100%).Last but not least the Story is very interesting and will keep you playing the game because you want to find out and explore everything this game has to offer. I won't spoil anything at this point but believe me, you don't want to stop playing ;)All in all if you hesitate to try this game or not - just buy it, believe me you won't regret it!

content:
Posted: August 3, 2016
												So If your looking to play this game I would say go for it when it's on sale, especially if you want to play games that are VR Compatible. I played the game all the way through in just about 20 hours. The game has a set story line which is good in some ways. You are allowed to explore areas to your leisure, but you do have to be aware of how hot and cold it is as well as how fed and hydrogenated you are, as this is a survival game. Something important to note this is also a HORROR/SUSPENSE game. So don't play this game if you don't like going into scary tunnels with dangerous traps and animal/plant life. You may be wondering what exactly about the game is Horror/Creepy like, well let me tell you (SPOILER ALERT), there is a part of the game where you are in a certain underground chamber and there are dead alien babes that are walking around and looking at you and making noise. But they only move when your not looking, so when you look behind you, you see that they have all moved closer. (Don't worry they don't actually do anything if they catch you, it's just creepy.) So if your okay with that then you will be okay with playing this game. Pros: Good StoryGreat Voice ActingGreat Graphics (If you can use the highest)A Lot of MysteryLarge amount of ground to ExploreGreat gadgetsCons:No World MapCan't fight anything.Crafting is limited.No tutorials are given with regard to interactions with certain hostile environments or animals/plants.Some game factors are completely unrealistic or annoyingly stupid: (For instance the fact that you can survive in 200 Degrees Fahrenheit for a while before getting heatstroke, The fact that Heatstroke can only be fixed by going somewhere extremely cold or by using a med-pack. You can't empty out a bottle of gas (Bottle of water with gas in it) unless you are using it to craft specifically. Some puzzles require you to place water in containers to open doors and you can't use the water from the Rare Wine Bottle that says it has water in it to open those puzzle doors.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2016
												It might be the whisky, but I'll give a thumbs up to The Solus Project. There are however, quite a few BUTs involved. Why? Because Solus is a bit of everything and that will definately not please everyone. It has a bit of survival BUT it's far from hardcore. There is a lot of food and water to be found and if you build your personal warm/cold orb of doom (which I didn't because I'm a muppet) you should be fine. There's not a lot more to surviving than that. I didn't mind the casual survival as I am more of an explorer. Luckily there's a bit of exploring to be done BUT it doesn't really yield anything interesting. Although I'm a bit of a completionist the game didn't really give enough incentive to go looking for all secrets. The paths to the objectives are quite linear. No fancy-pansy-teleporting-swimming-through-acid shortcuts (yes I tried :).At times the game can be quite immersive. I liked the way down at the start of the game. The recordings your character makes are also quite nice (even though it's not interactive). Face it, you would be freaked out when YOUR spaceship was shot down RIGHT? Helas, most of the pages you find are quite boring. The story is ok, not horribly intricate but enough to make me play till the end to see what would happen. As I am not easily impressed by storylines I assume many people will think it is (and I quote) "awesome". The graphics are pretty decent. I enjoyed them but after seeing them again and again they did loose a bit of their splendor. The devs are quite fond of caves. At times it reminded me of the Fallout 3 metro tunnels. Quite exciting at first, but BUT damn there are a lot of them.Should I mention the UI? I probably shouldn't. It feels really consoly. Creating/combing items is a bit awkward. Inventory management if I can call it that is the same. Could've been optimized for PC. Then again, there's not a lot to build/combine so this won't bug you as much as you might think (the fact that there's not a lot to build might).But Elmo, you are the grumpy grump. Didn't you hate anything about this game? Well yes I did, how nice of you to ask! First of all, you are very, very slow in this game. This does NOT bode well for the human race. Second. The teleporter, oh the teleporter. What intern programmed that feature? In a glass half full scenario: you will get pretty good at making trick shots because the normal trajectory is so horrible.So all in all, a pretty decent walking sim. If you're not planning to get into every nook and cranny you might want to pick it up at a discount.Elmo, the grumpy lootmaster signing offps. did I mention getting stuck between pillars of basalt?

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												TLDR: This game is amazing.I am playing without VR, as a regular first person shooter style. In the dark, with only myself and my glowing monitor even vaguely visible.My first moments in the game was inspiring. I had no idea what I was doing, the world felt harsh and hostile and I was in awe of the sheer scale.I felt lost. Alone.It was perfect.The sound and ambience sucks you in. Audio cues tell you what's going on. I highly suggest headphones, surround sound if you've got 'em.The handcrafted nature of the world is obvious. Beautiful landscapes. Contoured caves. Convoluted secrets.The world itself is your enemy. Heat. Cold. Starvation.Storms.  The storms themselves are a sight to behold of terrifying proportions.Any of these can kill the careless and unprepared.Though the game itself is not particularly brutalizing and there are several levels of difficulty in which to choose from.  I played on balanced, and it was just that. Balanced well.  You don't grind to survive.  You scavenge and prepare and make decisions.I actually made a terrible decision at one point in the game, losing my torch. I battled constantly threatening hypothermia, but with a little tact, I managed to make it past the area.  Even if you make a mistake, not all is lost.Be smart when playing, and it's not a frustrating adventure in finding out how angry a game can make you.  It will take you on a fantastic story driven adventure.The only small issue I find with the game is that it's incredibly difficult to backtrack. The cave systems are winding mazes, and if you're an idiot like me and don't get all the tower pieces in each area, you're going to have a bad time.Because of this, I have not yet finished the ending, but the journey so far has been easily worth what I paid for the game.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game casts you into the cosmos, stranded on an unknown world. The elements of survival (while basic) make it all the more realistic. I expect them to add a lot more items and functions to that system. That being said; the weather system is the best I have ever seen in a game; the random tornados, lighting and meteors especially knock your socks off! Beyond that the thrill of navigating a (seemingly) dead world is fantastic-even more so when you realize the ancient civilization that  once lived there. Uncovering their history is exciting. I would only say that the game is rather linear (which makes since considering the discover/progression of the game). That being said I highly recommend this for anyone who wants to feel trapped on a planet.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												I really enjoyed this game and played most of it in VR.  Here are the things I like about it:1. Tornadoes - The tornadoes are scary and the music that comes with them make them even more terrifying.2. Nice graphics and great sound effects and music.   I loved the cave with all the giant, glowing mushrooms.  I also loved the giant moon, that was my favorite scene.3.  First person and very immersive.4.  Very Interesting story line.  The further you get into the game, the more you learn about the alien race that used to inhabit the planet and what happened to them.Tips on playing:1. When in doubt, use your teleporter.  It serves as more than just for teleporting you back to a cave when the weather gets bad.    2. Food is everywhere, you don't have to stock up on it too much.3. Don't swim with your torch ;)**Warning Spoilers below**Suggestions for improvement (I know the game is no longer early access, but I think these would have made the game even better):1. There should be a suggestion in the beginning to use your teleporter to get into the first cave.  I was completely clueless on this and didn't think I could shoot it in there for some reason.  I actually stopped playing for quite some time because I got stuck on this and couldn't find the solution.2.  The player seems to care less about the aliens he actually encounters.  For example, when you get to the top of the windmill and activate it and then make a log afterwards, he says absolutely nothing about the reptilian/predator looking entity that was chained up trying to literally bite your head off.  I think that would have been important to note because it is the first alien contact you have.  That was not the only instance.  He reported once that he "thought" he saw one when in fact it was standing right in front of you.  Unless you really weren't paying attention, it's impossible to miss.  That probably should have been said the first time you saw one for the very first time standing in a window (which he said nothing about!).3.  I know VR is "expiremental" but there was some shimmering lights around plants and some other things that threw off the feel and graphics a bit.4. There should be more than just the 15 components around the islands.  I thought I got them all but was left 1 short.  I tried my best to retrace my steps, which took forever! but was not able to find that last one.  Had to use a cheat command.  Also, not everyone thoroughly searches everything, which is why there should be an abundance of the parts.5. There should be manual save options so I can go back to an older save.  I ran into a couple issues and was not able to load an older file so had to use cheat commands (like the time a pillar got stuck up on a ledge somehow).
