content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												I played this in VR and even though VR-mode is currently only in Beta, I found the experience amazing and enthraling.  Would totally recommend it.The sense of presence in some of the areas (particularly the caves) is huge.  And when various monsters appear (which happens only after a few hours of peaceful exploration) then they have a real sense of danger.  Particularly when you are waiting in the dark listening to a monster passing, and afraid to equip your torch for fear it sees it.  And yet there aren't really any jump-scares, just occassional areas which give a sense of dread.  This is an exploration game, not a horror game. --Edit to my original review to state that the VR inventory has been updated and now works great.  And this, combined with the dev's visible work in this area, means that I am confident that the remaining VR issues (which are not so annoying as to detract from the whole marvelous experience) will be ironed out.  I don't want niggling mention of small issues to mar this review and potentially put people off a purchase, so I've removed them from the review and into their proper place as a bug report.So much have I enjoyed Solus that on upgrading from my 770 GTX (which actually ran the game fine on lower settings) to a new 1070 GTX, that I started my 10 hour campain again from scratch in all its graphical quality!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												This game is amazing! The "story", if you want to call it that, is good. It is literally exploration, and only what you seek out and find, that makes the story. What i am trying to say is, you can basically run through the game and not read anything or pay minimal attention to the things around you, but why would you do this?But now a few other, minor things that should be mentioned, for example the performance.It uses the Unreal Engine but sometimes stutters really bad, that has to do with the sky and ocean reflection updates.If you receive these kind of stutters, then there is a fairly easy fix for it:go and open:steamapps\common\TheSolusProject\Solus\Config\DefaultGame.iniin the config find and change following from True to False:AllowOceanUpdate=FalseAllowSkylightUpdate=FalseThis will help a lot, also go and enable FXAA in your driver settings, if you are on an nvidia card, this did help tremendously with my frames per second, boosting it from 45-50 to 90-95fps.TL;DR: Good game for little money for all explorers and spelunkers that know how to basic computer

content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												Let's start off with some backstory, just to be clear...When I was 8, the first Unreal game released. Not Unreal Tournament, no... Unreal Gold Edition with Return to Na'Pali. A campaign game, very shooter focused but also many RPG elements. Prior to Unreal Gold, my experience with gaming was purely simulators, mostly flight combat. I never owned a console, never experienced Zelda, but that game sold me on a genre I never knew existed. I completed the campaign and the expansion 4 times before downloading any modpack mini campaign I could find and playing those, too. Since then many games have released that had RPG elements which I've enjoyed. The newer Tomb Raiders, Fallout series, Elder Scrolls. I've loved them all, but none as passionately as that first, little-known game that truly taught me how epic a story a videogame could convey.Flash forward 18 years. I happen to be browsing Steam when a game pops up that seems to have some interest. "Okay" I say, as I watch the trailer like many before. "I'll give it a try, why not it looks entertaining"I had no idea what I was getting.I think the first hint was probably the crosses with the aliens everywhere. Not simple crosses, no... crosses for aliens with 4 arms. But why, when these aliens all have 2? Where had I seen such crosses before? Could it possibly be? Nali?Enter aliens. "Wait, is that a Skaarj?" "No but damn that's similar, and the staff reminds me an awful lot of the Krall..." Then I start thinking about the plot. A technologically advanced mysterious alien race which subjugates a physically more frail other alien race that is still primitive in development, and uses their technology like magic? Well okay, also familiar... At least they don't have to mine Tarydium.So I complete the game, hyped up and craving more, but also still curious about these glaring similarities... Come to find out in an interview the developer seems to share the same passion I do for a little known old game...Overall, I thought the added survival elements really helped modernize it over the inspiration. They are well balanced if you know what you are doing, and select the correct level of difficulty for your preferred playstyle. The added spookiness over UG was unexpected but welcome, and never quite the jump scare most people go for, but a more subtle reaction in the gut. Walking up to a corpse, seeing it lean upright and stare up at me as I stand next to it... I didn't jump back but had to utter aloud "Ohhhh no you did not just do that..."Honestly, the only thing I think this game is missing is an ASMD...Needless to say, I'll be raving about this one to friends for a while yet. The moment I get my Vive there will be a second playthrough happening.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Another survival game.Well, not just /another/. Solus Project is different because the surviving is on another planet. The sf backstory is pretty good, and the visuals are truly evocative of being on another world. The Unreal Engine does a good job here. Its not totally at a triple A level but its at least double A. The sound quality is good, music comes in small doses, usually during a "you done goodly" or "OMG" moment. Setting the game to Ultra really put some stress on my 980 ti, not sure if the game needs more optimization or what. As far as the game play goes, you really are in a survival situation, the planetary temps get horrifically cold at night and you need to keep up with food and hydration constantly. A little /too/ constantly because there is a lot to discover and just when your close to finding some secret you have to stop and go find a plant to eat. The game comes in three levels of difficulty. I've only tried Normal and it keeps you busy, hard must be hellacious. Theres a little phone/computer you carry that gives all your stats and reminders such as "User cold and wet" or "Starvation imminent". The crafting is pretty rudimentary, mostly using this object on that object to get a result, for example hitting a tin can to open it so you can eat the food inside. For this genre its got a lot going for it in terms of the story, but going back and forth between survival and exploration is a bit annoying. A good buy though, I reccomend if you want a different spin on the survival game genre.System Specs: Cpu: 4790K Gpu: Gigabyte 980 ti G1 Mem: 16 Gigs Crucial TacticalAddendum:I have to add on to this review. After you get away from the crash zone your "leash" to thesurvival part of the game gets longer. And theres much more interesting things to discover.I won't put any spoilers here but the feeling of things being /alien/ is nicely done.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
Product received for free
												I initially found The Solus Project to be visually enticing but difficult to get into. Interestingly enough, I approached each session of playing it with the same attitude. I sighed at the prospect of starting it up, but once I was in I found myself sufficiently immersed to keep on going until it was finally done. I felt the same about writing this review as well: unsure as to what I was going to write, but found plenty to write about once I started. Its level design and world building are great, its audiovisual style stellar, but it fails in making for a consistently solid gameplay experience. Don’t take that as a too harsh indictment of the game. If anything, The Solus Project is at its worst decent and a mark of wasted potential more than anything resembling a failure. It’s definitely one of the better survival experiences out there and others would do well to take a few pages from its book.Full Review Here: http://pressa2join.com/reviews/the-solus-project

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												TLDR: This game is amazing.I am playing without VR, as a regular first person shooter style. In the dark, with only myself and my glowing monitor even vaguely visible.My first moments in the game was inspiring. I had no idea what I was doing, the world felt harsh and hostile and I was in awe of the sheer scale.I felt lost. Alone.It was perfect.The sound and ambience sucks you in. Audio cues tell you what's going on. I highly suggest headphones, surround sound if you've got 'em.The handcrafted nature of the world is obvious. Beautiful landscapes. Contoured caves. Convoluted secrets.The world itself is your enemy. Heat. Cold. Starvation.Storms.  The storms themselves are a sight to behold of terrifying proportions.Any of these can kill the careless and unprepared.Though the game itself is not particularly brutalizing and there are several levels of difficulty in which to choose from.  I played on balanced, and it was just that. Balanced well.  You don't grind to survive.  You scavenge and prepare and make decisions.I actually made a terrible decision at one point in the game, losing my torch. I battled constantly threatening hypothermia, but with a little tact, I managed to make it past the area.  Even if you make a mistake, not all is lost.Be smart when playing, and it's not a frustrating adventure in finding out how angry a game can make you.  It will take you on a fantastic story driven adventure.The only small issue I find with the game is that it's incredibly difficult to backtrack. The cave systems are winding mazes, and if you're an idiot like me and don't get all the tower pieces in each area, you're going to have a bad time.Because of this, I have not yet finished the ending, but the journey so far has been easily worth what I paid for the game.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
												Wow.  This game provides a bit more of what I had hoped "No Man's Sky" would provide.  Some real unique alien planetary exploration.  For some reason, I thought this game was considered a sequal to "The Ball", but you won't miss anything if you don't play "The Ball" and it's really a completely different type of a game.  "The Ball" being a entirely ball based purely puzzle game, and "The Solus Project" much more of an epic adventure survival game.  "The Solus Project" comes with three difficulty levels.  "Casual" - more for explorers that want to experience the story, but don't want to micromanage for survival.  "Normal" - this is what I'm playing.  You have to survive in adverse conditions, things like heat, cold, food, water and wetness all affect your heatlh.  You also have a visual hud that guides you through your most inportant taskes.  And "Hardcore" which is like "Normal" but you don't get hud icons and hints for what to do next.  I have seen it mentioned on the forums that real survival enthusiests tend to think "Normal" is too easy, and "Hardcore" is much more enjoyable.  Me...   I like survival, and I like not getting frusterated because I want to get to the next part of the story, as well as see much of the world... so I think "Normal" is about right for me.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								Surprisingly good game if you like an exploration game where everything is atmosphere and story based. Although its not under the genre it should be considered a mystery game as well.This is a very good exploration game where you alone are exploring this alien planets surface. Most of the gameplay involves the environment of the levels itself. When it comes to level design and feel this game is unique and i can't think of anything similar to it. The environments design is absolutely cool with full day and night cycles with dynamic weather(plus tornados). The surface of the planet does have an alien feel and what you find on the planet is definantly interesting and engaging. The levels span from beautiful all the way to eerie. The detail put into the alien appearance of the surface and structures is amazing especially when it comes to the alien technology that you will come across.As you explore you find mysterious pieces of a civilization whos history you piece together through writings and pictures. This story requires you to manually put the words and pictures together to get things to make sense. It pretty much is like learning of ancient civilizations on earth through the artifacts we've uncovered. This method is of story telling is not used often so you'll be in for a treat with this one.This is a casual game that is definantly worth a try. Unless you need continious action because it is very lonely on this planet.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												I had played the first few parts of this game on a monitor before knowing I would even be buying a Vive. I really like the game then. Now that you've added VR support and I've had a chance to play this game on the Vive I have to say that makes it outstanding!This game is in a unique position as it is a full - complete game!  In a world of early access and tons of people rushing to bring a product to market, this game is a clear winner for anyone looking for a full VR game to play.Super job devs with the quick adaption of VR support.  With all of your great game design experience and now adding VR, I hope you make another game with VR from the ground up - it could only be amazing.My only suggestion for this game is that there are some areas which are hard to spot in VR that were easier to see with a monitor, I'm thinking of a low cave entrance for example.  The last thing I wanted to add -there are some things in this game that playing on a monitor were clearly a problem but now - in VR - have their creepy scary factor upped quite a bit. I like it!

content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												Wow.  That's all I can say for what I've experienced in this game with the Vive.  The environment is incredibly immersive and really gives you a sense of being on another planet.  It is just amazing.  There is one particular weather event that really gave me a true sense of helplessness the first time it happened.  I've only played for 5 hours so far so the story line is still unfolding but it really has nailed the core aspects of exploring a new planet while having to survive on what you can find.You especially owe it to yourself to experience this if you have a Vive.Update: Just wanted to give a little update after spending a lot more time with the game and using the lastest updated version tonight.  The game in its current state is one of the best games on the Vive.  It really is an incrediby powerful experience because of how well designed the alien environment is.  Now with the latest update the game is much easier to play and lose yourself in because there aren't any awkward control or gameplay issues to get in the way.   I really can't recommend this game enough.

The graphics are pretty good, the planet is errie and a lot of fun to explore at first.Unfortunately, the game eventually runs of how interesting things to have you do. Survival elements are pretty light and don't give much in the way of gameplay, there's a few nice puzzles and creepy moments, but for every good moment there is yet another "find the next key" moment.In the end the Solus project is a beautiful and intriguing but fairly shallow game, where you spend way too much time just wandering aimlessly looking for the next key hidden somewhere so that you can eventually make progress

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								I just want to say - - I'm not the biggest survival game fan - -   But when I watched a "Let's Play" of this - I was seriously intrigued - - I only watched about 10 minutes of it - -  basically up til the guy finished talking his head off and built his first torch.    So I decided to pull the trigger and check it out for myself.   I'm seriously glad I did.   This game has a uniqueness to it that really resonates with me.  It's a puzzle game, exploration game, survival game, but it's wrapped into a neat little package that doesn't feel forced or over-developed.  It's very much a game that tells it's story through the environment.  Through discovering remnants of your crashed ship to reading diary's and heiroglyphs left behind by the alien civilzation.  None of this is particularly original, but the way it's handled is very well done I think, and the writing seems pretty well.   I can tell there are some very particular characters being developed behind the scenes and I can't wait to learn more.   I can't wait to uncover the secrets this world holds and why oh why some giant green ball of energy blew up my ship.  It doesn't really feel so much like a survival game as it does an adventure game.  With a sincere focus and direction and an obvious goal.   You aren't just dropped onto a planet naked and left to your devices.  There is a mystery to be uncovered, there are diary's to be found, heiroglyphs to be read, other trapping more inherent with a game like Gone Home or Myst.  The survival aspect I feel just adds to the challenge of solving the puzzles and uncovering the mystery.  The crafting mechanic that's seamlessly implemented into the survival system is very concise and isn't jumbled up with a bunch of silly recipes and experience point curves.  You aren't left fiddling with menu's or having to wait things to happen.  It just works, and it's simple and it's right in front of you. This is a game I would highly recommend to anyone who enjoys adventure games.  It's got beautiful world and what looks to be a beautiful mystery just waiting to be solved.  And I can't wait to solve it.   If you're looking for something fresh to play and don't mind Early Access - give this one a shot.   I'm sure you will be as impressed as I am.   Stellar game and it's future is looking very bright.And by the way - - Be mindful of of the weather.   Meteor Showers and Tornados will definitely ruin your day.

												Playing on the HTC Vive, this is the most enchanting and atmospheric experience I have had in VR to date. It is also the first long form game I have played on the Vive. The Solus Project has made me even more excited about the greater depth of games that will come to VR over time. To be able to play and explore for hours with a developing storyline uses virtual realities ability to enhance the emotional involvement of the user within games and shows how good development can lead to a very powerful gaming experience. Extremely enjoyable in VR, highly recommended!

												Great game,.. sound concept,.. fluid gameplay,.. good instructions on how to interact / control. The random exploration driven events are ♥♥♥♥ing awesome,.. graphics are OK,.. the atmosphere is Gorgeous,.. sounds/sky detail 10/10 water/grass 6/10 rest of environment 8.5/10 character interacivity 9/10 feel of game / player motion 8/10 (it's not Dayz or Rust in feel and motion but it kills ARK's clunky♥♥♥♥♥gameplay) the story is told in journal pages that are actually pretty interesting and make me want to explore to find out more (and i ♥♥♥♥ing hate "find-a-page-to-continue" games),.. if you liked Myst back in the day,.. or are into explorative / narrative driven event games that have a good amount of open puzzles added to it,.. this is your game,.. if you are looking for a new COD or fast paced shooter,.. not this one,.. but if you enjoyed games like The vanishing of Ethan Carter, and think that they needed survival elements added to it to give it a more full in depth feel... then this is a must have...

content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								I see lots of good reviews, so maybe it's just an issue with my machine/Vive - I tried the game on Oculus DK2 originally, and it seemed pretty smooth back then (2 months or so ago?) - I saw it now shows up for Vive, so gave it a try. The intro video was smooth, but soon as I was in the actual game, the frame rate dropped to nothing and was really jerky moving around - had to shut it down fast because it hurt. I started on Ultra graphics, and then tried with low graphics, with the same issue. So you understand, I use an i7 4790K CPU, and a 980ti video card. It's not a PC power issue. Is this only happening on my Vive? I have to mark it down for now, because it's just unplayable on Vive so far (for my testing), regardless of the graphics settings.--edit-- changing this to a thumb up, since it seems this is a vsync issue they are working on and the game is playable if you disable vsync in the game files.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2016
												This is a Virtual Reality review of the game using the HTC Vive.I usually really enjoy Survivor/Crafting type games but playing Solus felt more like a chore than anything. Finding food and water is actually incredibly easy, so the only real problem comes down to monitoring your temperature (I was hypothermic for hours after swimming in frozen water but there's so many medpacs around that I was never worried about dying) inventory management and avoiding bad weather. Also light sources are important for exploring caves and things, but it's easy to run out and get stuck in a dark cave, forcing you to blindly teleport yourself out. Some of the weather effects are really cool and scary (tornados, meteor showers, etc.) but walking around the huge environement in VR is absolutely not fun at all. It takes way too much time no matter what type of movement you're using.After an hour or so, I decided I would keep playing as I'd already payed the money and wanted to see where the story was going. However, around the 3 hour mark I've encounted some type of bug or issue where it's not showing me the next obective and I've become totally stuck and unable to progress. I could restart the game but I have absolutely no desire to do so. I would refund it but I've already played it too long.I tried playing the game in non-VR just on a regular monitor with mouse and keyboard, and the game seemed a lot more playable, but still somewhat mediocre (and ran like♥♥♥♥♥♥on my decently high end PC).It's too bad because I really wanted to love this game and certain aspects of it are good, but overall it's fairly mediocre and doesn't feel at all like a game that was built with VR in mind.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have started playing this game without knowing what to expect. The thing I was more afraid of was the optimization thing. You know, UE4 isn't exactly canon yet as far as I know. Still, the game runs smoothly no problem, everything maxed. Now back to the game: reading all info regarding your system and the environment that matters in a extremely well crafted and properly designed mobile device is definitely good and helps immersion. You can tell the developers do care about details, since temperature will raise and decrease according to your placement (right under a breaking sun or taking advantage of cooler shades? This matters as well). You sweat? You have to drink more. -15° and you decide to jump in the ocean? Hypothermia, here we go! But what I like the most is that The Solus Project awards exploration while being story driven at the same time. This is not one of those games where "you make the fun" (or I'd rather say "we don't care, so please make your story!"). As far as I have played: good graphics, good atmoshere, decent narrative and good gameplay!

Early Access Review
								With only a day after release this may be prone to change but as of now my opinion on this wonder filled magnificant game is a good one. I'll admit I'm a sucker for space type, survival, and exploration with this game blending them together perfectly. First the story without spoils: You're stranded on a foreign world and need to assemble a radio type tower to signal a satellite all while exploring the mysteries and dangers that lie on it. This story along side amazing gameplay and vastly superior graphics?_____ This is the part where I say 10/10 but I can't really since after all it's still an early access and if I know my early access survival games then this could shoot downhill fast but I highly doubt it with this one. All in all it's worth the low cost and in time a 10/10 worthy game.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												[VR Review]I got a Vive VR headset, and this was the first game I wanted to try it on. Anyways, first impressions were very good - the VR experience is very amazing. The controls took a bit of getting used to (although keep in mind that this could just be because I'm new to VR).My current graphics card is an AMD Fury, but even with that I had to lower the settings to around medium quality overall to stop the framerate tearing I was seeing. The calibration and aiming controls for interacting with the environment work well, and I ran into no problems with those.The only major issue I had was that I could not figure out how to open the inventory. All the other buttons worked correctly (i.e. interacting, movement, jumping, etc.), but no matter what I tried the inventory button wouldn't work. I may have been using it wrong I suppose, but I doubt it, as I'm already very farmiliar with the gameplay of The Solus Project. The radial menu for inventory opens correctly for crafting and interacting with other objects, too.But besides that one issue, it's a truely excelent VR experience! -------------------------------------------<ORIGINAL NON-VR REVIEW>[The review was getting so many edits to it, and was getting really messy, so I'm doing a complete rewrite...]First impressions were a bit clunky - it took me a while to get used to some of the controls and elements of the game, but I started having fun after that with a lot of the puzzles. The game reminds me the most of "Myst/Riven", and the puzzles are somewhat challegning. That being said, the "challenege" of the puzzels is mostly the challenge of finding the next switch far too often lol...In any case, if you are looking for an atmospheric puzzle game with a deep intriguing story, I high heartily recommend this game. It is a lot buggier than any other "Early Access" game I've played, though.Some of the biggest annoyances for me are that you get ONE save slot (which can be TERRIBLY gamebreaking for any number of reasons when a save occurs at a TERRIBLE time), and there is no real way to completely turn off the "survival" elements of the game for people (like me) who would much rather just "explore" without having to manage an absurd amount of "survival" elements...Additionally, the falling damage is ABSURDLY unfair and broken - your legs must be made of chewed up toothpicks, because a 3 foot fall causes falling damage ffs, and it scales in damage EXPONENTIALLY fast, so that anything above 15 feet or so just plain up MURDERS you.THANK GOD that the collision detetction is ETREMELY sound, so at least I'm not dying because I slid down a slope all the time like some other games I could mention! n.nUOn the plus side, it's SO REFRESHING to see a game that DOESN'T use "invisible walls" all over the place (the ONLY time I ever ran into one was when I tried to swim very far out into the ocean, and I guess that's fair - it's hard to come up with any other way to add a barrier in that situation).Also, the game runs flawlessly in "Fullscreen Mode" - it just freezes up and lags like mad in "Windowed Mode".So I DEFINATLY recommend you try this game! I've been wanting a fun and challenging puzzle game for a long time (one that DOENS'T include tons of "horror" elements, whcih all the morte recent ones usually have, sadly...).

number of helpful: 10 of 20 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								A superb and highly atmospheric survival game, The Solus Project is something like a great science fiction novel. In that, it has a story worth your attention and every single page is yours to interpret.       Seemingly stranded on a mysterious distant planet (no spoilers!) you must find out what happened. Supplies, shelter, cover from an approaching storm await your travels. You must craft and explore being mindful of your trusty PDA companion known as "Wilson". Filled with environmental details, spectacular sounds, superb music this novel of a game is more than worth your time and effort. Very highly recommended. I cannot wait for more from this "Early Access" game and the studio behind it.   Pros:-Outstanding atmosphere-Superb audio to include voice acting and music-Interesting and meaningful story so far-Great graphics & very unique overall design-Smooth play control  Cons:-UI/User Interface is a bit confusing from the start-PDA seems static. Not able to zoom in and look at it or "review" discoveries/lore-Some fauna could use more detail. The "eye plants" and cave vines for example

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Starts off with a nice story line. You begin on an alien planet and need to survive by gathering supplies into your backpack and/or gathering them in a cave.The nights are very cold and the days are warm, so at night you need to keep warm. You do this by finding the necessary supplies then using them to stay safe. Once you do so, you can begin to explore more safely.There are puzzles, traps, secrets, and more along the way. Backstory is provided via pages strewn around from the wreakage. Some story is also provided by alien structures/monuments. The rest of the story is provided by voice.The sound effects and music are all really good and help pull you into it.As this review is from Early Access, there's currently some bugs. Nothing major.But, some annoying things could be better such as when getting wet its quite difficult to read the in-game UI as there's these big water droplets in the way that may not be moving out of the way.The water droplet animation is REALLY bad.And some other things... what they improve or fix in the end just isn't known at this time.You can jump and move around at will. Into the water you go! The ONLY invisible walls I've noticed are deep at sea.There's plenty more to find out for yourself...Overall, definitely recommended. I haven't wanted to play a survival based game until now. This one is good.(Its best to have a short review for this game as the more you read the more its going to take away from the discovery aspect of it which is very important here.)

content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												This game didn't live up to my expectations. I expected a lot of exploration on another planet, maybe some unusual plot twists. Unfortunately while I really had to walk a lot on this planet all the exploration seemed too simplistic. A shrine here, 2 idols there. And why do I have to spend so much time in the dark caverns? It is dark, damp and unpleasant in the caverns. This game is a little too psychological for my taste. If you are looking for exploration and don't want to explore dark caverns for hours this game is not for you. But if you like psychological games with some pressure and a dark atmosphere you can try this game.

Posted: March 27
												I'm genuinely surprised by the "Very Positive" review average for this game. I played it in VR using the Oculus Rift and was bored to tears. The problem is that this is a game that relies solely on atmosphere, given that nothing happens 99% of the time, and doesn't have the sense of presence that an experience like this requires. This kind of game can work, and incredibly well when put together in a compelling way. However, what's here is uninteresting and serves as a rare case of a game that makes you feel like you played longer than you actually did. A good game feels the opposite.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2016
												I guess this game is designed for PC/xbox play, and I hate to say that I don;t think it translates so well to a VR experience.  The interface is quite clumsy, using 'look' type cursor mechanic in several places that can be an uncomfortable experience to manage.  The scenery looks nice in the videos, and I'm sure it is just as stunning when played on a flat screen, but appears to be quite lacking when viewed through the lower res of a VR headset.   Movement through the VR environment is clumsy, and use of Vive controllers makes menu and action controls unintuitive and cludgy.  I think a bit of a rework on the VR support would make this a MUCH better experience for the Vive!

content:
Posted: January 7
												Goldfish. Yup, you're reading that right. Goldfish. Apparently, they have memories which only last a matter of seconds. How someone figured that out I have no idea. Perhaps someone taught the fish morse-code or two-bubbles for 'yes' and one for 'no' but anyway. They're lucky really. You stick them into a bowl around a foot wide, put in some rocks and a castle and they'll find it endlessly exciting. "Ooh, rocks! Never seen that before!." "Ooh a castle! Never seen that before!" "Ohh rocks! never seen that before!" Repeat ad infinitum.Goldfish would love Solus Project. If they had fingers... and could remember the controls long enough to use them.At first Solus Project appears to have it all. Great atmosphere, interesting scenery, a mysterious planet and spectacular environmental effects which vary from tidal patterns and dynamic weather to tornados and meteor showers. It's a walking simulator with some survival elements thrown in to keep things interesting... or at least, it attempts to. Just for a moment, go look at the screenshots. Now understand that what you see there is what you'll be looking at for the rest of the game. The first island looks like the second, the caves look the same, the alien ruins look the same. It's that goldfish in the bowl but you don't have the ability to forget that what you see 10hrs into the game is largely the same as what you saw in the first hour. When you look at the game, you may think that this is an open world. It isn't, it's a linear environment that ironically loops back upon itself. So not only is it repetitive, it also makes the player retread through areas they already visited. The level design of the game itself also has a number of issues. The translocator teleportation device is intended to allow you to traverse the landscape more easily but handles really poorly. It's like throwing a metal cooking tray with all of the dead weight you would expect but then, almost paradoxically, it bounces off of surfaces like it was made of rubber. Worse still is the fact that it can come to a stop on an angled surface that is actually too steep for the player to stand on, so when you teleport to it you slide down. There are also numerous instances where the translocator will allow you to teleport into a space where you are trapped. This frequently happens with the pentagon shaped pillars you see the developers have reused again and again throughout the environments. When trapped by the world geometry in this way your only option is to quit out and load up your last save game. As you can imagine, this deters a player from exploring which works contrary to the point of the game.As the developers themselves have said, it is the players fault if they get themselves into 'bad spots' and not their responsibility to build the world to prevent these problems as any attempt to do so would be "even more immersion breaking". So no doubt there are many more ways for the player to get stuck, break progression by going off the intended route or get trapped in world geometry throughout the game because the devs feel that it is better for players to get stuck and have to reload their last save point or use the command console to fix the problem than to fix issues with the game.It also appears that the world is also "quite similar visually by design" which they feel excuses why it feels repetitive.All in all, Solus Project is far from worth picking up even on sale. A lot of effort has gone into the games atmosphere but there just isn't anything to make it interesting to play after the first couple of hours. Hunting around for secret caves and bonuses which give 1% to a stat is also really poor design as the reward does not justify trudging around the intentionally repetative environments shining your torch into every dark corner to see if there is something tucked away off the clearly established route to the next area, I really wanted to enjoy the Solus Project - but saddly I'd need to be a goldish to do that.(edit - updated middle of review to reflect the fact that the devs did not intend to create platforming sections although they exist and that Wrenchse (a developer) has stated that the problems with level design "might mean that people get themselves into bad spots" but that "we do think that is more preferable than having invisible boxes blocking stuff off".)

content:
Posted: February 22
												A real diamond in the rough, that I wish I could reccomend. The underlying story is intriguing and keeps you tethered for more, but it's revealed almost entirely through written text. Some of the environments reveal the mystery, but the player direction and dialogue are dumbfounded and entirely disconnected.It would be reasonable to assume that the dialogue was recorded far too early and then neglected. Leaving you bewildered when the idiot protagonist ever opens his mouth. Whilst this alone shouldn't ruin a game, the final act is entirely construed from this. The player is leashed to a moron, sighing every step of the way as we slowly drag our feet to the inevitable conclusion. The ending leaves a lot to be desired, and speaks volumes of the overall experience. "Why even bother?"

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												Disclaimer:  I played this on PC (non VR)  This game doesn't seem to know what it wants to be.On one hand, it's an exploration / adventure game,  which makes sense seeing as it is the spiritual sequel to "The Ball" which had a heavy emphasis on puzzles and adventure, with nary a survival element to be found. Unfortunately it seems as though Sjoerd realized that it was 2016 , and survival games were popular, so he shoe-horned in a bunch of ill-fitting survival mechanics which do very little to make the game enjoyable.  I'd go as far as to say that they shoot it in the foot.Swimming will make your character cold and wet, and quickly kill you from hypothermia.  Not that there's much to see underwater anyway, it's mostly just an empty expanse of sand.  Your character will constantly complain about needing food, so you will be forced to bash open tin cans with rocks and repetetively munch on the contents until the suit stops ♥♥♥♥♥ing at you.  There are text logs scattered throughout the world which you can discover with your "WILSON" (LOL Castaway reference!) device.  They aren't very interesting. They say first impressions are everything,  and this game doesn't make a very good one. It is fairly mediocre looking with low poly assets and low resolution textures.  It somewhat compensates for this with a stylized look that was also present in "The Ball" (textures tend to look hand painted), but the best I could say about it is that it looks passable.  Kind of like a better than average looking Unreal Engine 3 game ( Bulletstorm came to mind in spots)  Given that it needs to run at a high framerate to support VR devices, this isn't a huge surprise.  Don't expect your jaw to be dropping to the floor here.Fairly dissappointed in this one.   It was developed by an indie dev I respect, and I *want* to like it, but It's just not grabbing me.  Maybe I'll give it another try another time, but for now, I'd recommend that if you want an exploration / survival game that is actually decent try Subnautica or The Long Dark instead.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												Short answer:Trite and predictable story, puzzles to solve aren't really puzzling, just busy work, with a survival system that has all the same problems as most do.Heh they even did the predictable 'horror' trope of one part of the game following you around with laughing baby doll things, in space...With hard settings for survival, you seem to barely last 5 minutes without apparently dying of dehydration. Puzzles are mostly avoid bear traps and flame-shooting things to get a key, or other dvice to make another thing open. P.S. why does a supposedly advanced race need bear traps and other floor-triggered things? I mean, the next stage up is leaving out curdled milk for me to drink while I'm randomly dying of dehydration, no?There are also some core issues with the level handling, which repeats areas. But, at a couple points it loops you back through where you came from, where there are 3+ routes to take and it isn't ultimately clear, because sometimes the forward-vector breaks, which means you may run in circles for 30 minutes+ before you find what it should have been pointing at. Fun. Or when something gets triggered but your view of that thing is obscured when it happens and it tells you to follow that thing...so...you wander until you figure it out...equally fun.All-in-all, not worth the money spent on it.

												I'm sure the basic game experience is wonderful, but the barrier to entry for playing this in VR is too high IMO.You are met with a barrage of several pages of text trying to explain the buttons and how to play before the game starts and expected to remember it all at once and just get stuck in.There are no simple usability niceties like labels which appear near the controllers pointing to different buttons labelling their functions (it's something I first saw with tilt brush and have since seen in some games too).I'll come back and try it again when I notice a VR related update and revise my review if things have been fixed, but as it is I would not recommend the game, for VR playing at least.

Early Access Review
								Graphics are very good (Unreal Engine 4).Sound effects are very good and some nice scary effectsIf you play on easy the survival aspect is somewhat lost. the game is more of an explorer game. content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								A fantastic and immersive story driven survival game, The Solus Project is something special in a world filled with survival sandboxes. Stranded on an alien world, humanity's dwindling hope for survival must uncover the mysteries of an ancient civilization while battling a hostile environment, and solving strange puzzles.Graphically, the game is amazing. The landscapes are alien and beautiful, and the night sky is breathtaking.The music and sound effects add a level of eeriness to the world that really drives home the feeling that you are not on Earth.The gameplay is survival with food, water, sleep, and body temperature all while balancing the need to always progress and explore.All in all, it is a satisfying experience.

Early Access Review
								So I finished up quite a bit of TSP before I decided to write this. The idea is new, and very immersive. I do wish there'd be combat, but the entire puzzle aspect of the game is well developed and can stand on its own. The world is immersive, and there's a very real sense of isolation that is invaluable in bringing the game to life, but not to the point of horrifying. There's  a sense of fear of what's over the horizon, and the weather anomalies really help to highlight that this is a world untamed by humanity.Please finish this game. I want to see what's over that horizon you guys keep hinting at!

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												In VR, the game is incredibly bad performing. On my system it runs with >60 fps on highest settings at 1920x1200 in the normal mode, but in VR it's stuttering when I go beyond the lowest settings. VR needs a serious performance update to be feasible. Lowest options will make UE4 (one of the most advanced engines in existence) look worse than UE2 from more than 10 years ago (which is not exactly furthering the immersion), stuttering will get you motion sickness.Games of this kind have to be played standing (except you have a solution for the headsets cord wrapping around you and your seat), without being able to freely rotate you will get uncomfy very fast. The devs are working on the neccessary adjustments for inventory handling, but at the moment they are not released and you have to rifle through all your pesky items every time you need something. The VR controls do not allow strafing (walking sideways), which is very annoying as you have to rotate all the time to make a step around an object (which may give you a headache over the time), will hopefully be fixed soon.While The Solus Project offers an interesting world to immerse yourself, the technical side of the game in VR is severely lackluster at the moment. I'd recommend to put it on your wishlist and wait for the neccessary patches to be implemented.Review will be updated as the game was.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												The game looks amazing, and has it's "Holy crap!" moments.  But for me and a few other people, it has one critical flaw.  We're unable to save the game, and when we change areas our inventory completely vanishes.  I put about 2 hours or so on my first playthrough, exploring the world, picking up loot and experiencing what the game has to offer.  Only to progress to the next area and have everything disappear.  "No big deal.  I saved just before I came in here so maybe it's just a bug."  I loaded my "saved" game found it dropped me right at the beginning in the water, with nothing actually saved.  The only thing it saved was the fact that I was no longer in the drop pod.  But I was going through the motions in the water as if I was leaving the pod...  I spent the next 3 hours of game time on record trying everything to find a fix for it.  Went to the developer's website and tried the suggestions there, went to the forums and got some assistance, but after awhile everything went dark.  So I deleted the game and have abandoned it since.  Buyer beware.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
												OK FREAKING AWESOME - how ever I can't get the hang of it. (controls are not logical - poorly implimented)  I have to say that VIVE games and demos so far have been so logical that the control is just intuitive.  NOT THIS GAME.  At the start I had a bit of that initial "AWE" that I had when I first used my vive for the first hour.   But the frustration of the controls eventually took over and ruined the experience.  I with this was a  "NEUTRAL" recommend as it's GREAT - but it's HORRIBLE but I suspect it will be fixed.  I crashes, I made it to a cave, a drank some water, I ate some food, I filled my water can... I was looking for shelter and I saw red spots and died. (I THINK) I seemed to be alive, but I no longer could move.  (or was that the lousy control?)    Graphics are stunning. I used AA and 150% and it was very nice and sharp. SOME text is hard to read on the tricorder but just bring it up to your face and it gets clear. (I had no issue with that and liked the high res text). I really liked what seemed like steam/breath from my mouth - and the VIVE head set feels like you're wearing a space mask.  I felt great, but the movement wasn't like walking and killed the emmersive feel. Rotating was click to turn. (wasn't into that) other games have good movement. (budget cuts!).   I think eventually I will get the hang of controls. But at this point (about 20 minutes into it) I have no desire to try again.  So  NO RECOMMENDATION to buying it.  HOWEVER it's freak'n cool - and I'm sure will have major complaints about control and I'm sure it will be fixed. (do I refund it until then?)  I hate hassling steam... so I'll prolly keep it and wait for a update.   BUY IT give is thumbs down to help make them fix it.    Looks and feels like a AAA title - but has indy (single man dev control) or worse.  ?  so like whats with that? No one beta tested it and complained?

								Nice graphics and  gameplay, but too short game 7.6 hrs and I waste a lot of time doing nothing and the game is finished.Only a few glitch I found. One is the smalls holes you can find in the path and if you use the teleport gun you can pass and walk in the wall. content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												Review for VIVE version only, this is no reflection on the base game which by all acounts looks pretty fantastic.I'll get this out of the way first; If youre buying this to play purely on the Vive, unfortuately I do not recommend the game in its current state, for a few reasons:- Many of the interaction nodes are superfluous. For example, if im holding the torch in my actual hand, theres no need to have an extra step to trigger the combination with the oil container - i should just be able to dip it in myself. Same goes for many of the other cutting/combining actions.- Similarly, a crouch control is unneccesary when I have full freedom of movement in real space- The scale of many items, as well as the terrain is far to too large. The PDA is a prime example, appearing approximately a foot long! I can move the thing up to my face so it doesnt need to be that big- Inventory management seems unnecessarily cumbersome with the current contol scheme - this is the main thing putting me off at the moment- It would be nice to have proper positional audio for the PDA (environmental sounds are already vaguely positional), as currently it appears as though the messageas are coming from inside your head rather than from the PDA itself and this is initially disorientating. (As an example, in the game Call of the Starseed, holding the tape player up to your ear sounds as if the tape player is really next to your ear)- I can walk though walls  (again, Call of the Starseed solves this problem quite well)In summery, if youre buying this to play on the Vive, wait a while untill its a little more polished, as in its current state it is not likely to be an enjoyable experience, in my opinion. Ill be sure to check back later to see how this develops as the gme itself looks rather good!

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Review for vive:I recommend getting this for the summer sale, but I strongly recommend against playing it for a while. The solus project should be good for vive, but it's terrible at the moment. The button assignments would probably be better if they were assigned on random. And the intventory mangement is the worst I can imagine. You basically have to "scroll" through all your items every time you want to switch. 1sec each item. And guess what happens when you get a bit frustrated? You scoll past it. Any way to scroll back? Nope! Have fun finding your item the next two minutes. Lots of fun to be had when you die of hypothermia after failing to equip and light your torch within FIVE minutes.Also, navigating is terribly hard in vr, especially with the teleport switching directions on you if you look to the side. I've spent hours trying to find the right way.But in the end, I still spent 11 hours in the game, which says a lot of the potential.Shame on the devs for releasing this for vr now. And shame on the devs for not removing the vr support before it's ready. I could have been a fan.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								Pure awesome!! I cant stress enough how good this is, especially, for an early access game. Too many times you see altered artwork of the worlds and videos that always llok 10x better than the actual game. So far, this game looks good, runs good, makes sense, et al. Everything that you expect out of a game - the basics - are already done correctly.Now, you crashed on a fairly hospitable planet. Lucky you. Plus you have one main tool and there are survival notes that got scattered all over the palce. So, the main tool you use is a PDA. And its a sweet little tool. It scans an object when you look at it, tells you how your health is, receives incoming satellite messages, recordings, is used as your save tool (sleeping will automatically save), and more. By more I mean after scanning the object you also have the option to pick the item up or craft it into something right there. Its totally fluid and you arent moving in and out of menus trying to do your next action. Centralizing the majority of the information into an easy to read smaller screen isnt an original idea. But this is done well. Its clear, concise, and smart. It sits on the bottom left of the screen. When you look down your hand automatically moves more of it into view. When you need to select other options, like sleeping, it can cover the full screen. What I like about this is that it feels and acts just like an important tool in the field should. Its not cumbersome but it also isnt hidden. Its that fine balance.World design is really nice so far. I didnt expect the caves to be so nicely done and well thought out. Also, after carefully climbing some rocks outside, I was absolutely sure that I would find something very valuable at the top. But I didnt. And I like that even more. It shows me that the devs arent predictable. So what if you scaled the mountain jumping from column to column. You know what you get? A can of food and a journal entry (ie the same stuff you find on the ground)Suggestion to Devs:I am gathering artifacts and other things that can be used for upgrades to my character (and I gueess my suit). However, Im not sure if Im not far enough along to be able to equip those things or if its done automatically. It says that you can upgrade your gear from the "Stats" page/option but even after selecting that page, and having acquired upgrades, it doesnt seem that I need to apply them or cant at this time. My only suggestion would be that since they do such a good job starting you off with everything else in the game I think there should be a message in the "stats" page the first time you open it. If you open it before you can upgrade yourself then a simple message of "This is the page that will allow you to upgrade your system, your PDA will notify you when it is time" and of course, if you dont open the page up before its necessary just having the PDA instruct you how to do it, like it does with everything else.Another cool thing: Ability to set your units of measure in the very beginning of the game. Im from 'Murica, so the metric system always makes me doing calculations on the fly. Two of my cars speedos read in kph so I am used to doing that while driving. But when it comes to liquid measures, forget about it. I can dmetric temps because of my computer rig. But I couldnt tell you what is a safe body temp in C. So I selected standard unit measures to be displayed in the game. Awesome little feature that they couldve easily overlooked or decided to keep out.Conclusion: Im super excited about this game. I saw the price and I didnt expect much at all. I expected bad character movement, glitchy, unpolished worlds, and I thought I would at least experience poor performance and crashes. Noe of that exists in Solus. It feels like a game that does not need to be in Early Access. You know what this reminds me of? It reminds me of "The Forest" but in outer space/landing on a foreign planet. Rather than a survival book you have a PDA. It looks similar too. Im so glad I purchased this. I consider the price to be a discount, even if you buy it at full price. And I cant wait to see where they go with this. I imagine that this type of story can always be added to. And Im hoping that the devs do that through DLC's later on.

												I played this for a while, but was really disappointed by how lackluster the survival elements were. I first thought something was up with how much food and water you could easily find on the first island, but later I found out there were sources of unlimited food and water scattered about. There are locations that have a big bowl of unlimited food next to a trough of unlimited drinking water. Maybe it's different on the absolute highest difficulties, but the game just seems to throw an excess of supplies at you, and given that it's a linear experience you'd think resource management would be more important than a cursory exercise. And then I lost all enthusiasm for the exploration when I reached the cave system with identical passageways everywhere and a 'mysterious' black cloud of instant death that you have to run away from.I really regret purchasing and spending time with this game, as both the mysteries and the gameplay challenges turned out to both be shallow in many ways.

number of helpful: 9 of 21 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												Disclaimer: This review is only based on the first 2-3 hours of gameplay.The Solus Project markets itself as an immersive survival/exploration game. Unfortunately it's hard to be immersed when you're bored waiting for a game to get good.The survival gameplay initially seems promising, tracking your health, water, calories, body temperature and fatigue, as well as the environmental temperature, humidity and windspeed, on a PDA that slides into view when you look down (I imagine this is a nice effect in VR - I played on a standard PC). You have an inventory to manage, prioritising food, refillable water containers and medkits. You construct a rudimentary torch from debris, stock up on supplies, and are ready to explore the nearby cave system. Unfortunately I quickly realise there's always plenty of food and water available (even underground) so managing hunger and thirst quickly becomes a chore. In the week or so of in-game time that has passed by torch (a bit of oil and kindling on a metal rod) has never gone out. The only stat I found myself paying attention to was the temperature. This boils down to using the torch if it's cold and using another light source (flashlight, crystal, glowstick) if it's hot. This game appears to be a walking simulator with survival aspects tacked on. Unfortunately, survival is not tense or difficult, just tedious and boring.Ok, so it's not really a survival game. That's ok, there should still be plenty of fun to be had from freely exploring, without having to worry about dying of thirst, right? Well, the level design itself is fairly linear. Sometimes there are a few different branches you can take from A to B. The main incentive to explore is to discover secrets. These are basically objects that give you a minor stat increase. Only, surviving is basically just a distraction and a chore and the secrets don't contribute anything to the plot, so searching for them is just another chore in itself. Additionally, the areas are often fairly open with lots of nooks and crannies. It just isn't my idea of fun to wander around the edge of a map looking for the opening, or spending hours jumping on rocks to see if I can climb up (you usually can't)."Oh well, maybe I'm trying to make too much of this game. Let's just get immersed in the story and the visuals and get lost in this world." I gave up on this when I realised how much of the plot relied on 'scattered notes'. When you find a piece of paper on the ground that starts with 'Yuri's Diary - 1/24' you realise you'll spend the next 10 minutes following these breadcrumbs and just hoping you don't miss any or read them out of order. The text doesn't appear all at once, it appears as if someone is typing. Accidentally move your mouse off the note and you have to start again. It is infuriating.One time, I left an indoor campsite, crouched through a crawlspace, walked through a cave, and came outside only to discover it was like 50 degrees and I was going to get hyperthermia if I stayed outside. I had to backtrack all the way to the campsite just so I could rest until evening. Not only is survival tedious, it's actually actively hindering your progress. This would be fine if it created a challenge, but it just creates more tedium.On the upside, the visuals are quite nice (if a little samey) and I feel like if I had stuck with it the plot might have picked up steam. The major problem is this game doesn't know what it wants to be. The survival gameplay, the exploration and level design, and the plot delivery are entirely at odds with each other. They contantly try and pull you in different directions making for a very tiresome experience.

number of helpful: 8 of 19 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												THIS IS A VR REVIEW:  Amazing game, not quite ready for VR though...I had to refund the game as much as I didn't want to. I played the game on Xbox One and I loved play it from beginning to end.  I recently got my HTC Vive and when I saw SP had Vive support I bought it with much anticipation.  The graphics are breathtaking and beautiful in virtual space, but... the game is just not ready for VR.  I DO UNDERSTAND IT IS A WORK IN PROGRESS, but if you jump into the game expecting a fluid experience then you might be disappointed.  Even with a GTX 1070, 32GB of RAM, and an I7, I was experiencing frequent jittering, my person shifting slightly, and other errors that made the game unplayable in VR for me.  This caused me to get headaches from the jittering and motion sickness from the shifting.  I've played about 30 VR thus far and haven't had this problem until now.  So in it's present VR state, I can't recommend, I suggest waiting until it's fully optimized before jumping in.  Outside of VR the game is still an amazing survival game full of exploration and mystery and I recommend playing it.

												Played this on a Vive for a few hours and I don't think I'll play it anymore because it's just feeling so tedious. Got into the caves and it feels like I was spelunking through a low-poly mess of jagged tunnels with an occasional low-res model feature.  I had the graphics settings cranked too. The survival aspects only add to the tedium. Got to remember to pick survival items up, eat, drink, sleep, stay warm. Super boring after a few cycles of this.Maybe outside of VR this is ok, but it just hurts to look at in the headset. The immersion feels really low.Had to backtrack through said featureless caves to get fire again because it turns out I would die of hyperthermia without it and I wandered around in the dark for a while getting totally over this experience very quickly.The interface in VR is very unintuitive, I kept having to visit the controls screen periodically. Jumping and moving in VR is just the worst as well, why even keep this feature? Remove them and remove the amount of controls you have to remember. Inventory was exceedingly clunky and hard to use. Most of the time I felt like I was missing some trick as to how to use this intuitively, but I don't think it's there.Some suggestions for subsequent games:* Bumbling around dark featureless caves is very unrewarding, add more detail to caves, or make them shorter* Overhal the VR interface, check out Vanishing Realms or The Gallery for how to do it rightI've watched some videos as how this game plays out and there's some really good stuff several hours in, but I can't bring myself to slog it out to get there. Also checked out the ending because I decided I'm not going back to this game and I would have been majorly disappointed with that if I'd stuck it out.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												Don't buy this and expect a proper virtual reality experience. I can't and won't comment on its content as I took only a quick look at it before issuing my first steam refund..As others said, you'll navigate menus by "looking" at buttons and by using the controller's trigger to pushIf you like to use the locomotion "walking" style, you'll walk in the direction where you're currently lookingYou can't walk backwards or sidewards, except you'll turn your head to the left or right (locomotion walking style)To crouch you'll need to press a button on one of the controllersDid I already said you'll navigate menus by looking at them? This continues to ingame menus like your inventory..The developers obviously replaced the mouse input with the HMD. And, on top of that, the official HTC Vive instructions are out of date and are missing an update since about four months.In its current state, this game doesn't deserve the label "VR ready".Edit: Well, the developer corrected me (see comments) and stated that these are technical issues. However, the walking style I described (now cut through) is still a somehow strange default. And whilst the menu navigation is due to the used unreal engine it still hinders me from enjoying this game in VR, in its current state. Let's have a look once there is an VR related update incoming.

												I played for ~3 hours and made some meaningful progress in the game, but I honestly just didn't like it.I didn't have any fun exploring the world.  The survival component was simplistic and tedious, and it detracted from exploration rather than contributing anything desirable to the gameplay.  I also didn't find the world to be immersive or suspenseful or even particularly aesthetic.  It felt transparently artificial.  I was not amused by any of the puzzles either.---Who Might Enjoy This Game?---If, in the year 2016, Myst still excites you as much as it excited people in the early 90's, then you might enjoy this game.  But even *if* you're part of that niche, I actually think you may prefer The Witness, which I thought was a much better game than this.  I can't strongly recommend The Witness either, but insofar as open-world puzzle games go, I think it succeeded in all the ways that I wish this game had.

number of helpful: 7 of 18 people (39%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												The road to hell is paved with good intentions. Very crudely, in this case.The Solus Project is a lazy effort that fails at being even a decent game, not to mention a good story-driven survival game.Survival: Food and water are plentiful, the torch you build within ten minutes of starting the game is permanent as it never runs out of fuel and gves you heat and light for the entire game. The torch can be extinguished if you dive into water while holding it but if it's in yout inventory, it's completely safe. Being frozen is a real danger unless you wisely choose to nap for 10 hours so it's +30 degrees outside, rendering the soaked/frozen part moot.Puzzles: They are not. The extent of puzzles is "Press a button", "Put a rock onto a button" and "Throw the teleporter disk into a narrow opening".General design: It's an Unreal fanfic, and a mediocre at that. Everything reminds of Na-Pali, including the two races, crucifixes made for a four-armed victim (although race C7 has two arms) and the "stone tablets translated by your PDA" plot delivery. It's also clearly visible that the map designer simply loves cloning hexagonal pillars with the same size and texture.Plot: It's seriously bad. Firstly, the entirety of the game is "gather parts for a radio tower to phone home" with no deeper reasoning and, more importantly, all the writings on the stone tablets that you decipher have no influence on the protagonist's actions even if they... REALLY should. And there's no intrigue whatsoever. The voice acting from the radio operator is quite good, though.Exploration: You don't need to. The only really useful items are the backpacks that allow you to hoard more stuff, but you don't need most of the "very rare" items. On the other hand, in a few places the game devolves into Item Quest. Because the only way to break weak stone walls is a mighty hammer, useful only for breaking weak stone walls and taking up inventory space otherwise.So: Bad design, an excuse plot, poor puzzles, a poor survival mechanic and, ultimately, confusing and needless lore. Good intentions, bad paving.

number of helpful: 4 of 12 people (33%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 28, 2016
												This game is great graphically, and it is kinda creepy. However, navigating the map (in the inevitable underground areas just sucks) since there is no real mini map and your waypoints are no help (As the point may want you to go down or up but you can't always tell). Although immersion wise it is pretty cool...from a "fun perspective" i just can't recommend. I like games to be interesting and challenging...but i don't like it when i need to google how to get past specific parts of the game because it is just not intuitive or even remotely easy to identify the next steps. Early on i found a place where i obviously need a key..but have no idea where it is. Travelling around would be fun...if there weren't random things trying to kill you, nighttime temp that kills you, random lighting storms that kill you, aliens that kill you, sun rising (super hot temp) that kills you...getting the theme here? it is a survival/exploration game that forces you to put aside the exploration and really just hide at regular intervals bc of all the stuff trying to kill you. YA it is a survival game i get it..but that's not its only tag...it was also tagged as an exploration game with mechanisms in place to lower the survival elements, but you can't lower them enough. It is frustrating to have to revisit teh same spots over and over again to do simple tasks because of the near constant environmental effects trying to kill you. it just gets old after going back to the same place for the 10th time and only having precious moments to search around (and try to remember where you already searched) before you run and hide in a cave for 10 minutes waiting for the storm (or whatever is trying to kill you) to go away, then you rinse and repeat again and agin.  In the future on a new planet, might this be accurate depiction of what you would face trying to survive? possibly..hell i don't know. But for now...as a game...is what i described above actually fun in a game? No..it's not. i wish there was a way to turn off all the random enviornmental effects so i could actually focus on exploration...(you can do this somewhat with the hunger/thirst meter but not the enivronmental stuff. so it just got old...search around..find something cool..run away and hide from alien/environmental event..then try to get back to that spot (rinse and repeat) till you find what you need to get to next area. or get stuck and spend time on internet trying to figure out how to do what game wants you to do next. good atmosphere, nice graphics..but just not that fun as is. If you like survival game elements above all else..then ya this is your bag. If you were hoping for more exploration and less annoying survival elements artificially prolonging the game bc you have to revisit the same places repeatedly to accomplish anything..well then you are like me and its not your thing...in that case, stay far away.

content:

Early Access Review
								I love a good survival game, too bad this isn't one.The map limits you to a few narrow corridors. What passes for the survival element is your fading food, water, and sleep meters. Replenishing these feels more like a chore than an adventure. There are no real options available: just hunt around for cans of food, refill your water bottles time and again, and try to figure out how the designer intended you to worm your way into the next area. Rinse and repeat.The opening and cut scenes are tedious, but the game play graphics are great.I wouldn't recommend this game. Well, unless you think it's fun to look for keys to unlock the next area while gathering conveniently placed food/water to reset your food and water timers.If your idea of survival involves wide ranging choices, random discoveries, random dangers, and the freedom to venture into the forest or scrounge along the beach, forget it.

Product received for free
Early Access Review
								The Solus Project comes as a fairly placid game in 2D despite the promise of mysterious adventure and hybrid gameplay. However, in VR it takes on a whole new level of detail and immerses the player into an impressive sci-fi adventure that’s very much a must have game for those who are looking for a more laid back adventure experience. Action fans need not apply here as this game isn’t for you, but if you have an open mind to explore and survive then this comes highly recommended, and with its low price point you’ll certainly get your monies worth.


YouTube™ Video: The Solus Project Review 

			Views: 12,908		

			Grip Games releases its final version of The Solus Project on Xbox One and PC and having been in Early Access since the beginning of the year and being almost three years in the making.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												:VIVE Owner:I wish I could return this. It's just not fun. You walk around picking stuff up, that's the game. After hours of gameplay I got to a point where you have to assemble a communication tower. The catch is you have to walk around collecting 17 individual peices of this thing scattered around an island. Who thinks this is fun? Who's birght idea when they were making this was to have the player spend an hour walking around picking of SEVENTEEN peices of junk.  Besides that you spend the first few hours just walking though dark caves and there's so much contrast you have constant issues with lens halo's and blurriness. Edit: they let me return it :). To clarify, I just did'nt find it very intersting. The environment is not compelling enough to keep me entertained while picking up stuff here and there. For an "exploration adventure game" I need something more then a different colored sky, red trees, and the occasional odd plant to keep me entertained. I go hiking frequently in RL and spending my free time walking around a bland and sterile simulated environment picking up junk to maybe use later is not what I got a VIVE for.

number of helpful: 5 of 17 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												I played the normal PC version.  This game is basically a frustration simulator with some terrible design decisions that prevent it from being an enjoyable experience.  The premise of being an astronaut stuck on an alien world having to explore and use your ingenuity to survive is an enticing one and here the developers have created a beautiful looking and sounding world to wander.  However, I have played for three hours now and have become increasingly frustrated by the janky movement and jumping mechanics, the regular occurences of being stuck in the environment with no way out (except to reload your previous safe) and dying because your character's spacesuit is not hardy enough to tolerate a 6 inch drop.  The worst moment was probably exploring up to the top of a mountain and dropping down into a secret cave below full of giant shells.  I found some new items there and an interesting headstone but when I went to leave I found there was no way out of the cave.  45 minutes later and I had to reload the game and lose those items and the time I spent.  That kind of thing is just not fun and I simply don't have time to play a game that punishes you purely for doing so.

number of helpful: 5 of 20 people (25%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
												Restarting my review because I made a rookie mistake: I played Hardcore Mode right from the start. That's because I was expecting a hardcore, sci-fi survival experience mixed with discoveries that felt rewarding, and intuitive enough of UI, UX, story and gameplay to get me through the game, even on hardcore mode. ("Hardcore" after all, refers to ease of survival, not intuitive player gating, progression, quest & waypoint systems, and puzzle hints)What I got instead was a handful of deaths, and I never once figured out how to get out of the "starting area" (again, in Hardcore Mode)—so this is my fault, and I should dial back a bit on my criticism of the game. I'm sure if I played an easier mode I would have had more guidance.But what *still* troubles me is finding out that *spoiler alert* --------------------> the starting area isn't what the whole game is like. That's, I guess, why I was jumping around on basalt columns. I thought it was an open-world experience that was meant to continue on the other, nearby islands as I continued to discover beautiful shrines and etc. Instead, apparently, the cave is pretty much where you *have to* go to get anywhere, and apparently the cave leads to nothing but more cave-ness.Imagine playing Skyrim, but by the time you get to the first "dungeon" of the game, you never go back out into the outer world to continue exploring. That's how the Solus Project feels (as of yet), and that's why I asked for my money back. I paid half the price of Skyrim for what I thought would be an indie, sci-fi, survival/suspense version of "half the game", so to speak, but that is definitely not what I got.I think I was jumping around on basalt columns because I was hoping that WOULD cause me to get somewhere and make progress in the outside, survival-world. Maybe the developer should implement that, because according to most reviews, once you enter the "main cave tunnel", the whole survival element goes out the window.Why not expand on the outside world, and put some fallen ships with treasure in them at the top of a path of basalt columns? That would be a much more rewarding dynamic than what people are finding in the game as it is.I still want my money back for this game, but I don't hate it. A lot about it was very good, but it was *not* a final release for VR or for PC, and it should therefore not (yet) be sold at the price it is sold at, unless it's declared an early-access price. I found plenty of bugs and so have many others.This game needs more time in the oven for VR development and more focus testing for the PC version. I will keep an eye on it and re-purchase down the line if it is A) sold for the price of an "unfinished experience" or B) brought up to the standards of a true $20 "final game" in the survival game category.

												I don't want to be overly critical, but I was unable to continue forth with this game. On my vive, the navigation quickly turned my stomach. I've logged plenty of hours with my vive across 50 different games and experiences, but this was the first to make me feel uncomfortable.The visuals were also not on par with what I would hope for $20. The abundance of small text seems like such a poor choice  for a VR game, and staring closely at my hand to read quickly removed me enjoying the world around me. I may have been willing to push through the queasiness if the game had been more instantly engaging, but unfortunately I will be requesting my first Steam refund ever. I'm sure many people will enjoy this but I personally would spend that $20 elsewhere.
